column1: I had high hopes for this book since I thoroughly enjoyed and laughed out loud while reading Bryson's 'In a Sunburned Country'. I was more than a little disappointed after finished `Lost Continent' I came away feeling more than a little disappointed.      Before I bought this book I was puzzled at the contrasting reviews here and I initially took the most of the negative reviews with a grain of salt. I figured these were written by people who mostly just took offense way too easily and were unable to laugh at themselves as Americans. I have to say though
column2: after reading the book I find myself agreeing with some of the negative reviews of this book.       First off
column3: as an American that has lived overseas for 3 years now
column4: I feel I'm more than capable of looking at America with an objective eye. I'm completely aware of America's many shortcomings - ie.  the propensity for urban sprawl
column5: the seemingly declining interest in it's rich history
column6: the ever growing dependence on technology and increasing laziness that invariably comes with it etc. etc.     Having said that
column7: I still regard this book primarily as just one endless
column8: tiring
column9: repetitive rant by an unhappy man. One would be hard pressed to find more than a couple instances where Bryson spent more than three of four sentences at a time describing anything he found ENJOYABLE. As one reviewer pointed out
column10: Bryson comes across as being exactly like the kind of people he constantly complains about in this book...rude
column11: ignorant
column12: and
column13: just like Bryson himself
column14: overweight (apparently he hasn't stepped in front of a mirror lately). One has to wonder why someone would put out a book that is so consistently sour in tone. If I had just finished such a thoroughly unsatisfying and unhappy trek as this
column15: I would be hard pressed to come up with a good reason (other than a quick buck perhaps) to actually write a book about it. Let me get one thing straight
column16: if this were a book about Canada or anywhere else outside the U.S. I would feel the same way. Yes
column17: there are a few funny passages in his book
column18: but his air of superiority along with the overuse of metaphors pretty much dampen it at times. As demonstrated in `In a Sunburned Country'
column19: his strength lies in sharing facts and history of the places he finds himself in
column20: and the humor is always much more engaging when it isn't over the top and written as if he's trying to impress himself.        There was a span of about 12 years between the writing of `Lost Continent' and `In a Sunburned Country'
column21: and it shows. This is a younger Bryson
column22: a man who seems to have a problem with every little detail
column23: and it becomes increasingly tedious and irritating as the book goes on. He rarely displays anything other than contempt for the places he finds himself in. A couple of other reviewers also made valid points when they found it curious that (with the exception of his Iowa drug buddy) he never manages to engage anyone in anything resembling a meaningful conversation to actually get a handle on their mindset (as he did in "In A Sunburned Country' for instance). His interactions with locals are mostly limited to ordering food at local restaurants and asking for directions. He seems perfectly content coming to conclusions about entire groups of people based on no real substance and communication whatsoever.       In this book
column24: sadly
column25: he comes across as nothing more than a sarcastic
column26: anti-social loner with a bone to pick with just about everyone and everything. Any remotely kind words he has about anything (and they are few and far between) are all but smothered by the sour tone of the book as a whole. I SO wish I could recommend this book for others to read
column27: but I'd be lying if I said it's time well spent

column1: Mr. Erasmus's book is possibly the most widely known book on the subject of fats.   Unfortunately
column2: the book's wide currency and authoritative stance does not hold up in light of crucial facts.  It contains a lot of awesome scientific formulas
column3: tables
column4: analyses
column5: and so forth
column6: and would appear to be an authoritative
column7: definitive "final answer" on fats
column8: but there is much in it that is alarmingly inaccurate and misleading. His conclusions on polyunsaturates
column9: saturated fats
column10: coconut oil
column11: butter
column12: flax and canola oil are all haphazard and inconsistent with fact-based science (For example
column13: read the findings of Sally Fallon and Mary G. Enig in their document on canola oil: http[...]).  Much of Erasmus's conclusions
column14: especially about vegetable based polyunsaturates
column15: reflect current dietary trends than anything else. Hemp oil
column16: which he espouses
column17: contains cannabinoids
column18: the compounds found in marijuana: people eating hemp oil have failed a clean test for drugs in corporation testing. Moreover
column19: the book promotes manufactured oils which Mr. Erasmus utilizes in his very expensive oil blend
column20: which are high in polyunsaturates.   For true science and data on fats
column21: one would be better to turn to Mary G. Enig's "Know Your Fats
column22:
which is the real, pioneering guide on fats. Enig is one of the world's foremost lipid biochemists, and she provides specific science and how fats work in the body and what the body needs. Also of value is her book 'Eat Fat Lose Fat' and Bruce Fife's 'The Coconut Oil Miracle,' which despels a lot of the myths regarding saturated and tropical fats. Erasmus provides very little information about the properties of coconut oil. Enig and Fife present common sense and scientific logic in their research and delivering of facts, something which is lacking in Erasmus's book. Enig is clear, and consistent from beginning to end: Erasmus's stand is contradictory.

Send in your query or your three chapters to fifty of these guys and then wait.  First
column2: they don't want to read them.  They hire someone to do this task.  They don't want to do it either.  They send you their rejection card and don't even acknowledge the title of your book.  Once they did. Now they're too many of you.  They do get shills to write good things about their own published book because they want the expectant writer to buy it.  That's how they make money.  You must have a contact with a publisher or an agent or they won't touch your stuff.  Even Hemingway was going nowhere until Scott Fitzgarald reccommended him.  Enough though of opinion.  Ask anyone that you know who is an aspiring writer if they ever got a positive response from an agent.  Michael Blake "Dances With Wolves" never got an agent until Costner said he was going to make the movie.  Even then it was like pulling rotting teeth.  The publishers sent regection after rejection until Blake sold it for $5
column3: 000 (to be published in paperback)with a $1
column4: 000 bonus if the picture was actually released.  He had given up writing after 35 years when "Dances" sold.  But who did he have to know...Kevin Costner of all people.  Another agent
column5: not Blake's
column6: said he had only taken one client on in one year and only because the guy sent him a bottle of French wine.  He liked French wine.  Go to the agent.  (How badly do you want to be published?) Talk to the agent.  Find out if they are even in the neighborhood of what it is that you're writing.  Call publishers.  Talk to their assistants.  They'll talk to you if you keep it short.  Find out what they really want.  Go to the library or the internet but don't encourage these "Write and be published authors."  They are conning you.  None of these agents have the slightest intention of reading your chapters.  Anyway
column7: one way or the other you will find out.  Don't use someone else unless you have an "in;" be your own agent.  Good luck you writers.  Some of you are great and are anguished over nothing.  You will succeed.  Do it yourself and don't forget foreign publishers that publish in English.  They will read your stuff. For heaven's sake's don't just sit there! Good hunting!

column1: I have read Webber's book for a class
column2: and I generally was not impressed. His arguments for returning to the Ancient church (he defines from 100-600AD) I don't think hold up.  He thinks that the Ancient church is the solution to post-modernism
column3: and he seems to naively present that period
column4: as if it did not have any problems. But we know that it was full of debates on theology.  Can we also go back to the Ancient church? Even though some people call this period post-modern
column5: we have not given up all the attributes of modern thinking. We are still highly critical thinkers. I am starting to think that hyper-modern is a better name for this period.   Webber is more interested in the practices after the NT was written
column6: than he is about thinking about the church as it is described in the NT. Yes the church in Acts and the Epistles was in flux trying to find it's way
column7: but wouldn't Paul be more better to read and thought about
column8: than the people and structures after the apostles? What ever happened to confidence in scripture? Surely it is more trustworthy than the Ancient church

column1: Wuthering Heights the novel grabs you at the first page and drags you through passion
column2: betrayal
column3: madness
column4: despair
column5: greed
column6: hatred
column7: and revenge. It's not necessarily a pleasant read
column8: but always an engrossing one. Emily Bronte's characters jump off the page and will continue to haunt you long after you've finished the book.   Modern day moviemakers have had a notoriously bad time translating any of the Bronte sisters' works into film and this is no exception. The characters are representations in name only and fail to capture any of the true spirit behind this amazing book. Juliet Binoche and Ralph Fiennes are two of the best actors working in film today
column9: but this movie is a definite low point for both.    As Heathcliff and Catherine
column10: Fiennes and Binoche seem to have failed to grasp the depth or the passions of the characters and their performances are flat and bland. Binoche's personality is too grounded and mature for the wild and carefree Cathy so she compensates with endless giggling that got on my nerves. Fiennes comes across as greasy and sullen instead of a tormented and complex soul; he simply does not have the charisma or the depth to play such a demanding role. The other characters are likewise lacking in realism
column11: only Janet McTeer fares well
column12: she is fabulous as Ellen Dean.   Even if the acting were better
column13: the story does not capture the essence of the book. Everything moves too quickly
column14: the film jumps around frequently and large plot holes are left either unexplained or are patched quickly with a few brusque words. Sinead O'Conner's appearance as Emily Bronte to bookend the film is contrived and unnecessary.  This film was very obviously made on a budget and the sets and costumes show it. The wigs are dreadful and the costumes are for the most part
column15: ugly and unflattering. Fiennes actually looks potbellied in some of his vests!   Maybe someday someone will make a film that does this remarkable book justice. This isn't it

column10: is not only a awkward rhyme, but one of many analogies to terrorism and the Holocaust for street-success. The attitude is polarized between death-threatening lyrics of pained animosity (Speak On It" and "Jealousy") to olive-branch offerings of peace

column28: Kurupt must consider his now higher wall to climb back to mainstream consciousness and present-day respect. The grains got the best of him.

column1: I have a problem with Bakke's idea of "fun."  Fun
column2: by his definition is a free-for-all.  For example
column3: he feels that an organization's "amount of fun" is determined by "the number of individuals allowed to make decisions" (99).  I agree that sharing information "reinforces the feeling of community" (98)
column4: but I don't agree with his suggestion that leaders should "ask for as much advice as possible before making a decision" (88).  "Sharing information" and "seeking advice" are two different things.    Bakke misuses the analogy of a child jumping into the arms of a parent by stating that the same is required of leaders to jump into the arms of the subordinate (103).  It is the subordinate who should trust the leader.  In one section of the book
column5: he stresses the importance of "asking for as much advice as possible before making a decision."  But in another section he shares the story of his administrative assistant who "routinely checks with the office accountant to see how her decisions would affect the budget
column6: but no higher approval is necessary" (apparently no other advice is needed as well) (79).  His idea of leadership lacks strength by decentralizing decision-making to others.   In his postscript
column7: Bakke discusses Biblical leadership.  At first glance
column8: what he writes sounds Biblical-"serve the people they lead
column9: and allow followers to use their talents effectively" (261)
column10: but his overall idea of leadership is not Biblical.  For instance
column11: he says
column12: "The Creation story does not assign people
column13: even leaders
column14: the responsibility of `managing' other people" (261)- I wonder what he thought God meant in Genesis 3:16 when He told Eve
column15: "he will be your master."  The Bible doesn't use the word
column16: "manage
column17: but God entrusted leaders to people throughout the Bible-that's why there were judges in the OT.  I don't think the Israelites would've left the wilderness if Moses asked as many as possible" before making a decision

column1: This book is somewhat intriguing. It is indeed an authoritative  scholarly account of the growth of government in the United States
column2: and for that reason only well worth reading. However
column3: there is a pervading subtext of libertarian conspiracy theory about governmental power in the book that leaves the reader wondering if the author might not be masquerading a scholarly endeavour (that in itself is very rewarding) in order to suggest that government is the incarnation of evil. The fundamental truth which is developed here
column4: that there is a permanent and necessary contradiction between the development of governmental power and individual liberty is unsophisticated
column5: not to say outright crude. In addition
column6: the author's thesis that after each crisis resulting in the growth of governmental capacities and power the government  (always conceptualized as a large undifferentiated whole in the book) tends to rationalize its subsequent business in order not to loose what it just gained is not a discovery of the highest order. This is the rule in every institutional setting
column7: whether corporate or bureaucratic
column8: we know that since Max Weber's work on bureaucracy
column9: without the libertarian hogwash

column1: The book Hubbert's Peak: The Impending World Oil Shortage is about the economy and the impact one scientist had on the world with his predictions.  Hubbert's theory stated that in the early 1970's oil production would reach its highest level. He was doubted my many scientists
column2: but when it came true scientists used it to look at what the future holds for oil production. It is expected to hit this decade at some point. This book describes the origin of oil and development over the many years. It also describes several different oil fields and the prosperity of them
column3: and the different types of techniques and bits used to find oils by scientists. Each scientist has different methods of finding the oil fields
column4: and they use data sets to record the sites and sizes of them. It provides an overview of what the future holds for oil production
column5: and what different kinds of energy we can resort too if needed to avoid the economic troubles lying ahead. 	I thought this book was overall pretty boring. I wasn't  entertained or hooked on it
column6: and it didn't make me want to keep reading in the end. I found it very confusing most of the time
column7: and it had a lot of information to try to digest all at once
column8: such as numbers and equations. It wasn't the kind of book I really get indulged in
column9: and want to read more of
column10: or cant put down.  	I would recommend this book to those who like to read books about our economy and what's going on in different industries. This book is easier to read for adults
column11: as it contains advanced material that could confuse younger children. For those who enjoy reading advanced books about our economy or oil
column12: this is an excellent book.

column1: Interview is definitely a different type of magazine for me- someone who usually reads business and travel mags- and it's not quite what I expected. With a title like "Interview" I read my first copy of this magazine anticipating pages and pages of nothing but interviews. It turns out that interviewing is the main focus of the magazine
column2: but it's not the only one. There is substantial space given to fashion
column3: movies
column4: and other areas
column5: too. Some of these columns are worth an occasional look
column6: but they failed to grab my attention. The writers seem to play it safe
column7: and that includes the interview section. They don't ask many daring or controversial questions. They keep it simple
column8: asking questions about an entertainer's latest album or movie
column9: without delving much into their personal lives.   Interview has many general annoyances. My greatest complaint is the advertising and the arrangement of the contents. About half of the pages in each issue are covered with ads
column10: with fashion
column11: liquor
column12: beer
column13: and hair care items providing the bulk of the advertising revenue. The ads are everywhere
column14: with the majority in the front pages of each issue. The table of contents is buried
column15: and I find this very frustrating. The contents starts with the interviews for that specific issue on one page
column16: then a few pages later
column17: proceeds to the remainder of the contents
column18: which is the regular monthly features. What's annoying is that you have to search for the table of contents. It varies from one issue to the next
column19: falling somewhere in the first half.   Interview also varies greatly in length. Some issues are as short as 80 pages while others are more than 200 pages long. The shorter issues use staples for binding while the longer issues are bound in a more professional way
column20: minus any metal.   This magazine centers on entertainers
column21: fashion
column22: music
column23: and the like. You won't find any interviews with politicians
column24: businessmen
column25: etc. Interview sticks strictly to entertainers
column26: and that includes the regular monthly columns. You won't find a column about the business side of the music industry or film industry. You will find only articles about the stars themselves.   Interview's only saving grace is the photography. It would make a nice gift for those who enjoy fashion and who like looking at pages and pages of men and women modeling fancy clothing. But in many ways
column27: the photos are overemphasized and there isn't enough substance to the magazine. The articles are very shallow with more eye candy than reading material.   Overall
column28: Interview is sloppy and cluttered with too many ads to make it worthwhile reading material. My subscription was free
column29: and I'm thankful that it was. Besides a few nice photos for clothing
column30: there isn't much to make this magazine worth the cost.

column1: I am honestly shocked that not one of the reviews so far written on this page offers any true insight into what a poor offering this album is.  I love Dar and tried over and over to give this album a chance to grow on me but it just does not.  Its only few strongpoints are "Hudson" and "Blue light of the Flame".  Altough "Everyone knows this is Knowhere" is a neat and fun song it fails to do what a truly great cover song sometimes can (provide a brand new look at the original) Cheack out Jonatha Brooke's version of Alan Parson's  "Eye in the sky".   Dar Williams is a great artist.  No artist ( in fact I would venture far enough to say no human being aside from one of the living members of Pink floyd) should EVER cover Comfortably Numb.     Her attempt at doing so is not just a poor choice but a pathetic use of studio time.  Listen to Mortal City and tell me whether this is a good album at all.  Great artists make poor albums that is what this is no matter what she names it.

I had high hopes for this book that were quickly dashed by a number of glaring problems.  Nick Eberstadt is a demographer/economist and he analyzes North Korea solely in these terms.  If he were to write a book about North Korean economics
column2: he would probably be capable of writing a masterpiece.  As it is
column3: he steps out of his well-troden field and attempts to predict the future of an entire country from a demographic/economic perspective.  The hubris of Eberstadt's work is that he ventures to write about things he knows little to nothing about. ...In this book
column4: Eberstadt simplifies North Korea into a one-sided demon bristing with weaponry and a declared enemy of the free world.  While this may be true
column5: it is difficult to take him seriously since he analyzes North Korea wholly from the outside.  Curiously missing from his book is a history of the internal developments that allowed North Korea to survive even when the Communist Bloc states fell like dominoes in the 1980s

column1: When is everyone going to learn - there is no such thing as a how-to-get-rich book.  The title for the book is a joke itself.  Trump and his editors were probably laughing all the way to the bank when they thought of the title.  Seriously

There is so much white space in the book because there is not much writing in terms of quantity or quality!  The advice is so mundane.  Half of the book is memoirs of a week as Trump - boooring.  And I don't want to read about the show in the last chapter.  I cannot believe this book was published.  The writing stinks and there is even some typos.  Trump may produce quality buildings
column4: but that cannot be said of his books

column1: Edward Wilson's works unravel of their own accord.  He tells us that human beings do not have free will.  Ergo
column2: Edward Wilson did not choose to write this book
column3: or any book.  He did not choose what to believe
column4: nor has anyone
column5: and therefore he can make no objective claim to correct knowledge.  If what he says is true then nothing he says can be trusted since it is merely the product of an infinite myriad of uncontrollable externalities working in concert to produce whatever it is that happens to come out of his physical manifestation.  It is even debatable whether or not evolution had true belief or correct knowledge as one of its requirements for survival.  Indeed it can be shown that false belief as much as true belief (and in fact no belief at all) can infer an increased level of fitness on the host organism.   If evolutionary psychology has any truth at all its truth is that we cannot trust our mental faculties to obtain the truth at all.  Nihilism in the truest sense

column1: Mr. Dennett's book demonstrates the ignorance
column2: irrationality
column3: and dishonesty  of humanists. Discussing the meaning of word materialsim
column4: Professor Dennett says:  "In its scientific or philosophical sense
column5: it refers to a theory that aspires to explain all the phenomena without recourse to anything immaterial--like a Cartesian soul
column6: or "ectoplasm"--or God. The standard negation of materialistic in the scientific sense is dualistic
column7: which maintains that there are two entirely different kinds of substance
column8: matter and ...whatever minds are supposedly made of." (p. 302)  Philosophers stopped believing in dualism a thousand years ago with the development of metaphysics. A modern view is that man is an indefinability that becomes conscious of its own existence.   The philosophy that God does not exist is not materialism
column9: it is naturalism. Materialism is the view that all that exists is matter. Materialists frequently say that free will is an illusion and that the experience of the existence of oneself is some kind of epiphenomena. (In a quote below
column10: you will see that Dennett puts free will in a list of things people belief in.)  It is not clear from the book whether Dennett is a materialist
column11: but he is certainly a naturalist. Concerning the proof of God's existence
column12: he trots out David Hume's "Who made God?" which is based on a misunderstanding of the principle of causality. I refer the reader to my personal website for my version of the proof.  Let's look at two quotes
column13: the first is at the end of the chapter "Belief in Belief" and the other at the beginning of the chapter "Morality and Religion":   "That is
column14: isn't it true that
column15: whether or not God exists
column16: religious belief is at least as important as the belief in democracy
column17: in the rule of law
column18: in free will? The very widespread (but far from universal) opinion is that religion is the bulwark of morality and meaning." (p. 245)  " Without the divine carrot and stick
column19: goes this reasoning
column20: people would loll about aimlessly or indulge their basest desires
column21: beak their promises
column22: cheat on their spouses
column23: neglect their duties
column24: and so on.  There are two well-known problems with this reasoning: (1) it doesn't seem to be true
column25: which is good news
column26: since (2) is is such a demeaning view of human nature." (p. 279)  In the first chapter
column27: he mentions "bulwark of morality" and "meaning." But in the second chapter
column28: he leaves out "meaning."  If our purpose in life is not to get to heaven
column29: what is our purpose is life?   Whether religion supports morality can be determined by observing whether there is a correlation of moral conduct with religious belief. Mr. Dennett makes such a correlation to the detriment of religion by citing the high divorce rate of fundamentalist Christians.  There are worse things than divorcing your spouse. Disingenuousness can be worse and can take the form of leaving unsaid what should have been said. Mr. Dennett should have explained why he did not discuss the idea that religion gives meaning to life.  The only miracle mentioned in Mr. Dennett's book is the Shroud of Turin
column30: which has on it a mysterious image of a crucified man.  Since no one claims to know how the image got there
column31: it can be called a miracle. However
column32: Mr. Dennett does not tell us anything about it. The reader is left to find out about the famous relic by looking it up on the internet.

column1: What a waste of money!  After sending about 160 letters to the various recruiters listed in this book
column2: about 90 were returned as undeliverable due to firms out of business and people moving to different firms.  The headhunter business is extremely fluid and recruiters apparently do not remain with a firm for any length of time.  The book also advises people not to call a recruiter on the telephone.  This must be an attempt to alleviate the recruiters from having to actually speak to a person without having a sure shot position open for them.  The authors must be former recruiters because they seem to write from a recruiter's point of view and not a job seeker's.  The book's advice and how-to sections are common sense; anyone with half a brain uses the steps outlined in the book already without having to be told to do so.  All that this book accomplishes is to line the pockets of the authors at the expense of people who are looking for valid resources that can assist them in a job search.  Ask your Uncle Ralph if he knows of anyone who is hiring and don't give these two useless people
column3: (Christopher Hunt and Scott Scanlon) any of your hard earned money
column4: especially if you're currently unemployed.  P.S.  the only reason my review has one star is because I wasn't offered the option of no stars

column1: Ok
column2: first of all
column3: read that ttle again. Don't you love how idiotic grown ups sounds when they try to
column4: like
column5: borrow the vernacular twists of their offspring for ironic employment in a
column6: like
column7: polemical setting? Reminds me of Cusack's dad in 'Better off Dead
column8: ' the way he keeps trying to talk to his son on his son's level. There's so much bad faith and pretension permeating this book- it's all there in the title...  As for the' author's "polemic
column9:
it basically consits of numerous, misinformed, tendentious tracts soldered together into a rusty heap. You've heard this spiel before, most likely from your grandparents or parents who just don't get it- that they had their time. This is our era. Our use of language reflects and underlines our differences from those who came before.   I particularly didn't like his seeming dismissal/blanket statement on hip hop. He really ain't down with the brothas, which is not surprising, given that he's a black intellectual, and there's nothing established black academics like more than a long-winded, whingeing harangue about the endemic evils of hip hop Kulture. Ugh. He doesn't even seem to possess much of a knowledge of hip hop artists or their work... Nada... There is much that I find execrable in said culture and in it's major 'artists' but still how can one overlook its myriad unifying and artistic elements... Even I manage not to fall prey to an all-too-easy reductionist formula, which seems to be the The main point here- the author views the degredation of the english Language through the lens of pop culture at large (as a bad thing, mind you), it begins in the evil counterculture 60's and... you know...   Digressive, ranting out-of-context mixed with counter-intuitive psuedo-linguistic gibberish. For example, the author holds up both Dylan and Tom waits as examples of artists who are reverred not for their songwriting abilities, but more for their authenticity, thir 'genuineness'. This is plain false. Laughably false. I've never met a fan of either artist who wasn't struck by their strange and completely idiosyncratic use of language. Moreover, the author seems to feel that pop culture music is driven by whites emulating blacks. True, up to a point. I love this stance, and from Chuck Berry to James Brown to Miles Davis to Funkadelic to Fishbone to Bad Brains, to the innumerable black influences on The Clash, I will never tire of pointing out that, basically, it's all black music. One would think that, at least on some level, this is a good thing... But no, it leads back to the counter-kulture (with a k) ideals that have subverted language...????   HUH?  The saddest thing is that, as a reactionary elitist, I'm inclined to agree with many of the author's basic points. But both his presentation and his defense of his points were so hare-brained and wrong, I just felt sullied. With friends like these...  
 After a week of using this I find the motor noise that others talk about is nothing.  Mine is a refurbished model from tigerdirect, so maybe the motor was already fixed :-)  My mother in law has a camcorder that sounds like a blender.  The ZR 500 is OK in low light, but you CAN adjust the exposure manually to correct if it isn't to your liking. You can also adjust the focus too!  My friend who is a mini DV guru said that in this end of the consumer spectrum this camera is on par.    I've made two practice DVD's (with firewire, no problem at all) with this camera and like what I see.    For those of you that have bad motornoise: try your video software to edit the noise out.  Power Director has that feature.  I am happy with this product, but I would rather have a higher end model now that I have a bit more in my budget for a camcorder. A great camcorder for beginners!

column1: I was very disappointed by the book.I wanted an explanation for Israels continuing occupation of Palestinian lands but got only apologistic rhetoric from this obvious pro zionist.Much of his writing I thought quite racist and certainly biased
When purchasing audiobooks
column2: I normally follow a simple but very effective rule: never
column3: never
column4: never buy an audiobook read by the author. Even if the author is a talented writer
column5: he/she is invariably a terrible narrator. Always look for audiobooks performed by experienced readers
column6: as in Bryson's own "Notes From a Small Island" and "A Walk in the Woods"
column7: read by Ron Mclarty.  In Bryson's case I made a rare exception when I listened to "In a Sunburned Country" - the audio version had received reasonable reviews and his performance was indeed adequately entertaining. For this reason I assumed that "Neither Here Nor There" would be equally enjoyable. I was wrong. Bryson's deadpan monologue makes it sound as though he was bored out of his mind while reading this book. Passages that may have seemed amusing in the written version are herein delivered in a sleep-inducing monotone. The sardonically comedic talent he displayed in his reading of "In a Sunburned Country" is totally lacking. I would recommend this audiobook only as a cure for insomnia

column1: Jon Katz does have a problem but it isn't a midlife crisis.  This is a book about an unemployed New Jersey writer who deserts his family for a couple of months to "find himself" by embarking on an odyssey to a local Vermont vacation home only to find that he's bored and runs back to his family for entertainment and a cure for his own shallowness.  The "mountain" is a hill off a local Vermont highway.  The "spiritual transformation" is analogous to that of a couch potato who feels hungry during Monday night football and heads back to the fridge to discover  replenishment.  The man has no insight.  His thoughts and observations are as shallow as Howard Stern.  He attempts to lend some credibility and substance to his ramblings by comparing himself with Thomas Merton and dragging Merton anecdotes in to pad the book where Katz clearly has nothing substantive to offer.  Save a tree and avoid this book at all costs.  Better yet
column2: write your own and offer the rest of us something worthwhile to ponder rather than this drivel.  If you read this book you will understand why Katz was unemployed when he wrote it

The nineties were a pivotal era for the software industry. The masses began to embrace computers while the industry responded by making personal computers more and more useful and affordable to the average person. The proliferation of access to more powerful computers spurred the growth of the Internet toward a critical mass. These mutually supporting trends snowballed into a genuine cultural transformation.  In the marketplace
column2: the demands for PC hardware and software were growing at astonishing rates. Thousands of software startups were vying to stake out the largest territories on the new frontier. Powerful multinational corporations were competing ruthlessly to dominate enormous mass markets.  The general character of all this competition was that of a race. Competitors raced to create the most significant technological advantages for customers
column3: particularly those features most complicated and difficult to mimic. By consistently outpacing the competition
column4: one could secure a privileged position as front runner. One could retain this privilege only by continuing to improve products at least as quickly as any challenger. Enormous fortunes were won and lost in this race
column5: and it affected virtually everyone involved in the creation of software.   During this era
column6: most software managers were under tremendous pressure to optimize immediate construction speed. Teams heroically sprinted to the finish line
column7: the next product delivery date
column8: only to be told that the race was not really over
column9: that they must immediately start sprinting again. Only a few mature organizations realized that they were actually running a marathon.  Before the dust settled
column10: the average complexity of a marketable software application was to increase a hundredfold. Unfortunately
column11: a majority of software professionals were not equipped to deal with such complex systems. They failed to realize that beyond a certain degree of complexity formal architecture and design methods become indispensible. They navely elevated construction speed above all other considerations. Crippled by this self-defeating objective
column12: many teams were driven to the breaking point. The rate of project failure grew rapidly. Poor working conditions were widespread. Engineers were disillusioned and discouraged. The most capable managers resigned themselves to dutifully wasting resources in order to give the outward appearance of construction progress while design work went on behind the scenes
column13: almost secretly.  Enter Steve McConnell's "Rapid Development." It set out to address what many thought to be the most pressing software development problem of its day
column14: speed. There were already dozens of tools and methods on the market that promised to increase development speed. These were deemed "rapid application development (RAD)" tools and methods. But they had all failed to deliver. The software industry was still desperately searching for a silver bullet. It was the perfect time for a new book on the subject
column15: especially one granted legitimacy by Microsoft Press. (Because of Microsoft's superlative success during those difficult times
column16: popular opinion held that they were the ultimate authority on how to develop software. Despite a cynical attitude that prevailed among many engineers
column17: books backed by Microsoft were generally taken seriously.)  This book accomplished a lot of good in its day. It stimulated the reader's thinking along the right lines. It said
column18: in effect
column19: "If you want to work faster
column20: you will need more than motivational speeches
column21: `performance' awards
column22: gadgets
column23: and quick-fix schemes. You will need to devote real mental energy to the problem." That was a message that most managers desperately needed to hear
column24: and most developers applauded. If you were a typical developer
column25: this was a great book to recommend to your manager.   But now it is the year 2007. In the full light of day
column26: this book's charlatanism seems obvious. It is gushing with camaraderie with the poor
column27: overworked developer. While denouncing the silver bullet syndrome prevalent at that time
column28: it proffers its own magic pill. It says
column29: in effect
column30: "My friends
column31: this book contains the secret elixir of speed."   In essence
column32: "Rapid Development" asserts that
column33: although RAD tools and quick-fix techniques alone do not work
column34: simply choosing the appropriate "best practices" for your project will solve all your problems. Everything comes down to avoiding a few simple mistakes. Like the silver bullets it purports to replace
column35: it neglects to mention the intricacies of architecture and design to be mastered and the creative talent to be developed. Instead of endeavoring to teach the abstract principles relevant to software development efficiency
column36: it bombards the reader with inane diagrams and fictitious scenarios involving companies with cute names.  Not surprisingly
column37: from the outset
column38: McConnell tags development speed as the essential problem of the software industry. But
column39: even by his own definition
column40: so-called rapid development is a chimera. In reality
column41: the software market creates specific windows of opportunity with particular success requirements. There can be no absolute standard against which to quantify raw speed independent of other factors. The proper goal is not simply developing software quickly
column42: it is outpacing competitors in terms of customer satisfaction gained versus time
column43: and doing so consistently over the course of many releases. Time to market is only relevant to planning in specific cases. It cannot be abstracted and considered in a vacuum. What software teams need is not speed but long-term efficiency
column44: and control leading to consistent predictability. The scourge of the industry in the mid nineties was the nave belief that the race is won or lost by lines of code per day. By framing the problem in terms of construction speed
column45: this book only helped to perpetuate that error.  We cannot avoid the fact that software engineering is a highly complex and creative endeavor. It requires significant knowledge
column46: skill
column47: and talent. In the immature industry of the nineties
column48: many professionals were not properly equipped for their jobs. In particular
column49: a much deeper theoretical foundation for architecture and design was needed. To some extent this is still true today. Such knowledge and the skill of applying it must be painstakingly gained through in-depth study or formal training. It cannot be acquired as McConnell suggests
column50: by casually reading fictitious scenarios and contemplating "best practices" while waiting in airports.  On the whole
column51: "Rapid Development" comes across as a high-pressure sales pitch for the concept of "best practices." The fundamental premise behind this concept is that software is like fast food. If we create a streamlined process and train our teams to observe certain rules
column52: we can churn out software products like hamburgers off an assembly line. This is the antithesis of a proper conceptual approach. The common idea that unites "best practices" and fast food is that of economizing by employing uncreative and under-educated labor. Perhaps
column53: in a labor market with a dearth of qualified engineers
column54: such drastic measures are required. But we must not forget that they are interim measures. As long as the public wants great software
column55: we cannot really reduce the demand for good engineers by employing "best practices." Everyone will simply have to wait until the supply catches up with the demand. In the mean time
column56: perhaps we ought to avoid chasing away the best engineers we already have and discouraging newcomers.  Even today this book is not completely worthless. There are a few useful pieces of hard data
column57: though they merely support what seasoned software professionals already know by experience. And a talented young engineer with good analytical skills may be able to abstract some of the important principles of software engineering success from the "case histories" and their discussions.

Overall this movie was bizarre and kind of a waste of time.  Some scenes didn't make sense and it was very overdramatic

column1: I bought this book for a readings class this semester.  I don't have a suitable vocabulary to describe how poor it is.  The text is inconsistent and full of errors. I question the underlying assumptions of his theory but it is never fleshed out in sufficient detail to be understood and examined.  Some examples:  Page 8
column2: the author discusses history
column3: "there were no exceptions or counterexamples (to Newton's laws) until Einstein advanced the theory of relativity".  Really?  How about Maxwell's equations
column4: the Michelson-Morley experiments
column5: the theory of the ether
column6: Mercury's orbit around the Sun?  Page 18
column7: The author uses matrix algebra notation and operations on nonlinear equations. Superposition does not apply to nonlinear equations.  Example 1-13
column8: consists of a redesign problem where one constraint is "no increase in cost"
column9: and the solution to the example problem is to add a component to the existing design.  And that component is free?  Title of one section: "Reduction of uncertainty: Conversion of a design with time-dependent combinatorial complexity to a design with time-dependent periodic complexity".    It goes on.  I made it about 100 pages into it

column1: Rarely have I seen such speculative extra-Biblical theologizing in a purportedly Christian book.  Several things are commendable
column2: such as references to the death of Christ for sinners
column3: evangelical truths like God's sovereignty and man's accountable agency
column4: the Trinity
column5: Jesus' Deity
column6: reality of the afterlife and God as Creator. There is a definite evangelistic appeal to readers to consider the claims of Christ and the abundant evidence in Scripture (Primary Order) and nature (Secondary Order) of God's powerful existence. Also evident is the author's sincerity in embracing scientific interpretation of physics data.   He is Persuaded
column7: but alas not Persuasive in this arena.  String-theory seems to be the flesh and blood of this book's plot. Unfortunately
column8: it is a highly hypothetical
column9: still-in-protoresearch-phase area of physics bordering on metaphysics. It has but scanty observational
column10: scientific-method data and a few creative equations to bolster the rare physicists who consider it even to lie within the bounds of 'True Science'. Unfortunately
column11: the author seems to consider it well within the realm of plausibility
column12: possibility
column13: probability
column14: preponderance. His pronouncements throughout the book give the impression of fait accompli. For him
column15: String-theory is the sine qua non that is the long lost rapprochement and Unification Factor bridging the gap between physics-metaphysics and theology.  And here lies the main troubling aspect of the author's faith opinions: trying to enlist a speculative-at-best physics novelty to unravel knotty theological problems in Christian Doctrines without resorting to the Bible itself first and foremost. His extra-Biblical approach gets him deeper and deeper into hypothetical extra-dimensional realms of imagination.  For those interested in a more thorough rebuttal of the Beyond-the-Cosmos notions postulated here
column16: check the web for the article by William Lane Craig reviewing this book pointing out the manifest errors and mal-interpretations of Scripture.

column1: There are so many publishing errors in the first paperback edition (2004) of Leon Kass's book that it is almost unreadable.  It is obvious that no one even bothered to look at the book before sending it to retail.  Do a quick read of Chapter One and you will see what I mean.  Sentences are left entirely unfinished from one page to the next
column2: leaving the reader wondering how much other text has been omitted.  Although page 35 starting with the word "nogoly" is pretty classy
column3: my favorite example is the transition from page 37-38.  Here
column4: Dr. Kass is begins to frame an argument
column5: but the sentence is never completed.  Then
column6: the next paragraph begins
column7: "Crudely put
column8: the argument could be stated this way."  What way?  Of course the irony is all the more poignant because this series of publishing mistakes follows Dr. Kass's meta-observation about the technology used in producing this very book.  Good stuff.  I would not be nearly as concerned had this book not been a god-send for my present research project.  But $17 later
column9: I guess I have to track down a hardback copy in the hopes that I can actually read what Dr. Kass has written

column1: The Tomtom has great features.  But I returned mine.  First
column2: the maps are very dated.  This makes it iffy at best.  It has terrific potential
column3: if it worked.  You can use a PDA stylus on the map sitting at home outside on batteries to plan a trip.  It's amazing.  But I wanted to plan a 600 mile trip myself using it's internal maps and waypoints.  But I tried a local test first.  I used roads as waypoints
column4: main roads.  This way I can force the Tomtom to use MY routes.  I did not like it's choices
column5: since it is a dated map database.  I set up a local route
column6: and started to follow it.  It took me to the first road/waypoint no problem.  But it would not go past the first waypoint.  I would go down the road (first waypoint) then it would tell me to take a u turn!.  I did.  Then it said take another u turn.  It had me going in circles.  Perhaps it's not made to use roads as waypoints
column7: but all indications it gave were that it would.  The manual was no help.  Support was no help.  So it went back.  I have ordered a Garmin i2.  Hope this is ok.  I have taken the same trip from SE FL USA to SC USA with a Garmin C330.  The Garmin has maps that you cannot update
column8: but got me to my destination no problem.  I don't recommend this TomTom.  Do research.  Go to manufactures websites and look at unit manuals.  Hope this helps

column1: Joseph Nye keeps repeating himself: multilateralism by global American charm attack. That is simply a stupid assumption. And it is untrue of American history in foreign relations. Nye still owes some answers to European scholars of International Relations who criticized his idea. In fact that is no personal multilateral approach..
In his last book
column2: Andrew (Andy) Hargreaves takes us through the dark alley of modern education. At the end of the alley
column3: shines his promised land of Marxism. Hargreaves political views are cleverly disguised
column4: but still obvious. He never speaks of a Marxist society
column5: but instead uses jargons such as "beyond the knowledge society"
column6: "social mission" and "cosmopolitan identity".  The kowledge society and related terms
column7: such as knowledge worker and knowledge economy
column8: were created by Peter F. Drucker and appeared in his 1969 book "The Age of Discontinuity". In his 1999 book "Management Challenges for the 21st Century"
column9: Drucker has following to say:  "Knowledge workers are rapidly becoming the largest single group in workforce of every developed country. They may already comprise two-fifths of the U.S. workforce - and a still smaller but rapidly growing proportion of the workforce of all other developed countries. It is on their productivity
column10: above all
column11: that the future prosperity and indeed the future survival of the developed economies will increasingly depend." (page.141).  Drucker is absolutely right
column12: that the knowledge society aready exists
column13: but Hargreaves eyes are focused on the society beyond
column14: which in his opinion clearly belongs to the Marxist ideology. Following quotations make this abuntantly clear:  "Teaching beyond the knowledge society means developing a cosmopolitan identity that can build chains of caring for those who are out of sight but should never be out of mind." (page.48).  "Teaching exclusively beyond the knowledge society cultivates caring
column15: develops character and builds cosmopolitan identity." (page.52).  "We have seen that standardized educational reform has made it almost impossible for many teachers to teach either for the knowledge society or beyond it as part of a broader social mission." (page.162).  What is the social mission of the teaching profession ? Hargreaves emphasizes this aspect of teaching:  "Teachers and others must now dedicate themselves to bringing together these two missions of teaching for the knowledge society and beyond it - making it the pinnacle of their professional purpose." (page.52).  "The standardized reforms of Ontario education offer only disincentives and discouragement to those who see their work as being about teaching beyond the knowledge economy and about creating values for good. They are squeezing the social mission out of teaching." (page.96).  As previously noted
column16: one of the expressions that Hargreaves uses instead of Marxism is "cosmopolitan identity". In true Marxistic fashion
column17: he keeps on striking the hot iron:  "This is what teaching beyond the knowledge society must address: developing cosmopolitan identity and humanitarian responsibility at home as well as abroad." (page.35).  "Teachers and others
column18: therefore
column19: must think not only of how to teach for the knowledge society
column20: but also of how to teach beyond it
column21: so we address other compelling human values and educational purposes in addition to those that make a profit - purposes concerned with character
column22: community
column23: democracy and cosmopolitan identity." (page.43).  It is disturbing
column24: that Hargreaves goes so far out on the Marxist limb
column25: that his book is more of a political declaration
column26: than an analysis of education. I believe that John Locke (1632-1704)
column27: Auguste Comte (1798-1857) and John Dewey (1859-1952) would have agreed with me.

column6: the food  supply will actually become more abundant even as population increases

column9: even as the efficient agricultural methods he  counts on are depleting the fertility of croplands and accelerating erosion  of topsoil
column10: as drug-resistant pathogens proliferate
column11: and as ecosystem after  ecosystem goes to the wall (there is one paragraph on stresses to the  environment as a possible problem). How ivory a tower must such a writer  inhabit

column1: Professor Ellis is a very intelligent man
column2: but he plays fast and loose with the facts
column3: and sometimes he uses his gift for writing prose in ways that mislead the reader especially in
column4: American Sphinx.  Ellis has obviously covered all of the ground with regard to what is known about Jefferson--but he doesn't objectively present all of the factual scholarship existing about our 3rd President.   If you want to know more of the detail of what was all involved with Sally Hemings
column5: you MUST read Douglass Adair's essay "The Jefferson Scandals."  This essay is found in the book: Fame of the Founding Fathers: Essays by Douglass Adair.  Published by W.W. Norton.  Sally Hemings was the daughter of Jefferson's father-in-law; and Sally's lover was not T.J. but T.J.'s nephew (his sister's son).  That's why Jefferson never talked about the "scandal" because his close family relatives were involved; however
column6: not the way Prof. Ellis says.  The unfortunate fact is that Prof. Ellis mentions Douglass Adair in American Sphinx
column7: but he never mentions Adair's research (which Ellis cannot reasonably be ignorant of) on the alleged Sally Hemings-Thomas Jefferson liason.  It's obvious from American Sphinx that Ellis has read Adair's essays.  Prof. Ellis must know that the best evidence exonerates Thomas Jefferson
column8: but he never tells us about that. The well publicized DNA test does NOT prove TJ was the father of any of Hemings' children.  TJ never fathered any children with Hemings and Ellis knows it. Prof. Ellis is intellectually dishonest on this point
column9: and on many other points of Jefferson's life.  Too bad because he would otherwise have written a tour-de-force.  Instead it's a tour-de-FRAUD

column1: "All life/ has song..." Stan Rice announces at the start of "Singing Yet
column2: chaotic collection of poems from his prior three releases, plus several new poems. Rice (who sadly passed away at the end of 2002) displayed a flair for evocative imagery, but his poetry is so confusingly random that it's almost impossible to decipher.      The first parts of the book are a tangle of bizarre eroticism (comparing melons to a woman) and odd morbidity (It is death's/drizzle we write/checks on/when we die/we bounce"). But in the "Some Lamb" section
column3: Rice delved into some deeper
column4: more real turf: the death of his daughter from leukemia. "We stopped beside a hole where she/was put by men who could not see."      With an actual focus
column5: Rice's poetry shifts into aching confusion
column6: describing his daughter's illness
column7: death
column8: and burial
column9: all the emotions that came with it. Unfortunately
column10: Rice's poetry doesn't improve after that
column11: including in the stretch of new material at the end of the book -- while his style mellows out a little
column12: Rice's poems are still surreal and still nonsensical. "The iceplants/turn to the sun/their purple/sadist flowers..."     Dreamlike poetry and strange images are not a problem. But Rice's poetry goes beyond strange and into incomprehensible. "Golden silver copper silk/woe is water shocked by milk/heart attack
column13: assassin cancer/who would think these bones such dancers?" he announced at one point. Okay
column14: whatever. Maybe it's about death. Interpret that as you will. While his poetry can be intriguing and seductive
column15: most of the time it just seems like cool phrases tossed randomly together.      Certainly Rice can't be faulted for his lack of description. He could evoke astoundingly weird
column16: Dali-esque images. The problem is
column17: they seem strung together like beads. Rather than focusing on one and exploring it
column18: he seems just to have tossed them together randomly
column19: assuming that they will see profound despite their lack of connection. "Thunder no more
column20: sky/big sandwich gold & coral" -- it doesn't evoke anything by itself
column21: and it seems completely disconnected from what comes after it.      An overview of Stan Rice's poetry
column22: with a stretch of new material
column23: "Singing Yet" doesn't shed any more light on what went through his head. Nor does it make his random poetry any more appealing.

column1: Allan Bloom
column2: the late translator of Plato's Republic and professor of philosophy at the University of Chicago
column3: has assembled a partially cranky
column4: but never the less insightful critical examination of the American University system in the post-60's era. His assessment predictably reeks of the stuffy conservatism of his mentor Leo Strauss
column5: but that should not deter one from confronting his arguments. The American university
column6: in his perception
column7: is inundated with transitory cultural and political problems; the academy (in Plato's conception)
column8: must continually strive towards the good
column9: it must teach what is eternal and beautiful and drop the multi-culturalism and relativism of the postmodern era. Bloom is distraught about the preponderance of German philosophy in the academy
column10: a Nietzschean rejection of morality and a Heideggerian rejection of the impact of the individual. Bloom's knowledge of history and philosophy is fair
column11: and his arguments are not totally grounded in neo-conservatism (he rejects the legitimacy of the MBA)
column12: yet at the same time his book often comes across as an old man's rant. He does not value the creativity and individuality of the student intellect
column13: and he may ultimately just be afraid of the black panthers. On the contrary
column14: I suspect that his concerns may be more relevant today as the popularity of the liberal arts degree has lessened
column15: and superficial non-fields such as feminism and multi-culturalism appear to have grounded their place in the academy for good.

column1: I imported from Quicken for Mac to Quickbooks Pro for Mac and after 3 weeks of trying to make the result work
column2: I gave up. The interface is far less intuitive than in Quicken (for example
column3: entering vendor names by typing the first letters then scrolling through the choices with the arrow keys as in Q) does not work in QB
column4: forcing one to guess at the exact vendor name the first time; and the imported names and addresses do not go automatically to vendors if they have been paid
column5: and customers if they provide payments; rather they all go to an 'other names' list that
column6: with a thousand or two names in it
column7: cannot be simply dragged to the  correct list; rather each one has to be edited individually. When I started forming invoices and quotes for customers
column8: I found that QB would forget the customer's address
column9: sometimes including it and other times yielding a blank field. Also the field lengths in QB are often shorter than in Q
column10: resulting in incomplete import of memo fields. In addition
column11: export capabilities are negligible; one can only export transactions and other details in a proprietary format that can't be used elsewhere
column12: unlike Q which exports in a readable and massageable format. Overall it seems that QB has been written by a different company than Q
column13: and to a large extent the programs are not compatible even though the import from Q to QB appears at first viewing to work OK. It is better to start a new financial year with new software and enter all data in again by hand rather than try to make QB use Q data
column14: in my view. I have switched to MYOB AccountEdge at a rather higher cost
column15: and find that this clean start at the financial year beginning works OK for me. The MYOB product is a little clunkier than QB with more fields to fill in and numbered accounts all over the place
column16: and its Q import is a total joke (with repeated questions on where to allocate accounts for each transaction without an explanation screen) so that import of any more than 10 transactions becomes laughable) but its export abilities are wonderful and I think its inventory control is better than QB; also
column17: it has not yet lost invoice addresses the way QB did on me. One has to input addresses in fields before memorizing tranactions however otherwise the memorized transactions in MYOB don't update. I have found that MYOB is about as intuitive as Q when it comes to entry of payee fields etc; while QB has lost that data entry ease entirely. QB may have an advantage if your goal includes payroll however; MYOB seems to have a pretty sad service unless you are prepared to pay all of the taxes yourself.

column4: but for 99% of New Testament words and meanings this is not an issue.  Trenchard's book is actually MORE helpful
column5: in my opinion
column6: than this or any lexicon because he simply lists every possible meaning of each word.  One way to get to the essence of a word's meaning is to look at the cognates
column7: and Trenchard lists them all.  A Greek concordance will actually print all the NT uses of a word in Greek.  Bauer's lexicon is just not that helpful and is too wordy.

column12: such as one of the first encounters between March and Marmee (I'm not going to go into details so as not to spoil the scene)
column13: I believe that she made a radical departure from anything that Alcott would have written of her characters
column14: and that Brooks really did not stay true to the original.   The first half of the book is also really dry. This could just be my personal taste
column15: but the first half moved so slowly! The book started to pick up about half way through. Overall
column16: the story being told and the Civil War aspects weren't bad
column17: and could be a decent story in their own right if she'd just speed things along at the beginning.  However
column18: I think Brooks did the book a major disservice by linking it to Little Women. I bristled every time she mentioned an individual from the book
column19: because she was really changing their characters (other than Aunt March). The choices that Brooks' characters made were not in keeping with choices they may have made in Alcott's book.   In the afterward
column20: Brooks discussed her research and how she actually based the March family and particularly Mr. March more on the Alcott family itself than on the characters from Little Women
column21: even commenting how the March Family in Alcott's book isn't very interesting
column22: and how "Nobody in real life is such a goody-goody as that Marmee." If she felt that way
column23: then why use them as the basis for her book? Seen in that context
column24: her earlier *huge* liberties with Marmee's character seem to just be a way to "stick it" to Alcott: "ha ha
column25: look how much more realistic Marmee is now!

column1: ALL THE BEST SONGS ARE ON OTHER ALBUMS.  This is an audio recording from multi-media presentations.  Much of the material is geared around visuals and Anderson's stage personnae.  This is like listening to a television broadcast of a football game without the picture.  You get the general idea what is going on
column2: but you miss a lot.  It is not like listening to a football game over the radio
column3: where the broadcasters explain what you aren't seeing.  Without the visuals to go with this CD
column4: many of the stories and jokes come up flat.    This CD set is about 4 and a half hours long.  It was taken from several years of Anderson's live shows that eventually became the United States.  Each CD more or less covers a specific "tour".  Her back up band changes from CD to CD.  You can tell that as time goes on
column5: she gets more famous (and maybe has more money) she is able to add more to the shows (and her backup band gets bigger).  The sound quality is amazingly good.  It is sharp and crystal clear.  There is almost no audience noise
column6: which does help create a good atmosphere for her stories.  About 80% of the material is spoken word.  There is some music.  It is probably less than 45 minutes of the total 4 and a half hour production.  The recordings come from early in her career.  She later redid most of the best material and put in on other albums.    I would suggest getting her other CD's.  Or if you want to see her performance art work
column7: I would suggest searching out the Home Of the Brave VHS tape (I don't think it has been released on DVD).  Don't get the Home of the Brave CD

column1: I'll put my opinion first
column2: so there won't be any doubt in your mind.  I don't believe that you can write useful books about national character.  Is there really such a thing as "national character"? People are  just too different
column3: too unpredictable. How well can you predict the  behavior of the people closest to you ?  How well can you predict what  people in your own country will do ?  Would every Italian
column4: if they could  write well
column5: have written the same book as Mr. Barzini ?  I seriously doubt  it.  So what we have in THE ITALIANS is one man's views on the conglomerate  nature of 50 million Italians.  After reading it
column6: I felt even more strongly  that such books
column7: though possibly entertaining
column8: are a waste of time.  An  informative book about unicorns--but do they exist ?   Anthropologists have  been concerned
column9: for many years
column10: in getting the "inside view"--the  view of a culture as seen by the person within it.  While Barzini is  indisputable Italian
column11: he tries to visualize Italians as seen by foreign  visitors
column12: then explain to those of us not lucky enough to travel there
column13: why  they are as visitors see them
column14: or why they are not as foreigners may think.   This is not a successful gambit.  Cultures are based on many general  factors--like history
column15: socio-economic patterns
column16: religion
column17: family
column18: etc.---but the specific results are just that
column19: specific.  Barzini covers  many topics--the importance of spectacle and giving an illusion of  something rather than actually having that quality; the family vs. the  state; Italian modes of achieving success; the north-south split; Sicily  and the Mafia; and last
column20: the tragedy of Italy's long domination by  foreigners.  But nothing really connects.  There are only superficial
column21: scattered impressions
column22: nothing very concrete to grasp.  The reader is left  with a handful of stereotypes.  Barzini is at his best when describing the  lives and modus operandi of particular characters in Italian history.   These sections were well-written and interesting.  But his portrayal of  Italian "character" is fuzzy
column23: contradictory
column24: and ultimately
column25: unconvincing.  Finally
column26: if you are a lover of lists
column27: you will thrill to  this book
column28: because there is a list on nearly every single page.  Myself
column29: I  got pretty tired of those lists.  If you want to know something useful  about Italy
column30: read another book.  If you just want entertainment
column31: which  might support any stereotypes you have about Italians
column32: then this book could  be for you

column1: The author spent his entire life in journalism and not academia and it shows in the book.  The book is written at the 8th grade reading and intellectual level
column2: which accounts for its popularity.  The book is a collection of interesting tidbits about the ancient Greek world that the author collected in his hobby reading.  An analogy would be describing a religious belief system by the sequence of body postures used by the worshippers and ignoring their intellectual beliefs about the spiritual world.  There is a total lack of academic rigor.  The author tells you what to think instead of presenting the evidence and making you think for yourself.  What is worse is the absent material.  The author totally ignores the usually understood reason for the trial being revenge from a high level public official that Socrates frequently publicly ridiculed for being incompetent.  Another journalist aspect is the occasional political propaganda presented.  Watch out for irrelevant and false references to the current world and notice how they are presented as proof by blatant assertion

column3: at times

column6: finally

column1: I so badly wanted to enjoy this book. I'm an avid reader of SF&F and mythology
column2: and I have an endless fascination for the biological and mythological dimensions of the wolf. The author seems to have used a painfully literal interpretation of Joseph Campbell's The Hero With a Thousand Faces as a map to writing The Sight. I understand that most Young Adult fantasy is more or less a retelling of the Hero's Journey- after all
column3: archetypes are archetypes because they are so integral to our understanding of what it is to be human- but other than the fur and feathers covering the characters
column4: there isn't much to distinguish this work from all of those that have come before. I was most offended by the broadness of characterization. Young Adult does not translate to "stupid" or "unable to cope with complexity". I couldn't bring myself to care about or empathize with the characters at all.  The only thing worse than a novel with stick-figure characterization is a novel with stick-figure characterization and a moral axe to grind. Beliefs can be unifying and freeing- especially if they're ersatz NeoPagan- or divisive and controlling- especially if they're essentially Judeo-Christian. Next slide
column5: please. I appreciated the effort to create a unique culture and philosophy for the animals
column6: but the piecemeal construction and the sheer weight of pseudopsychology and new age aphorisms (is this what "wisdom" and "nobility" are supposed to sound like?) that were forced out of the animals' mouths mostly obliterated that for me

column1: This is the first time I have written a review.  In this particular case
column2: I felt it was my responsibility to forewarn potential readers of the disturbing contents of this book.  I've read several "self help" books on subjects ranging from introversion to optimistic thinking.  I found this book to be of little help and quite disturbing.  The book is filled with tests and self evaluations.  I do not believe it is necessary to know where one falls on the optimist/pessimist scale.  Often
column3: such tests can only further depress or make anxious an already vulnerable reader.  In Chapter 5
column4: the author uses an extremely horrific and disturbing story to illustrate a five step process to forgiveness.  I was further sickened by the author's list of "bodily pleasures" in Chapter 7.  Rather than feeling uplifted by this book
column5: I found myself feeling upset and outraged by the author's egotism
column6: ignorance
column7: perversion and insensitivity.  I caution anyone seeking advice on optimism

column1: This book by Murray is little more than pompous propaganda--albeit effective politics for the right-wing. His pseudo social scientific analyses fail to hold water when backed up by more than 100 real social-scientific studies published in numerous peer-reviewed journals. As a social scientist trained in sociology and economics
column2: I find this book offensive for its lack of objectivity
column3: sloppy research and unsubstantiated claims. Published and marketed by wealthy corporate donors whose objectives in the 1980's were to slash social and economic safety nets from the beginning
column4: Murray attempts to posit the work as rigorly objective
column5: academic research. Murray argues that government aid to the poor and working class left them only deeper in poverty and because of this
column6: the government ought to slash social spending for the good of the poor themselves and the rest of society. He ignores most of the real causes of poverty--the de-industrialization and de-unionization of much of the country along with massive federal cutbacks in housing
column7: income
column8: education and health assistance. Murray's book brings out the worst in society as he attempts to legitimate the lack of concern
column9: contempt and ignorance by priviledged citizens for the underpriveledged for political gain. This book truly deserves the dust bin.

column1: "Four Brothers" is yet another nail in the coffin of John Singleton's increasingly moribund moviemaking career.  The director - who burst upon the scene in 1991 with the vibrant and gritty "Boyz n the Hood" - has here mounted a film so burdened by implausibility and contrivance that it makes one wonder if the once-promising filmmaker will ever be able to get back on track again.  The story
column2: reeking of artificiality
column3: features Mark Wahlberg
column4: Tyrese Gibson
column5: Andre Benjamin and Garrett Hedlund as four troubled young men raised by the same foster mother.  When she is killed in a convenience store robbery
column6: the quartet launches into action
column7: seeking revenge against the perpetrators and becoming slowly convinced
column8: through their investigation in the neighborhood
column9: that the killing might not have been as random in nature as they had been initially led to believe.    The main weakness of this film is that it gives us virtually no reason to care about any of the characters.  By not showing us any scenes between the boys and their foster mother (except for one embarrassingly bad Thanksgiving dinner fantasy sequence that looks as if it were conceived by a first-year film student)
column10: we are forced to take their relationship totally on faith
column11: rendering the boys' thirst for revenge arbitrary at worst and academic at best.  The acting is uniformly flat
column12: with the characters little more than wafer-thin stereotypes
column13: and even the action scenes come across as surprisingly mundane and second-rate given the Singleton pedigree in this area.  The boys' running around from venue to venue in their Detroit neighborhood
column14: brandishing guns in full view of the populace and screaming for information about their mother's killer
column15: is ludicrous on the face of it and often reduces the film to the level of cheap low comedy burlesque.    With nary a single moment that rings believable or true
column16: "Four Brothers" is by-the-book filmmaking from a director who has proven that he has the wherewithal and talent to do so much more.
