This book's title is deceptive in that it suggests the author is going to examine the place of capitalism within formal Catholic social thought.  Sadly
column2: Dr. Woods foregoes the opportunity to examine the teachings of the social magisterium in favor of the standard bromides of the Austrian school.  Admitting at the outset that he's no intention of bringing up the pronouncements of the popes throughout the ages
column3: he instead nit picks about the sorts of things which have traditionally annoyed Austrians.  In most things
column4: Woods follows the lead of others
column5: contributing nothing himself in the way of original analysis.  He acknowledges his intellectual debt to Murray Rothbard in the introduction and
column6: later on
column7: draws on Rothbard's arguments concerning the 16th century scholastics
column8: some of whom wrote opinions in accord with Austrianism.  Unfortunately
column9: a few 16th century theologians does not the Church make and it's of course silly to even think that these men
column10: grounded as they were in the thought of the Angelic Doctor
column11: would in any way endorse Austrianism or the anarcho-capitalism of Murray Rothbard.  It would be the equivalent of saying that the popes are Austrian because they view private property as a pillar of society.  Nonsense!    According to Rothbard
column12: the error of Thomists and all classical natural-law theorists is that they viewed the state as a "major locus of virtuous action".  Elsewhere
column13: Rothbard defines the state as a monopolistic criminal enterprise.  Each of these views is well outside of the social magisterium; no where will you find a pope who rejects the validity of the state since it holds authority by the will of God.  St. Paul addresses the state in Romans 13
column14: not the all-powerful market
column15: and he does not fall on the side of Murray Rothbard.  The errors of the non-Catholic Rothbard on political issues are not enough to persuade Woods that he's suspect as an authority in economics.  He clings instead all the more tightly to the luminaries of Austrianism in a book ostensibly dedicated to Catholic social teaching on economic concerns.  For myself
column16: if I detect a serious error in the realm of political theory on the part of a writer
column17: I become very cautious in following his lead in economic matters.  Rothbard's political views are inseparable from his economic theory since the state exists solely to destroy the fruits of the market (cf. Man
column18: Economy & State).    The supreme irony is that Dr. Woods continues to defend the compatibility of Austrianism and Catholicism
column19: even against the condemnations of economic liberalism by popes like Pius XI
column20: to whom Woods appeals against the errors and confusion which have plagued the post-conciliar Church (cf. The Great Facade).  Here

column34: they speak

column42: Pius X

column44: legal
column45: and social modernism which We condemn
column46: no less decidedly than We condemn theological modernism."  Liberalism takes many forms.  In our own day
column47: most faithful Catholics assume it is primarily concerned with corruptions of human sexuality.  In fact
column48: the popes remind the faithful that liberalism appears under varied guises.  Dr. Woods evinces a poor philosophical foundation and he is easily taken in by all sorts of assumptions.  For example
column49: Ludwig von Mises
column50: critical inspiration to Rothbard and other Austrians
column51: claims in his work Human Action that praxeology "is the science of every kind of human action"
column52: rejecting any who would claim that his new science
column53: heretofore unknown to the doctors of the Church
column54: is not limited to those actions which lead to an improvement in a man's material well-being.  This claim of course is fundamentally at odds with St. Thomas and Catholicism at both a natural and theological level.  From a Thomistic perspective
column55: one wonders how anyone can have a perfect science of all human action that does not weigh good or bad actions.  This is true whether it's philosophical ethics or evangelical precepts.  The error of the past
column56: says Mises
column57: is that philosophers like Aristotle sought to explain human action by notions of good or bad
column58: just or unjust
column59: or even worse
column60: the "interference" of a Deity.  Instead
column61: human actions are not ordered by objective valuations
column62: but rather by the dictates of the market.  Virtue and vice are subjective notions which have no place in economics.  If a man is to "succeed" says Mises
column63: he must adjust his actions to economic law.  In his intro to Human Action
column64: he uses the example of a man who wants frequent sexual intercourse: if he's going to get it
column65: he's going to have to know economics.  Austrian economics
column67: he quips that "simple faith and economic rationalism cannot dwell together.  It is unthinkable that priests should govern entrepreneurs."  Meaning
column68: the Church has no business at all talking about the market.  The social magisterium is just so many opinions which may or may not be the correct way to establish a just and felicitous social order.  Rothbardians would go further and say that the Church can be ignored without moral peril whenever She posits the notion of a common good capable of being guarded by the state.    Woods argues that economics is not a species of ethics but is instead a pure science studied in the same way that physics is by physicists.  As St. Thomas says
column69: "external goods that are used purposively by men have a moral consideration."  It's precisely this ethical cast that Mises and other Austrians have sought to banish from economics.  The Church has claimed the right to decide the moral lights which should guide Christians in formulating a just economic order.  Woods does not meditate upon the question of whether there is a moral calculus in the laws which the state passes to regulate the exchange of goods or in relations between labor and capital.  How can he?  His mentor Rothbard had already taught that the state was criminal by nature so it follows that its decrees are only the threats of a crime syndicate having a monopoly on the use of violence.  Rothbard took Mises to his logical conclusion
column70: deciding that the market would necessarily find the most humane and efficient way to secure corporate goods with the state tagging along as an unwanted parasite.  Woods uses the same line of thought in his discussion on safety regulations.  The market will always do a better job of implementing safety in the workplace than any public regulation because it is rational.  If an objective moral evil exists in the social order
column71: it cannot be addressed by a ruler or rulers.  The market is infallible and will eventually solve any problem
column72: whether it takes days or decades.  Positive laws to remedy or palliate a condition are by definition always worse than doing nothing.  It's kind of like a doctor telling his patient to forego any treatment since death will eventually cure his illness.  Woods wants us to accept that economics is a value-free science
column73: a set of observations about the way things work in a world marred by scarcity.  At the same time
column74: he can't help dipping into moral considerations (e.g
column76: predicating moral or immoral of certain economic choices.  In addition
column77: he favorably quotes the Jesuit Mariana
column78: who calls any ruler "wicked" who sets a price by edict.  Mises and Rothbard of course also resorted to various moral arguments when discoursing on economics; their gift for moralistic psychologizing has been picked up by anarchists like Hans Hoppe at UNLV.  The question is then:  whose morals guide the discussion?  Are they Catholic?  Do they reflect the mind of the Church in her magisterium and her liturgy (cf. The Feast of Christ the King)?  The Divine Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom
column80: is very un-Rothbardian: the priest prays for the good of the civil authorities and the armed forces
column81: major no-no's in Murray Rothbard's School of Politico-Economic Anarchy.  Passages like 1 Peter 2:13 become problematic at best
column82: candidates for expunging at worst.  To be deep in Austrianism is to cease to be Catholic.  At the very least
column83: we can dispense with the pretension that economics is just a pure science about the way things are.  This claim can also be found in fields like sociology and psychology.  It's foolish to predicate pure value-neutrality of the political science
column84: but the Economic Man is a powerful myth
column85: so it happens that the whole science of economics gets a pass when it does this very thing.  The Austrian School is a marginal school at best (no pun intended)
column86: with Noble Laureates and scholars coming from other schools like Chicago.  The variety of theories would suggest that economics is a science in an equivocal sense only.    Woods has repeatedly shown that he's out of his depth in tackling the question of the Church and the market.  For those who accept Woods' thesis
column87: think more carefully about it after reading Rothbard and Mises.  Both authors have good insights and much of what they write is reasonable when they discuss the minutiae
column88: but this book is nothing more than an Austrian primer.  Woods limits much of his effort to sniping at individuals like Belloc.  Heinrich Pesch gets two whole pages even though he's hugely influential in 20th century Catholic social thought. One senses that Woods is really only interested in regurgitating standard Austrian doctrine.  We don't need this book for that purpose since many others have already been written.  A concise but potent antidote to Austrian ideology is the recently released Compendium of the Social Doctrine of the Church.  Unlike this book
column89: it actually delves into the heart of the Church's teaching on economic

column15: Billy Madison is about the title character (Sandler)
column16: heir to his father's multi-million dollar corporation

column18: in general

column24: Madison starts out unable to spell the word "rock" (his version: "rok"); do we really believe he could turn that around so quickly? I found Sandler's character inconsistent. One second he's a spastic moron

column27: and there's no real reason to believe they're the same person. I found the humor lame--jokes revolve around ugly homosexuals finding Billy attractive and little kids pissing on themselves.  None of this will matter to the Sandler fan
column28: but those on the fence might take note.  Some positives include two of the supporting cast--Norm McDonald (who needs to work more) and Chris Farley's brief appearance (who is missed). Also
column29: the teacher/love-interest *is* really hot.  Sandler Fans: 4 Stars.  Everyone Else: 2 Stars

column1: I can't for the life of me understand why Rosetta Stone has garnered such good reviews (although I see a few negative ones here
column2: so I feel validated) and seems to have such an outstanding reputation. I find it practically worthless
column3: and it's expensive to boot. I'm sure that my experience with the German program would apply to Rosetta Stone's other languages as well
column4: as they all taught via the same method.   I've been learning German for about 6 months and besides Rosetta Stone I have used Pimsleur
column5: Rocket Languages
column6: and have taken private instruction. Obviously
column7: private instruction is best. But this review is about software
column8: and Pimsleur is best. But Rosetta Stone has more bells & whistles
column9: which is perhaps why people think it is so good. But it isn't. For example
column10: nowhere in Rosetta Stone do you actually learn how to say useful things. Nowhere do you learn how to say "Hello
column11: How are you
column12: "What's your name
column13: or even Where's the bathroom." Instead
column14: you will learn how to recognize such useful phrases as "The woman and the boy have a ball on their heads" or "The man is under the donkey" or "These two fish are from the same species" or "The blue triangle is bigger than the red square." Ridiculous!! And note I said "learn how to recognize a phrase." This is the biggest weakness and disappointment with Rosetta Stone. It really doesn't get you to talk at ALL. You are not required to utter a word. You see four pictures
column15: and the speaker will say (in German) "The boy is drinking milk." Now
column16: if you have already heard the word for "boy" (Junge) and three of the pictures have no boys
column17: you simply click on the picture with the boy and presto
column18: you're correct! This multiple choice way of learning is not effective for learning a language! (There is a "practice speaking" mode
column19: equally useless
column20: which I mention below)   With Pimsleur
column21: which is an audio only program
column22: you hear conversations that will impart essential words and phrases. And they are repeated (and asks you to repeat) in such a fashion that it sticks. For example
column23: it was weeks ago that it introduced "How much do I owe you?" yet I still remember it. (Wie viel shulde ich Ihnen?--No
column24: I didn't cheat and look it up!) Pimsleur is brilliant in the way it gradually builds your knowledge and abilities. Of course
column25: it isn't perfect as it doesn't explain the grammar. But neither does Rosetta Stone
column26: and Rosetta Stone is worse because with Pimsleur there is also an English speaker who explains some things
column27: while with Rosetta Stone you are left to twist in the wind. That's why software language learning programs should be seen as supplements--supplements to classroom or private instruction.   What are the bells & whistles on Rosetta Stone? You get to do a lesson in a variety of ways--seeing pictures with audio (the speaker)
column28: or pictures with audio and text
column29: or audio only
column30: for example. There is also a feature where the speaker on the program says a phrase
column31: and you repeat it into a microphone and can compare your voice signature to the speaker's. But I found that this didn't work well at all and wasn't worth the trouble. And again
column32: the phrases weren't useful

column1: To anyone who knows the real history of the European part of WWII
column2: this is an idiotic premise for a book.  In America--and nowhere else in the world--they teach that America
column3: with help from the Soviets
column4: defeated Nazi Germany.  This is propaganda  and makes us a laughingstock for our naivete.  In truth
column5: while we were fighting the Japanese
column6: and crushing their hopes beyond repair in the Battle of Midway
column7: making it only a matter of how long it would take
column8: not who would win
column9: the Russians did the same thing to the Nazis in the Battle of Stalingrad and surrounding areas.  One huge difference is that while the U.S. lost between 292
column11: 000 dead in the entire war
column12: the Russians lost beween 20 and 30 MILLION dead.  (Ponder that for awhile.  I find it incomprehensible.)  Unimaginable numbers of men
column13: women and children died in and around Stalingrad
column14: and the old beast Stalin--in perhaps the only completely truthful statement of his life--said
column15: "They are not fighting for me and they are not fighting for Communism.  They are fighting for Mother Russia."  He was right.  When the 12-to-18 month battle was over
column16: the Russians' fatalities far outnumbered those of the Nazis.  But the Russian people's courage--aided enormously by the climate that had doomed Napoleon
column17: and supplies and food from the U.S.--destroyed a majority of Hitler's army.  The Nazis were in full retreat back through Eastern Europe
column18: forcibly conscripting 15-year-old Poles to fight in what remained of their great army.  All of this was well BEFORE D-Day.  If you read American newspapers from November of 1943
column19: you can read about conferences between FDR
column20: Churchill (my pick for the greatest person of the century) and Stalin--discussing what they would do when the war ended.  In other words
column21: they knew victory was a done deal--over half a year before D-Day.  So
column22: this book is another effort to say the U.S. military played a major effort in defeating Nazi Germany.  That is a lie which every country in the rest of the world scorns us for believing.  In World War II
column23: we did the following things:  (1)  Defeated a Japanese government & military not much better than Hitler's.  While we had help (as did the Russians in their immense sacrifice)
column24: we were clearly the main force in the Pacific
column25: just as were the Russians in Europe;  (2)  Kept Stalin from metastasizing his way through the rest of Europe;  (3)  Hastened the war's end
column26: a big deal.  Nobody will ever know how much longer Hitler needed to get the doomsday bomb
column27: but we all know what he would have done
column28: as those Russian tanks smashed their way through those final blocks toward his bunker
column29: if he'd had the doomsday button at his command; and   (4)  Lost the lives of 292
column31: 000 courageous souls
column32: not to mention the hundreds of thousands of others who came home with what is now called Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (a major mental disorder) and/or serious physical injuries.  I am not disparaging any of those sacrifices
column33: nor trivializing Items (1) through (3)
column34: nor (of course) our defeating Japan.  But this country REALLY has to get past the notion we beat the Nazis or co-beat them.   We didn't
column35: any more than the Soviets co-beat Japan.  A year ago
column36: I heard an idiot on ESPN tout some movie about D-Day
column37: a movie which was to air that night on their parent network
column38: ABC.  He referred to D-Day as
column39: "The most important battle of World War Two."  There are a lot of places in Europe where one would not want to be heard making that statement
column40: and only people "educated" about history in American schools could in good faith state such nonsense.  This book
column41: sadly
column42: will only carry on this tradition of ignorance through propaganda.  The conspiracy to kill Hitler had been in its formative stages well before D-Day
column43: for the reason its major participants had already known Germany was hopelessly beaten.    Here is what all reasonable people can agree upon:  (A)  It is a great tragedy the bomb failed to do its job
column44: for it would have saved many millions of lives; and  (B)  It is too bad Rommel
column45: a man deeply respected by many American military leaders
column46: went down with the ship
column47: because I don't believe he would have failed again.  Moreover
column48: he obviously knew Stalingrad had destroyed the great Nazi machine
column49: and that the combined wraths of the Russians/Soviets over Stalingrad
column50: and the British over The Blitz in 1940-1941
column51: would take a horrible toll on the Germans at the hands of their victors.  And he was sure right.    Americans nowadays argue over the morality of Truman's two atom bombs
column52: with the vast majority of those who were not alive then condemning him for ordering the bombings.    I agree they are a fascinating subject for debate.  But I can tell you this:  I was born in 1953 and have asked well over 1
column53: 000 people in my life who were at least 21 on the date of Pearl Harbor how they felt about the dropping of those two bombs.  And I have NEVER found such a person who disagreed with the dropping of those atom bombs AT THE TIME
column54: though many disagree with it now or disagreed with it later.  Not a single one disagreed with it in 1945.    But the firebombing of Dresden?  Not only does everyone I know now who knows about it condemn it as a clearly indefensible thing (which killed more people outright than either of those atom bombs)
column55: but most people I have known who were adults during World War II condemned it
column56: too--not only to me
column57: but when it happened way back then
column58: finding no justification for it at whatsoever.  I apologize for using a monolithic subject with which to grade this book.  But it IS another book which perpetuates the lie that our military defeated or co-defeated the Nazis.  And our country's perpetuation of that myth/propaganda has done our country and its civilians a great disservice in the court of Western Culture's opinion.    I care a lot about that court's opinion of me and my country.  I don't care at all what Bin Laden and other fundamentalist Islamics think about me or my culture
column59: any more than I care what Falwell and Robertson think about me.  But I am tired of having the rest of the Western World view Americans as naive idiots.    A book which perpetuates the notion our military defeated the Nazis will only help ensure that we continue to be seen--not only by Russians
column60: but by all Europeans--as at least naive

column1: Let me cite just one example from The Truth Behind Left Behind that makes it a very weak defense of the Left Behind theology. There are many more
column2: but there are space limitations. In Tim LaHaye's Introduction to TBLB
column3: we read: "Jerry [Jenkins] and I have unashamedly taken the position that all prophecy should be interpreted literally whenever possible. We have been guided throughout by the golden rule of interpretation: When the plain sense of Scripture makes common sense
column4: seek no other sense. Take every word at its primary
column5: literal meaning unless the facts of the immediate context clearly indicate otherwise" (7). So shouldn't the reader interpret the weapons of Ezekiel 38-39--bows
column6: arrows
column7: shields
column8: war clubs
column9: spears
column10: horses
column11: and chariots--literally? Not according to our authors. Here's their interpretation from their chapter "The Coming Russian/Islamic Invasion": "Inspired by the Holy Spirit
column12: Ezekiel spoke in language that the people of his day could understand. If he had spoken of MIG-29s
column13: laser-fired missiles
column14: tanks
column15: and assault rifles
column16: this text would have been nonsensical to everyone until the twentieth century" (47). Of course
column17: this is question begging in the extreme. Why would the people in Ezekiel's day need to understand a prophecy if it wasn't meant for them? Why confuse them and us? How do Hitchcock
column18: Ice
column19: and LaHaye KNOW that this is what the Holy Spirit meant? Once the trio makes these ancient weapons of no consequence
column20: they are free to create their own prophetic scenario that can't be tested because it all takes place after Christians are no longer here! Convenient. Consider their words: "The focus clearly is NOT the specific weapons that will be used by these invaders" (47). What happened to "literal interpretation"? The weapons may not be the passage's "focus
column21: but they can't be dismissed as inconsequential to the narrative. The weapons are part of the story from beginning to end, and if taken literally would negate the future scenario outlined by the authors. They claim that Ezek. 38-39 has to be a DISTANT future battle because it takes place in the latter years" (38:8) and the "last days" (38:16). Most biblical scholars
column22: even some dispensationalists
column23: would say that these two time expressions most often mean nothing more than "in the future" or "in the days to come." The same Hebrew phrase is translated as "the days to come" in Num. 24:14
column24: which probably refers to David's victory over Moab. The prophecy of Deut. 31:29
column25: where the same expression is used
column26: came to pass in the period of the Judges (cf. 2:20-21). Here's how one Bible expositor explains it: "this expression does not refer to 'the latter days' (KJV
column27: RSV) in the eschatological sense. . .
column28: but rather to that portion of the future that falls within the scope of the speaker's perspective (cf. Gen. 49:1)." Then one has to wonder why the authors avoid interacting with Edwin M. Yamauchi's Foes of the Northern Frontier which refutes their historical
column29: geographical
column30: and lexographic arguments line by line
column31: and it was written in 1982! Yamauchi is a noted expert on this subject. The Russian invasion premise is only one of the book's many problems. If readers are interested in this topic
column32: I suggest that they pick up a copy of End Times Fiction: A Biblical Consideration of the Left Behind Theology written by me. Since Hitchcock and Ice refer to it several times
column33: it would be helpful to read what they do not deal with

column1: The film starts out with a brilliant
column2: and creepy premise -- what if there was a chemical that could be added to ordinary water
column3: colorless
column4: tasteless and odorless
column5: that
column6: when drunk
column7: didn't just kill its drinker but turned that person's body into a deadly explosive?  As the movie initially unfolds
column8: this premise is handled well and is remarkably chilling.  Pierce Brosnan plays the munitions expert who is in charge of determining the cause of several inexplicable explosions that have been taking out prominent senators.  His investigations put him in uncomfortably close proximity with one of the senators who may be the next target -- the man his ex-wife left him for following the death of their daughter.  As his investigation leads him to the bizarre method being used to kill off these lawmakers
column9: he finds that his attempts to protect them are being misinterpreted and miscast
column10: damaging his reputation... until he manages to prevent what would have been a deadly attack during a public rally.  Unfortunately
column11: it's right after this attack that the film unravels into a mess.  Up until this point it was a tight
column12: chilling mystery; the attacks unfolded with spooky "it could happen anywhere" finesse
column13: the chemistry used in the film to explain the explosive compound was handled remarkably well
column14: and the haunted past driving the protagonist (his daughter's accidental drowning and the way his life and marriage fell apart in the aftermath) was a nice subplot that helped but wasn't overbearing.  But at this point the film abruptly changes course and becomes a cliche'd 80s actioner.  His wife
column15: witnessing his act of heroism
column16: has the epiphany that she's with the wrong guy and comes back to him for a heapin' helping of "hot" 80s-style music-video simulated-sex.  Now the senator is the one on the outs
column17: and gee
column18: turns out he's dirty and probably deserves to get blown up
column19: but our hero is still sworn to protect him.  The man out to get him
column20: who up until now has been using remarkable finesse (and who wouldn't be creeped out by the concept that any glass of water could be their last?) suddenly switches over to much cruder tactics.  You could swap in virtually any action movie with a rugged loner hero
column21: unscrupulous ass who has to be protected
column22: glowering villain
column23: and useless woman screaming encouragement on the sidelines
column24: at this point
column25: to the same effect.  Our hero
column26: of course
column27: saves the day
column28: solves the crime
column29: and wins the girl.  Live Wire had the potential to be brilliant
column30: and would have been
column31: but the final act ruins the entire puzzle-box effect of the film.  It's a shame
column32: because it could have been a great thriller.  But it's not.  My recommendation: rent
column33: don't buy.  Watch up until the end of the rally sequence
column34: when the ex-wife gets that speculative
column35: "we're going to have SO much sex!" gleam in her eye
column36: and then hit the stop button
column37: and imagine the ending yourself.  You'll get a much better film out of it that way

I have been reading a series of autobiographical accounts of modern day warriors and had high hopes for this title.  As others have pointed out
column2: Coughlin's ego can be suffocating at times.  This could be forgiven if it were the books only flaw.  Alas it is not.  The writing is amateurish at best and the author's overuse of adjective and hyperbole is very distracting.  The language is disjointed and unnatural as if it were written with the heavy use of a thesaurus.  Again this could be forgiven as we're reading this book for a soldier's account
column3: not that of an English grad student.  This book offers a stark contrast in comparison with Nathaniel Fick's "One Bullet Away."  Whereas Fick seems to be an intelligent
column4: thoughtful and humble warrior whose primary concern is the welfare of his men
column5: Coughlin conveys himself as a shallow intellect with more concern for personal glory and satisfaction than anything else.  He is a team player when he hand picks the team and considers them worthy of his own company.  You cannot know a person from reading their writing but Coughlin's character development is very superficial.  His attempts to convey a "human side" are unbelievable and seem grossly contrived.  This is a great contrast to the character development in "One Bullet."  There is no connection between author and reader in "Shooter."  Coughlin does not develop the role players either.  In "One Bullet" you really feel the brotherhood developed among the officer
column6: his NCOs and the enlisted men.  Additionally
column7: Coughlin's demeaning descriptions of his support staff (non-trigger pullers) is tedious and only reinforces doubts about his team ethic.  To make matters worse the action isn't as well developed as in other titles.  The author's self-congratulatory tone and emphasis on personal exploits
column8: with plenty of after-action chest thumping
column9: obscures the view of battle.  He spends little time on the finer elements of sniper tradecraft
column10: training and shooting.  This can be found elsewhere.  Overall this book was a great disappointment.  If only a fraction of Coughlin's self-acclaimed exploits are true
column11: then he is a remarkable sniper.  He should let his accomplishments speak for themselves and not try to beat us over the head with them

column5: because up until that point
column6: the writing was quite good.

column1: The Contortionist's Handbook
column2: Craig Clevenger's first novel
column3: is a weird
column4: complicated
column5: seemingly pointless exercise in futility.  The novel follows John Dolan
column6: who is known by many other names throughout the book
column7: because that is what he does
column8: he changes his identity
column9: and others
column10: with great expertise and perfection.  We are introduced to John when he wakes up from a headache that he refers to as a "godsplitter" in a hospital
column11: and he is forced to undergo a psychiatric evaluation to determine if he is suicidal or depressed.  From that point
column12: the novel divides its time between the interview between John and the Evaluator and giving us John's life story
column13: which is remarkably uninteresting for such a weird tale.  The thing that gets me about this book is that it seemingly has no point.  I guess one could say its point to be "anti-psychiatry
column14: but forgive me for asking that the author also include somewhat of a plot to at least make the story interesting.  The only interesting and entertaining part of the novel is the interaction between John and the Evaluator.  But, for some reason, Clevenger decides that John's life story is more important, even though we are only given a brief, fleeting glimpse into a life that seems to be much more complicated than the author wanted to put into the novel.  Don't get me wrong, I am not complaining about the novel's length, because I don't think I would have finished it if it was longer than it already is.    I also read Clevenger's second novel, Dermaphoria, a while ago, and while I didn't really enjoy it, the novel at least had some semblance of a story that made it worth reading.  As this novel grew closer and closer to ending, I slowly realized that there was no way that any meaning was going to be given to the convoluted story within the last 20 pages.  Clevenger tries to inject some suspense into the story near the end, but he ends up just using underdeveloped characters to do things that we have no idea what their motivation is for doing.  I think that Clevenger could be a good writer, but, dear Lord, he needs to try writing a normal" novel
column15: until I read about one of his novels
column16: and it isn't about a drugged out freak or a mentally unstable counterfeiter
column17: I think that I am pretty much done giving his novels the benefit of the doubt

column1: I purchased the standard edition of X3 primarily for 3 reasons: 1) It claims to have the ability to convert pdf files into WP format
column2: 2) It claims to be able to organize your e-mail files through the use of WP Mail well beyond the capabilities of Outlook Express
column3: and 3) It claims enhanced use of WP for word processing.  What I found was a product that met only one out of three of its claims.  In baseball
column4: batting .333 will put you into the Hall of Fame.  In business
column5: fulfilling one of three claims will put you into bankruptcy!  While the pdf converter is a rather good tool
column6: WP3 Mail is unstable (and this is from their tech support department).  It destabilizes your use of e-mail to the point of making it virtually unusable in terms of reliability.  I imported older e-mail from outlook express when I installed the WP X3 software
column7: only to later find out that the system crashed regularly.  I could not get at my older imported e-mail
column8: and could not find a practical way to reverse the importing back into outlook express.  What really irked me was that their tech support was worthless in rectifying the situation.  They merely responded by saying they were aware of the problem and "may" release a patch to help sometime in the future.  Ahhhhh!  As to the alleged improved "word processing power"
column9: I have experienced more bugs then appear in an Animal Planet Channel special on insects in the Amazon Jungle.  Unwanted page formating changes occur when I click my mouse on the page I had just finish reformatting. Undesired line spacing would appear on pages.  The list goes on
column10: but who has the time to be more detailed.   Do yourself a favor and avoid the product.  If you need to upgrade
column11: check out the latest version of MS Word
column12: you will be far more satisfied I'm sure

column7: Wal-Mart

The plot described on the dust jacket of this novel doesn't really get started until maybe the last 80 pages or so.  The whole revenge plot feels tacked on and phony.  The ending is anti-climactic

column1: SPOKEN HERE: Travels Among Endangered Languages is a poigant story of journeys on the theme of language diversity undertaken by Mark Abley. His survey includes the loss of indigenous languages in Australia and North America and the dwindling minority languages of Europe.  The loss
column2: becoming ever faster
column3: of the world's minority languages is a true tragedy
column4: and Abley is to be commended for his effort. There are many fine points about his work. Unlike the average academic discussion of language diversity
column5: he shows the reader some of the actual people whose lives are being affected by the loss of their ancestral languages. He shows that language death isn't limited merely to small disadvantaged tribes in the third world
column6: but happens with us here in the West where Occitan
column7: Breton
column8: Welsh
column9: etc. are facing challenges. I was especially happy that he dispels the myth--propagated by the artificial language's movement--that Esperanto exists to promote language diversity by quoting a statement by the iniciator himself
column10: L.L. Zamenhof
column11: that language diversity is bad and Esperanto was meant to destroy it.   However
column12: so very much of SPOKEN HERE is objectionable. Abley is not a trained linguist
column13: and he makes mistake after mistake that even the greenest student of linguistics would capture. For example
column14: he dredges up the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis
column15: the now quaint notion that one's language shapes one's worldview. He makes blanket statements about how all the languages in the world are tending towards simplicity; it may be historically true for the Indo-European languages
column16: but many other world languages
column17: for example Mandarin Chinese
column18: are developing more complex morphology. He also seems to think that some languages can be more "ancient" than others
column19: for he writes that some languages were spoken in Australia when Sumer and Babylon were ascendent. Well
column20: guess what
column21: our language was spoken then too
column22: but it was called Proto-Germanic and English is a natural continuation of it. Languages don't appear ex nihilo
column23: so none can be more ancient than others.  Finally
column24: while Abley might not present the old urban myth of Eskimo words for snow
column25: but he gets close enough with his enthusiasm about other languages of people in the developing world. Now
column26: no one is expected to know everything
column27: and Abley could be forgiven for lacking formal training
column28: but he discounts real linguists as just eggheads who use too many "big words" and apparently he had no trained person proofread the work before publication. In some places he insolently puts his own opinions above those of respected scholars
column29: as in a passage where he writes "Chomsky may have made an important contribution
column30: but I think...".  As a result of this plethora of urban myths
column31: I cannot really recommend the book. If you are unsettled by the loss of the world's language diversity--and you should be--read LANGUAGE DEATH by David Crystal
column32: a trained linguist who still can related to the average reader with a gentle tone and not too much specialized terminology

column1: This book has major shortcomings; Stein's obsession with character over plot
column2: for one (Martin Amis said
column3: "I used to sneer at plot until I wrote a novel that had one
column4: titled NIGHT TRAIN. It was HARD and I used stay awake at night hoping I wasn't leaving any holes.")
column5: another being his obsession with "show don't tell" (Gabriel Garcia Marquez's novel LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA is probably the greatest novel of the 1980's and it's almost entirely "tell" and very little "show.") And the passages Stein includes from his own novels as examples of good writing were actually examples of terrible writing! (A taxi "disengorging" its passengers is categorically bad writing.) And Stein admits he rejected Frederick Forythe's THE DAY OF THE JACKAL. I wouldn't read a book by Dick Rowe about how to make it in the music business (Rowe famously rejected the Beatles from Decca Records). Stein excuses himself that he was going by only an outline
column6: but then Rowe was going by just a demo tape. Better writing books are out there

column1: The book is divided into two parts the first identifies the causes and nature of 'toxic shame' and the other how to heal from it.  I found the first part quite convoluted and lacking clarity he repeats things alot and seems to have invented a new vocabulary which is not always well defined.   The book uses alot of material from other authors such as Alice Miller et al. which represent the best parts of this book. There is an originality from them which Bradshaw lacks
column2: his input felt quite biased and perhaps that is why he rambles so much.  I have begun the second part but have found it lacking
column3: it uses the 12 step program as the ideal model for healing and somehow just throws together disparate research on healing.   If this book represents his others I think it sad that he has made a career out of simply putting forward other people's work with little valuable contribution from himself.  I found his tone somewhat preacher like and I feel he hides behind ambiguity in his language and writing style to disguise the lack of substance.  THe book does have value but only becuase of the references to other people's work.

column1: This may be the first time you hear me say this
column2: but Go Fish was too artistic and dated for my enjoyment.  I think that if I had seen this film when it was first released back in 1994 I would have been impressed.  This was a very avant-garde film that tried very hard to discuss an issue that was very "hush-hush" back in the early 90s.  Lesbians were very closeted back then and were not a major part of the culture norm as they are today (well
column3: as much as we recognize them today).  This makes for a very provocative film
column4: but it also makes for a very dated film.  This was my biggest issue with this film was that it nearly felt like a comedy instead of this symbolic struggle to pursue happiness like any heterosexual relationship.  I realize that director Rose Troche was trying to show us that a lesbian relationship is no different than a male and female relationship and even lesbians talk like men talk about women
column5: but somehow it just felt very dated and clich for me.  It didn't open more doors in my mind to the lifestyle of lesbians
column6: but instead gave me this dated image of this butch lesbian that is rebelling against something instead of embracing the true lifestyle.  The black and white photography
column7: while symbolically trying to show the black and white of the situation and relationship
column8: just felt like an art film.  This was an art film
column9: so what am I griping about?  I guess I just didn't want to see an art film with this topic.  I wanted to see something along the lines of Kids or even a documentary
column10: not something where the uneducated will laugh at and ridicule even harder.  I wanted a film that was going to punch me in the face
column11: not build upon dated/old clichs that instead poked my mind randomly and not very hard.  It was unimpressive.  It wasn't bold filmmaking
column12: but instead just this random
column13: average production about a lesbian love story.  Was it to be educational?  I think there were elements that could have been explored greater and into detail to cross that education/lifestyle acceptance line.  The scene dealing with bisexuality is the first that comes to mind.  This probably sounded great on paper
column14: but when it was actually filmed out
column15: it seemed high schoolish and bland.  The inner voices were not struggling with the character
column16: but instead causing confusion and chaos that will never be resolved.  Another scene that could have played out just a bit better was the dinner scene where a group of lesbians have gathered for a party.  There could have been more discussed between the lesbians like lifestyle
column17: issues
column18: and current problems (that would help with the dated feel) instead of just sex
column19: sex
column20: and more sex.  That was a huge downfall for me was the constant reminder that all these women wanted was to have sex.  There were times when I was watching this film where I felt a bit of sweetness in my mouth because I thought there was some candy-coating happening.  This does not need to happen in a film that is supposed to bring the lesbian lifestyle closer into the spotlight.  I never felt that these women in this film were given the best light to show their stuff anyway.  From the beginning of the first scene until the last (and all those snippets in-between) all they could talk about was sex.  They wanted to have sex more often than I honestly think about in a day.  It really made the rest of the non-existent themes seem blurry and unimportant.  There was just a consistent lack of togetherness for this film that ultimately hurt it in the long run.  This wasn't a film about women's rights
column21: but instead a dire attempt to show the similarities between homosexual and heterosexual relationships.  I agree that this happened
column22: but just not very coherently.  There seemed to be other elements strewn together in a very loose fashion that took away from the overall power of the film.  Don't get me wrong
column23: this could have been a very powerful film about a lifestyle that this world is still not accepting
column24: but instead it went too far to the left (which isn't bad
column25: except in this case) and chose to go the bleeding artist route instead of the informative
column26: here are the facts route.  The black and white photography
column27: the lack of character development (who really was Ely's partner?)
column28: and the cheesy moments between scenes where women talked to me about the illusive "honey pot".  It just wasn't coming together well for me and eventually fell apart all together.  Overall
column29: I was not impressed.  There are greater films out there that express the power of the relationship and do not create this unimpressive "raw" sensation by trying to shock the audiences.  One of my favorites is the film Big Eden which accepts homosexuality like it is commonplace in society.  If Go Fish would have been done in a similar style
column30: I think I could have walked away from the film with a better taste in my mouth.  Instead
column31: I am stuck with an unimpressive story that did nothing except joke about why lesbian women like to play the game "Go Fish".  Ha ha ha h....it just isn't working for me.  I do not recommend this film in the least bit.  There was one
column32: singular scene that made me chuckle and for the likes of me I cannot remember why.  It was an unmemorable feast of bad cinema.  Skip it.  Grade: * out of ****

column1: This book was not what I'd hoped for - which is a solid introduction to Yixing teapots.  It concentrates on the history of Yixing teapots - and those that have been found in archaeological digs dating back to the Song Dynasty in China.  Many of these ancient pots are illustrated in the book. There is some discussion on the qualities that make Yixing clay different from most other types of clay
column2: but there is also much missing.  The book doesn't illustrate examples of the differing colours available in the clay and never discusses famous clay types like Zhu Ni
column3: which is so highly sought after by Yixing collectors.  There is a fairly large section on ancient masters of the art and those of the 19th and early 20th centuries. It's just a shame that their chops or signatures - which are usually recorded on their pots are not included in the text. Also missing is information on the modern state of the Yixing industry and the mechanical way modern pots are mostly made.  This is a rather basic and superficial look at Yixing pots and wares - but if you are after some biographical information on the most famous past masters or want to see illustrations on some very ancient Yixing pots then this book will be of interest to you.

column1: As someone who is very interested in oil and it's effects on the global economy
column2: I looked forward to reading this book with great interest.   The Leebs go through a cursory analysis of the state of the current oil supply.  The question of when we will reach peak oil production is open to great debate with estimates varying widely depending on who is asked.  The Leebs assume that we will arrive at our peak oil consumption in this decade and predict $100/barrel oil by 2010.    They may be right
column3: they may be wrong.  I am not troubled by their prediction of $100 oil; however
column4: their conclusion that $100+ oil will cause hyperinflation is stated as fact with no real evidence to substantiate their belief.  In fact
column5: many economists will argue that rapidly increasing oil prices could be deflationary or only marginally inflationary.  The Leebs assume that the oil embargo of the 1970s and the resulting inflationary spiral that occurred in the U.S. will occurr again as oil prices march steadily higher.  This logic is flawed for a number of reasons
column6: not the least of which is that a steady
column7: measured rise in prices allows time for the global economy to adapt to higher oil prices in ways that a sudden oil shock does not.    Furthermore
column8: some economists argue that higher oil prices could be deflationary.  The Leebs ignore the fact that we are living in a globalized and highly competitive environment that is very different from the world of the late 70s.  If companies are having greater difficulty passing along higher energy costs to consumers; profit margins will contract
column9: investment in R&D and new manufacturing capacity will slow
column10: job groth will stagnate
column11: and deflation will be as great
column12: if not more of a threat
column13: than inflation.  When manufactures are able to pass higher energy prices to consumers
column14: the higher costs will tend to suppress demand thereby limiting economic and wage growth.    Personally
column15: I think they got it wrong.  The Leebs do not support their basic premise that higher oil prices will lead to inflation; they accept it as received wisdom.  For this reason
column16: everything that flows from their assumption of hyperinflation is flawed.

column1: I just saw the author talk about this book for nearly an hour on C-Span 2's Book TV.  He says he researched and wrote and tried to get inside the mind and career of Crockett for three years
column2: and he talked about him for 45 minutes without ever mentioning the fact of human slavery.    Crockett was a slaveholder
column3: and may have also been a slave trader.  In 45 minutes the author not only never mentions this
column4: but never used the word "slave: or :slavery" nor even made indirect allusions to the topic
column5: though it was at the center of American and Southern economic and political life during Crockett's career.  It was common back then for folks down on their luck to purchase some slaves in the East
column6: rope them neck to neck and walk them to Mississippi or Arkansas
column7: when that was the frontier
column8: or in Crockett's heyday
column9: to Texas
column10: where they would sell for three times the value they brought at the point of purchase.  Did that have something to do with Crockett's trek to Texas?  Did he bring any with him?  We'll never know from Buddy Levy.  The secession of Texas from Mexico was largely about the fact that white Texians
column11: as they called themselves
column12: demanded the legalization of slavery
column13: and the right to legally hunt down and return escapees from Arkansas and Louisiana.  On Book TV
column14: Levy talked for forty five minutes
column15: at great length about the secession of Texas and the political climate and happenings there at the time of Crockett's death.  He spent a few minuted detailing the career of Mexican president Santa Ana too
column16: recounting how the white settlers regarded him as a dictator
column17: but never mentioned the dictatorial act which displeased them the most -------- his refusal to allow slavery in Texas.    At the time of the Alamo
column18: one in five "Texians" were slaves.  Make no mistake
column19: despite the author's apparently sanitized version of the history --- that's what Crockett and others died at the Alamo for.  Human slavery.  Based upon his Book TV show and the author's evident big blind spot
column20: if I see his work in a library or bookstore I'll pick it up and look in the index to see if slavery gets mentioned
column21: if there is an index at all.  But I would never buy it
column22: and wouldn't recommend it.  Bruce Dixon Marietta G

column10: also

Shaw wrote Eliza's character very precisely to have individual dignity and determination to help her achieve her goals. The one thing I liked.  The play is about adaptation and transformation. column5: and more whining than day saving. Book 6 made them stand in paper doll doing a bad job miming the motions the real characters would have done.  This book Harry seemed to care more about romance.  A very poorly done romance littered with cheezy phrases and romantic moments on par with the worst of bad fanfiction; which had no background or build up from previous books.  A female character from the background
column6: whom Harry barely even notices all through the past five books
column7: is suddenly the most perfect and beautiful girl in the school in mary-sue fashion.  Several other characters in both the foreground and background were also unfortunately treated to Rowlings amature attempts at romance

The image of Harry that stuck with me and seemed to glare off the pages every time he spoke or did anything was of him lying

column1: Peter Tremayne's books have interesting plots and the stories are told well.  But beware
column2: if you're looking for a satisfying
column3: historically accurate view of seventh-century Ireland.  Tremayne (a pseudonym of the popular historian Peter Berresford Ellis) certainly knows about Irish law.  But widening circles show more and more ignorance.  The physical environment of a monastery in this period is simply wrong
column4: ranging from construction to scale (the evil monastery of this volume sounds more like a great Benedictine monastery of the twelfth century than anything of the likes of Clonmacnois or Glendalough).  There's extreme oddity in terminology
column5: such as the plural French word "religieux" to describe a single monk
column6: or "noviciate" in place of "novice
column7: both of which suggest he knows little of monastic life.  But most disturbing about this book is the utterly false picture it paints of Roman" Christianity in the early Middle Ages---stating specifically that ecclesiastical authorities suppported and enforced death penalties
column8: regularly engaged in corporal punishment
column9: etc.
column10: through a bizarre law system labeled as "the Penitentials."  This stuff just isn't true

column1: After many years
column2: I decided to finally give Kathy Reichs' Temperance Brennan series a go.  So
column3: where better to start than her debut novel 'Deja Dead' which introduces Reichs' heroine.  Temperance Brennan is an American forensic anthropologist working in Montreal for what I'm guessing is the French-Canadian equivalent of a Medical Examiner's office.  Of course our heroine is head strong
column4: independent
column5: and unlucky in love (aren't they all?).  Well
column6: some murders start turning up and
column7: amazingly enough
column8: our intrepid anthropologist is the only person that links the crimes together.  Do the police believe her?  No
column9: so she must investigate the crimes on her own.  And by doing so
column10: the murderer then turns his attention to Brennan and her family and friends (don't all killers eventually do that?).  First off
column11: the book is bloated.  The book (at least the paperback version) clocks in at about 530 pages.  Reichs' writes too much about menial tasks that her character
column12: Brennan
column13: does during her usual day.  Does anyone really want to hear repeatedly about what a character had for dinner or what paperwork she does at work?  I know I don't want to read it.  Now I'm a person who enjoys a nice
column14: long book but 'Deja Dead' (where did she get that title anyway?) is about two hundred pages too long.  And it is a very slow read.    Secondly
column15: her main character
column16: Brennan
column17: just isn't likeable.  In fact
column18: I found her quite annoying.  The policemen in the novel are portrayed as incompetent
column19: arrogant jerks who are too worried about being right than they are about doing the right thing.  When in fact I think that they just didn't want to deal with this overly nosy anthropologist who is obviously stepping on toes and irritating people who are just trying to do their jobs.  Reichs' tries to portray Brennan as a lone crusader fighting against all these odds to get to the criminal.  When in fact she is an irritating anthropologist who has no business investigating a murder.  She is
column20: basically
column21: a laboratory-based employee who should not be in the field.  So I don't blame the cops in the book that don't like her.  She's butting her nose in where it doesn't belong and
column22: in a part I actually liked
column23: she ends up bringing irreparable damage to her family and friends.  I thought it a just outcome.  Also
column24: after about the twentieth time of Brennan looking at some cop's rear end and saying "I like the way his butt looks...Oh
column25: stop!  You need to get laid." I wanted to scream.  Dr. Brennan
column26: at least in this debut novel
column27: is extremely irritating.  Thirdly
column28: I have read the basic plot of this book in a hundred other novels.  The suprise "switcheroo" ending is not suprising but more annoying...  It is just a cheap way to trick the reader.  And if I have to read about one more main character who ends up becoming the target of the "killer"
column29: I will scream.  Its pathetic.  How many times does it need to be written?  Its ridiculous.  Now
column30: 'Deja Dead' is the first of Reichs' books that I've read.  I've heard that the following books in the Brennan series are better and I certainly hope this is the case.  I really didn't like the book:  not the characters
column31: the plot
column32: the writing...  But I will give Reichs another try and read the next book in the series.  If its as bad as 'Deja Dead'
column33: I don't think I ever read another one her books

column1: In Edward Klein's The Kennedy Curse: Why America's First Family Has Been Haunted by Tragedy for 150 Years
column2: there isn't much new here except for pure gossip
column3: rumor and innuendo.    Klein starts off to make this a pseudo-scientific study of facts contributing to the Kennedy curse including lots of psycho-babble
column4: genetic factors
column5: etc.  He claims his book is a detective story.  He tries to show how "the Irish immigrant experience of poverty and humiliation developed into an obsessive lust for power and dominance over others at the expense of all ethical behavior."  Throw in domineering fathers
column6: cold mothers
column7: alcohol
column8: drugs
column9: sex
column10: thrill-seeking behavior
column11: ADHD
column12: restlessness
column13: boredom and impatience
column14: and you get a prescription for tragedy.  Many people believe a black cloud has followed the Kennedy family for many generations.  It actually appears that the Kennedy's followed the black cloud on their own.    In trying to prove his curse theory
column15: Klein spotlights seven family members including immigrant Patrick Kennedy
column16: Joe Kennedy
column17: Sr.
column18: Kathleen (Kick) Kennedy
column19: JFK
column20: William Kennedy Smith
column21: JFK
column22: Jr.
column23: and JFK's maternal grandfather
column24: John Honey Fitz Fitzgerald.  He barely mentions other Kennedy's that have suffered tragedies including Bobby Kennedy
column25: Ted Kennedy
column26: and Joe Kennedy
column27: Jr.  It was interesting to read about the immigrant experience of the Irish
column28: as well as some of the lesser known family members including Kathleen Kennedy and Honey Fitz.  But overall
column29: there isn't much new here
column30: and what is new seems mostly rumor and innuendo.  For instance
column31: Klein accuses JFK of having "chronic venereal disease" and claims it is possible that this caused the death of his pre-mature son
column32: Patrick.  This is a pretty serious allegation to make without proof.  He also tells how Carolyn Bessette Kennedy's friends destroyed her drug stash after that fateful plane crash.  I don't believe the Kennedy's are saints and I know they've done some atrocious things
column33: but give us hard facts.  Overall
column34: my recommendation is to skip The Kennedy Curse.  If you want to read more about this fated family
column35: there are much better and more comprehensive books to be had.  It is hard to believe this book was written by a Pulitzer Prize-winning author.

column1: This is a movie about a big girl who gets 'made over' and becomes thin
column2: finds love and lives happily ever after. It's a spoof on romantic comedies
column3: sort of like "Scary Movie" is a spoof on horror movies but this was not nearly as funny. I didn't like this movie. It tried hard to be funny but it wasn't. It was just a yawner! It relied on cheap
column4: stereotypical and often sexist jokes and tired parodies which will be forgotten in a few years and be even less funny. I wasn't deeply offended by this movie but I disliked the way it objectified women (i.e. showing a fat girl going to a body shop like a car to get made skinny and the super hot ex-girlfriend who looks and acts slutty and the boyfriend who thinks it's appropriate to have his ex hang all over him) I am fine with sex and nudity in movies but I didn't like the message behind this film. It was mindless and painful to watch and made me uncomfortable. I happen to be young and thin and generally have a good sense of humor about sexist jokes but something about this movie just left me with a yucky feeling! I feel like this movie insulted my intelligence. There are plenty of things in this world which make young women feel bad about the way they look and it's generally not a quality I look for in a so-called comedy! This is funny if you are male and under the age of 16 and even then
column5: this movie might be a bit overboard!

column1: If you want to read a great book on personal illness by a fine writer
column2: read Reynolds Price' "A Whole New Life."  The prose is authentic and there is not a touch of pretense in it.   Styron's lack of insight into his illness is topped only by his lack of knowledge of abnormal psychology.  His declaration that depression is caused by a chemical imbalance is disturbing
column3: because it mixes cause and effect.  His assertion is tantamount to attributing global warming to melting glaciers.  Mixing cause and effect is not something one would attribte to a writer of his distinction
column4: as it is the essence of clear thought.  Yes
column5: the intensity and distribution of various neuro-chemicals have been found to be compromised among those suffering depression who have been tested.  But how are they compromised?  Contrary to the author's belief that "the madness results from an aberrant biochemical process
column6: and that such madness is chemically induced
column7: it is the commonly-held view today that psychology plays the decisive causitive role in mental illness, as that psychology is formulated and developed throughout life, and is influenced by situations, including loss, misuse of drugs and alcochol, and unconscious dilemmas, among others.   That an organic etiology has been surmised in many cases of schizophrenia and other psychosis, as well as in profound obsessions, certainly rules in" brain damage
column8: whether it is evident at birth
column9: or the result of other physical and emotional trauma later in life; but it does not rule out psychology and the higher order mental functions we attribute to consciousness.

column1: BECOMING A MASTER MANAGER
column2: the textbook currently used in my Introduction to Management class
column3: does not effectively convey the important fundamentals of business management.  The book is structured around eight 'roles' of an effective manager
column4: and each role is further broken down into a number of competencies that are functions of that particular role.  While I appreciate the effort to organize a relatively broad subject
column5: I do not feel that the book is necessarily easy to follow.  The reading is constantly being interrupted by assessments and applications for each competency
column6: and while meant well
column7: they are usually skipped over in an attempted to finish the reading and they seem to me to be a large waste of paper.  Furthermore
column8: BECOMING A MASTER MANAGER stresses models and theories of management that I find useless without the necessary fundamentals of management
column9: which are not adequately presented in the textbook.  Some of the models and theories have merit and should be discussed more in depth
column10: but in a more advanced level of business management.  And while BECOMING A MASTER MANAGER is the official textbook for my management class
column11: I have relied heavily on a different textbook for my information
column12: and only the eve of a test do I bother to look over BECOMING A MASTER MANAGER
column13: I do not recommend this textbook for an introductory class at all

column1: I have read many bad books

column1: I USUALLY LIKE REICH'S BOOKS BUT HIS ONE WAS A WASHOUT.  IS EVERYONE GETTING ON THE DIVINCI BANDWAGON?? DIDN'T EVEN BOTHER TO FINISH IT
This book is not a serious or scholarly piece of work
column2: and I recommend that you not waste your time reading it.  It begins with a description of the life of Mohammed
column3: the origins and spread of Islam
column4: and the creation of various Islamic sects.  This is probably the best part of the book
column5: but it is still very poor.  For example
column6: Schwartz never really explains even the basic distinction between Shi'a and Sunni Islam.  And Schwartz's overall goals badly tarnish his discussion:  He wants to portray traditional Islam as being perfectly pluralist
column7: tolerant
column8: and peace-loving
column9: so as to contrast it with hate-filled
column10: intolerant
column11: and violent Wahhabism.  As a result
column12: his description of the Ottoman Empire (representing Schwartz's traditional Islam) is completely uncritical and consequently not credible.  For instance
column13: he never even mentions the Ottomans' barbaric and murderous treatment of Armenians and Kurds
column14: to name just two salient examples.  The rest of the book follows a similar pattern:  There are Muslims Schwartz likes (especially Sufis)
column15: and there are Muslims he hates (Wahhabis
column16: plus others who are not Wahhabis but whom Schwartz describes as "Wahhabized
column17: though he never explains what  that's supposed to mean).  The good" Muslims can do no wrong
column18: and the "bad" Muslims are behind just about every act of terrorism committed anywhere on the globe.  I know this sounds like it must be a charicature of the book
column19: but it's not.  Rather
column20: Schwartz's book is itself a charicature of the complexity of contemporary international affairs.  An example will illustrate Schwartz's appalling sloppiness with evidence.  On pages 217-218
column21: he claims that a "manifesto" written by Osama bin Laden proves that Saddam Hussein is connected with bin Laden and Al Qaeda.  I found this surprising
column22: because there is
column23: to my knowledge
column24: no proven link between them whatsoever (and I have followed this issue very closely).  In fact
column25: it is well known that bin Laden has always hated Hussein and secular rulers like him
column26: that bin Laden had called for Hussein's overthrow
column27: that Hussein hated bin Laden and had brutally repressed Islamic fundamentalists like him
column28: etc.  (See
column29: for example
column30: the analysis of this issue in a report by the Carnegie Endownment for International Peace).  So I was very curious to see what evidence Schwartz had found in bin Laden's "manifesto" to support his conclusion that
column31: in spite of all that
column32: Hussein and bin Laden were allies.  Here is Schwartz's evidence:  In his "manifesto
column33: bin Laden (1) called for an end to the UN sanctions on Iraq, (2) lamented the destruction inflicted on Iraq in the first Gulf War, and (3) also lamented the deaths of Iraqi children that were caused by the UN santions.  I'm not kidding--that is the sum total of Schwartz's proof" that Hussein was an ally of bin Laden and Al Qaeda in their global terror campaign.  It's absurd.  The book does contain one interesting thesis:  Schwartz claims that for most Americans
column34: the face of violent and dangerous Islamic extremism is Ayatolla Khomeini and the Iranian revolution
column35: while Americans have regarded Saudi Islam as "moderate" because the Saudis are US allies.  Schwartz plausibly argues that the reverse is true:  Saudi Islam (Wahhabism) is much more dangerous because of its support for a "holy war" without borders
column36: while the Islamic revolution in Iran was really about liberating the Shi'a of Iran from oppression under the Shah
column37: not about waging a larger war beyond Iran (although Schwartz does acknowledge Iranian support for certain Palestinian militant groups).  The thesis is interesting and possibly true.  But that one interesting point certainly doesn't make this dreadful book worth reading.  If you are looking for an introduction to Islam
column38: or for insightful and well-reasoned discussion of world affairs
column39: please look elsewhere

column10: and smell like. She includes several sexual episodes in which attention to vaginas seems to be emphasized. The monologues on female genital mutilation and ethnic rape are disturbing. column11: and the consequences of ethnic rape the next. One topic is silly; the other screams for thorough treatment. Henri-Georges Clouzot's "Diabolique" is a film that falls short of its potential.  Its rather routine resolution undermines its brilliant premise
column2: suffocating atmosphere
column3: and top-notch acting.     Christina Delasalle (Vera Clouzot) and Nicole Horner (Simone Signoret) conspire to murder Michel Delasalle (Paul Meurisse)
column4: the director of a boarding school.  Christina is Michel's wife and Nicole is his mistress.  Both are frequent victims of his abusive nature.  The two women carry out their plan perfectly but Michel's body disappears soon after they dispose of it.  Even more troubling to Christina and Nicole is that subsequent developments suggest that the murdered man might still be alive.     "Diabolique" is graced with three outstanding performances.  Meurisse is effectively slimy as the subject of the murderers' ire while Clouzot and Signoret are superb as the oddly-matched killers.  The film also does a wonderful job of keeping the viewer in suspense once Michel's body disappears.  However
column5: the payoff at the end is not worth all the time the viewer has invested in the film.  The ending is not clever
column6: shocking
column7: or surprising.  It is just plain disappointing.  Too put it simply
column8: "Diabolique" is one of those films that runs out of gas before it crosses the finish line.

column1: Read my initial review below which was on July 27.  On August 11
column2: Kensington told me that they do not know when the password registration process will be working
column3: and they strongly urged me to send the product back for a refund.    On July 27 I wrote: This should be a great item at a great price.  And as far as I can tell
column4: it works fine.  Kensington has some serious technical problems
column5: however.   The encryption installs and becomes fully-functional before you can register your USB key and password.  Registration is essential in case you lose the key or forget your password.  This is a BIG problem
column6: because as of July 26
column8: Kensington's registration utility was down and not expected to be working until 6-10 days(current estimate).  Worse
column9: the message I got when attempting to register my key the first two days was "Authentication Failed" which told me nothing.  Even worse
column10: their overseas technical support person did not know about the problem. So he also thought I had a defective key
column11: and we wasted a lot of time discussing replacement and timing (I'm about to leave on a trip and really wanted this protection for the trip).  When I finally realized that I would not receive a new key before I left
column12: I asked whether I should uninstall the product or whether I could register the key verbally in case the key was lost on the trip (I figured the answer was no but I was getting desperate).  He went away for a long time
column13: then he reported that he would have to call me back (that took 40 minutes) and finally he reported that probably my key was fine
column14: it's the registration that was offline.  And no
column15: there is no other way to register - that's part of the security.  So the encryption is in place
column16: the laptop boots and runs fine
column17: but I have two days to decide whether to risk taking my laptop and losing the physical key
column18: which means I would have to wipe my hard drive
column19: or risk uninstalling the encryption and having the laptop stolen
column20: in which case I still lose all my data AND sensitive data is exposed.  The laptop will be at risk in hotel rooms
column21: and the key will be at risk on my person as I will be swimming and snorkeling. Kensington claims the thing is waterproof - maybe I'll just buy one of those little waterproof capsules and keep it around my neck.

column1: After the book Ms. Campbell did for Beadwork on beaded beads I expected this to be more and BETTER.  Instead it's mostly just a collection of project classes taught to beginners.  The only artistic offering in the whole book is the Industrial Strength Bead by Ingrid Bloch made from hex nuts from the hardware store.  The remainder of the projects is a big yawn. You'd never be caught dead in a necklace of Pumpkin beads or Crisscross beads.  I taught 8-year old Girl Scouts how to make Sea Anemone beads years ago!!  You've seen them all before.  The gallery pieces are gorgeous and some are even made by the contributors to the book.  If they can do this high quality work
column2: why include the insipid baby sample projects?  Why can't more quality books be written like the one by Valerie Hector?  There is a glut of junk project books on the market and this is just another one. Save your money or else buy the Beadwork book on beaded beads and Valerie Hector's book. PS  Since Diane Fitzgerald has several beads in this book her 5 star rating is hardly objective.  While her designs have not been published before they are just variations of the ones delineated in Valerie Hector's book. Even with her bias for the book she describes the projects as "tiny".  Maybe these project books should be marked "baby" when their projects are so basic and pedestrian.

I recently purchased the Receptor HD. Out of the box it was a fairly complex set-up. The antennas are totally inadequate. I am 10 miles across water from Seattle and neither antenna can pick up more than half the HD stations there. I have an Accurian from Radio Shack and it picks all the stations up with no difficulty using the same antenna(s) in the same place. And it cost 1/2 as much. The Receptor sound is "boomy". If you walk away from it
column2: all you can hear is muffled booming. After 5 days
column3: the radio quit entirely. Boston Acoustics was non-responsive to emails and has only a toll number with long waits to speak to anyone. They say they will repair it...but I must wait for an RA...and shipping is at my expense. Not a lot of confidence in their products! Listen and compare before you buy. The Accurian only lacks an input for external devices..and it sounds more balanced

column1: I could sum up this book very quickly:  1) Trust in God for everything  2) Read the Bible  3) Attend church  4) Ask your husband

The book primarily revolves around the Bible and its interpretation of parenting. Why not cut out the middle-man and just read this "wonderful book?" It's not like the Bible is a work in progress.   This book is more about proselytizing and keeping Evangelicals reading "inspired" books rather than competing viewpoints. And with America being one of the most pure Christian nations in the world ( US is more Christian than India is Hindu and Israel is Jewish ). Anything published by Zondervan should be looked at skeptically.   I also dislike how males are stilled deemed unworthy parents in the Christian community. They can assist and help
column4: but cannot be considered primary parents. But given this books lack of true substance
column5: I doubt it would have made any difference

column1: As a strong proponent of attachment parenting and a rather radical unschooler
column2: this book was a BIG disappointment!!! I bought this book after reading the reviews and wish I hadn't paid more than $1 for it. While the title "The Unprocessed Child" accurately describes Laurie's upbringing
column3: this book shouldn't be grouped with other unschooling literature. The author
column4: while cherishing the close bond she has with her daughter
column5: reminds me of the mother in "Love You Forever" who sneaks across town and climbs into her grown son's room at night to spend time with him--sweet but a bit creepy. The fact that she admits that she even went to college at the same time as her daughter so she could spend more time with Laurie pretty much says it all. The mother clearly has her own issues that I hope she allows herself to work through and heal from now that she's not spending 24/7 with her only child. We have been unschooling each of our four children since birth --challenging temperments and all--and I feel very privileged to spend so much time with them as they discover how exciting it is to decode and discover the world around them. If you want to read a GOOD book about unschooling without unsupported platitudes and preaching in almost every chapter
column6: I would recommend "Homeschooling our Children
column7: Unschooling Ourselves". Those authors offer more balance and eloquence than Ms. Fitzenreiter.

column1: Erskine Caldwell while apparently wrote during a different time
column2: apparently did nothing to promote anything other than stereotypes of the rural south.  I myself am from a small rural town in Arkansas and grew up with stories my grandparents told of their experiences during the great depression.  They were poor and lived by subsistence farming but they were proud and spoke with a sense of accomplishment of their home life.  While their education and opportunities may have been limited it seemed to make them appreciate what they did have later.  I was surprised to find out that Caldwell had actually lived in the South following my reading the book because he didn't seem to have anything pleasant to say about it at all.  All regions of the country do have impoverished persons who have no ambition to improve themselves nor realize the situation that they're in but this I felt was an unfair take on what was not an easy time for anyone in America.    If you like southern literature
column3: I would much more highly recommend a Willie Morris book
column4: Cold Sassy Tree by Olive Ann Burns
column5: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter
column6: maybe one of Shelby Foote's works of fiction
column7: or Eudora Welty amongst others.  In those stories
column8: poverty and racism which are issues in the south are evident but portrayed in a more fair and consistent light.  I will admit in closing that I was interested in the story and finished the book fairly quickly but I felt the content was not all that impressive and only served to deepen stereotypes and preordained views that wrongly exist about the South
