column1: Dear-o-dear-o-dear! I have just had the dubious privilege of previewing this offering aimed at the pre-teens
column2: paedophiles and tone deaf. It was like being a fly on the wall at a karaoke sleep over. I listened in disbelief as the girls slaughtered the pop classics - "Dancing Queen" may never sound the same again. It was scarey to think that these little divas had been given the benefit of "getting it right" in a studio setting. I'd hate to think what they sound like performing live. Most of the songs here make Little Jimmy Osmond singing "Long Haired Lover From Liverpool" sound quite good in comparison. Some songs are performed slightly better than others; "Girls Just Wanna Have Fun" was listenable but I would still urge these little darlings not to give up the day jobs. (I hope they haven't already?) If they keep practicing some of them may go on to better things but in the meantime I can't see it myself. Perhaps this CD was somebody's idea of being cruel to them. You know... play it back to them in a few years time when they are grown up. Still
column3: bless 'em eh?

column1: It does not seem that Thomas Pauley is particularly rich.  One of his best success stories is getting a good loan rate so he could buy a used Mercedes that had 55

column3: unicorns and mermaids
column4: you would see them running around all of time." One of the most objectionable ideas is his concept of tithing.  He makes God out to be some sort of cosmic accountant that will strike back at you is he does not get his 10%. Additionally Mr. Pauley's concept of tithing is very specific. According to Mr. Pauley giving to a church or charity is not tithing. Giving 10% to a rock star because you are inspired by his lyrics is fine (as in the case of his son).  If fact he would say that giving to poor people would be "foolish spending".  You should tith to your spiritual source. I get the distinct impression that he wants me to kick back 10% to him.   There are a few good ideas like make lists and get specific about your goals but it is never followed up by an action plan.  You should just put in your order and wait for the universe to fill it.  Mr Pauley covers himself with a hugh loophole which is

 I must begin by saying I am a fan of Gregory's and love 'The Other Boleyn Girl', 'Virgin's Lover' etc - could not put them down.    However, I did not like this book at all - and I tried very hard.  I see that I am not alone here as other people have loved her other work and disliked this one.  There was too much focus on the incest and sex - and while I completely understand that Beatrice is just a fictional character, the detail in the way she treated her brother sexually, etc was a bit much at times.  I actually preferred reading about the beautiful land she lived on.    One positive thing I will say is that Gregory really has driven her point home well on the fact that the women of Beatrice's era were very much powerless - they had no money of their own, could not inherit land even if they loved it - in fact lived and breathed it - more than their (to quote another reader) 'dimwitted brother'.  They were really quite forgotten and I have always found that truly sad - so well done to Ms Gregory for making that very important point.  She brings women to life on the pages of her books moreso than anything and you really feel for them - as much as I loathed Beatrice I felt sorry for her at the same time - she was in many ways a product of society and the way she and all women were treated.  She went mad in her desire to possess the land she so loved - but if she had the freedom that women today are lucky enough to have, she would probably have been a relatively normal woman.  A sad tale indeed.    I wouldn't recommend this one though - I'd point people towards Gregory's other work

column1: My roomate who is devoutly Catholic has this book and I decided to read it
column2: because to be honest
column3: if I read all history books that I would agree with
column4: I would find that my world was very narrow and one-sided.  Let me first start with some of the positives.  1. The book did present an orthodox perspective on many historical events in the early church.  Some of these examples include the debate over the Trinity
column5: Divinity of Christ Gnosticism and other controversies that were prevalent during this time period.  2. His research and work on Thomas Aquinas was excellent.  His examination of the early Scholastic movement was by far the best portion of this book.  3. He does criticize those in the church who abused their positions prior to and during the time of the Reformation.  However
column6: this was brief and will lead into some later criticisms.  4. He does actively criticize liberal Catholics who would see the church morph into something that has no basis in the Scriptures or in Church history.    Despite
column7: these positives
column8: there are many aspects of this book which are historically inaccurate and present an idealized picture of Church history which reflects a tendency to show a one-sides view of the Catholic Church.  In this way
column9: he moves away from being a historian and instead becomes an Catholic Apologist in the same vein as Karl Keating and others.  Criticisms (especially concerning the Protestant Reformation):  1. His utter dismissal of Eastern Orthodox and Protestant Churches as heretical.  On page 111
column10: he describes eastern Christianity as being a "hotbed of heresy."  It would seem that all Christian faiths outside of Roman Catholicism are untrue and without merit    2. Protestants particularly are treated with disdain.  Luther in particular is vilified as a rebel.  He quotes selectively from Luther in order to paint him as a wild and irrational human being.  While Luther's later anti-semitism is well worth being criticized or condemned
column11: Crocker goes too far in tying Luther to Hitler and the Holocaust.  Also
column12: he does a disservice in creating a false portrait of Erasmus as a superior theologian to Luther.  3. Along the same lines
column13: Calvin is given some credit as being the greatest Protestant theologian
column14: but he is ultimately dismissed as creating the first "Christian Police State."  Now
column15: Calvin again was a man who was imperfect
column16: but his Geneva Republic which he called an "Aristocracy bordering on Democracy" was one of the first attempts since ancient times to create a system of checks and balances and representative government that had not been terribly evident in the Middle Ages.  In the American context
column17: it might be interesting to note that Calvinism (in its distrust of human nature) was influential in helping the American Founders to create a system of checks and balances whereby we got our Executive
column18: Legislative and Judicial Bodies.  Also
column19: Crocker's comparision of Calvin's view of art to the ACLU was a cheap shot that could have been omitted.  With some of these thoughts in mind
column20: I recommend reading this book to provide a one-sided view of history.  However
column21: I would not read this as a detailed and non-partisan account of history.  A better book that is historically more sound and would seem to be non-partisan would be "The Protestant Reformation" by Diarmaid MacCulloch is a much more unbiased look at the Reformation.

column1: As is sometimes the case
column2: the title of this book is somewhat misleading.  Having read several books which were generally favorable to Greenspan I thought this one might give a balance counter view.  Overall
column3: it turned out to quite a disappointment.  In the first few pages Professor Batra made it clear that he thinks he is probably more qualified to be the Fed Chairman than Greenspan.  On page 1 he says "He had not done any path-breaking work in economics
column4: at least not that was commonly cited."  On page 3 he says "It could explain how he had advanced so far without sufficient credentials; how his extraordinary career appeared to derive crucially not from merit but from favoritism and connections".  Also on page 3 -"Greenspan did not even have a Ph.D. at the time; nor had he penned anything pioneering to earn the recognition of his peers".  On page 7 I again knew the book was in trouble when Batra stated "...because in my view intelligence and integrity go together".  Does anyone actually believe that all dishonest people are dumb?  On page 9 Batra made it clear that the book was as much
column5: or more
column6: about his economic philosophy than it was about Greenspan when he wrote "In fact
column7: I will offer a new economic paradigm to cure the global stagnation that has resulted from tax trade
column8: and monetary policies inspired by Greenspan".  He does offer a paradigm; unfortunately
column9: real world experience shows that the paradigm does not to work as he postulates.  Clearly
column10: the book is attempting to put forth his agenda.  As the rest of the book demonstrates
column11: Professor Batra is a fairly strong liberal in whose world the working poor will spend all additional income and the idle rich will simply put extra income under their mattress.  He regularly harps on reducing income taxes on the "poor" and increasing them on the "rich" and "big businesses".  As recently as 2003
column12: the Congressional Budget Office documented that the bottom 40% to 50% of the population pay little or no taxes while the upper income individuals and businesses pay the vast majority.  How the government could reduce the taxes on people who do not pay taxes is never addressed.  Professor Batra does correctly point out that the Social Security tax is quite regressive.  In order to discredit Greenspan
column13: Batra gives Greenspan gives Greenspan far more power than is warranted.  Throughout the book
column14: Batra tries to convince us that the President and Congress did whatever Greenspan might suggest or support.  As written
column15: the book makes one believe that Batra never watched Greenspan testify before Congress where the congressmen tried to get Greenspan to support their way of thinking.  Basically
column16: Batra tries to blame Greenspan for all of the acts of Congress.  Batra's new paradigm he calls Economic Democracy.  In this Economic Democracy the Federal Government would buy most of the stock of the large companies and then give it
column17: or sell it at a big discount
column18: to the employees of the companies.  That way the employees would be in control rather than the CEOs and boards of directors.  Clearly
column19: Professor Batra is not living in the real world.  In the real world most of the employees who were given the stock would simply sell it in fairly quick order and that
column20: of course
column21: would return things to where they originally were.  For many years I was an "employee owner" of the nations largest totally employee owned company and I can attest that they do not operate in any way close to what Professor Batra assumes.  The good professor needs to get out his ivory tower and get a job in the real world.  If you want to learn about Greenspan
column22: this is NOT the book to read.  Save your money.

column1: Sugrue's thesis in this book is that endemic racism (along with economic decline) is responsible for Detroit being largely Black
column2: poor and greatly in decline.  He's a revisionist historian who wants to refute older narratives that Detroit is corrupt (because all the city governments after 1967 have been run by Democrats and Blacks).  Instead he attempts to refute that by showing the deeply ingrained racism in the community.  Sugrue's attempt at political polemics is bad history.  He fails to mention the obvious: Detroit is over-taxed and run by incompetent
column3: corrupt politicians.  It's public unions have caused government workers to be some of the highest paid in the country with little to show for it.  This is thanks to former-Mayor Young who instituted an arbitration law.  To pay for this
column4: the city's taxes are exorbitant which pushes businesses further out.  Because of this
column5: Detroit never found other businesses to take the place of the declining auto-industry which has inflated pay for its jobs in the first place.  Of the past three mayors
column6: two have been highly corrupt.  Archer who was mayor in the '90s
column7: after a distinguished career in the state Supreme Court
column8: tried to reform the city but was kicked out of office.  Young and the current mayor
column9: Kilpatrick
column10: are very corrupt.  Just do a google news search of "Kwame Kilpatrick" and "corrupt" and you'll see the various scandals that have plagued him.  Other than stealing city funds for himself and his family he turned down a $200
column12: 000 private gift to the city for charter schools because the teacher's unions were against it.  Young
column13: mayor in the '70s and '80s
column14: made room for a GM plant by confiscating private land through eminent domain.  Few could understand why he buldozed tax producing land when he could have given over acres of abandoned property
column15: except that the residents of that neighborhood voted overwhelmingly against him.  Yes
column16: white people with means fled Detroit for the suburbs.  But Sugrue glosses over that fact that middle class Black residents left as soon as the could too.  Southfield
column17: a surburb township
column18: is overwhelming Black and middle class
column19: populated by those who couldn't stand the crime and corruption of Detroit.  Far from being an example of a typical post-industrial American City
column20: Detroit is the exception.  It should be held up as a prime example of how not to run a city.  That being said
column21: unless you've been assigned this book
column22: don't read it.  Sugrue gives excuses and vague general reasons (aka racism) for Detroit's decline when the real problems are staring him in the fac

column1: In Refuse To Choose
column2: Barbara Sher badly confuses two very real but very different problems: the inability of some people to finish any project they start
column3: and the shame dumped by family and friends on people who pursue many diverse passions in life.  The book rightly dismisses that misguided shame thrust on people with ecclectic interests
column4: and in doing so may be very helpful and encouraging to an otherwise successful person who meets that description.   But for people who are unable to bring any project to completion
column5: the book offers little useful advice
column6: and several suggestions that are likely to make the problem worse instead of better.  Instead of explaining how to complete projects and escape from the traps that prevent them from being completed
column7: the opening chapters dismiss the value of completing any project we start - an assertion even this book can't support for very long.  In the closing chapters of the book
column8: Sher gives exactly the same advice that anyone else would: pick one project and see it through to the finish
column9: ignoring all others.  And that's a reasonable suggestion
column10: but it leaves most readers right back where they started.   In one particularly ill-conceived passage
column11: Sher encourages overwhelmed parents to set aside parental responsibilities in favor of other priorities; she gives the example of feeding the kids cereal for dinner instead of going through another day's shopping routine
column12: and asking the children to help out with an important business report instead of working on it privately.  On the surface
column13: this sounds reasonable: why let drudgery sap away any more creative energy?  But a deeply misguided philosophy of parental and personal responsibility lies underneath this type of suggestion.  The children in this scenario learn that it is their responsibility to solve the parent's problems
column14: and they also learn that eating properly and other such "adult" behaviors are ultimately unnecessary.  The parent in this scenario learns that the sound parental decision-making is unimportant - and then the parent wonders why the adolescent child shows no ability to make good decisions.  There are good ways for a parent to maintain a reserve of creative energy
column15: but this ain't one of them.   Some of the ideas in the book are useful.  It is indeed a good idea to put aside others' negative judgments of our many exciting projects
column16: and to find encouragement by making lists of past accomplishments
column17: and to keep a journal of creative ideas
column18: and to occasionally abandon a project with the same enthusiasm with which it was launched.  But these are not new ideas: Julia Cameron's The Artist's Way covers the same territory with much greater insight and wisdom.  If you're looking to free yourself from your inability to complete any projects you start
column19: get The Artist's Way
column20: follow its program
column21: and find out what the real problem is.  And keep pursuing your many interests - but do it to satisfy your deepest desires
column22: not to distract yourself from them

 As a woman interested in the art and science of Ayurveda I was of course drawn to this book.  It is a very informative and helpful book but the tone of Svoboda's writing is very condescending.  In the beginning the author appears to have great respect for women and the fact that they are the givers of life.  But in every other paragraph to follow the doctor seems to make a point to talk down to the reader.  It's hilarious actually.  I wish I had the book in front of me to quote from.  He even goes so far as to instruct mothers in how to raise their children.  I don't know if this doctor is even a parent.  He makes no mention of his own experience in this area.  The amount of effort and energy that goes into creating and then raising up human beings is enormous and deserves respect and appreciation, which Svoboda for some reason is unable to offer to his readers.  This book does little to truly support women of any age group now that I really think about it.  Women need compassion, not simply facts and a talking to" about how they should be doing better.  So for all those who wish to read this book
column4: you will find clearly presented valuable information about how Ayurveda relates to womenkind.  But getting past Dr. Svoboda's holier-than-though tone is like scraping a heavy layer of ama off the tongue

column12: take a look at Halpern; you won't regret it.

 I rank this book slightly higher than Season of the Machete, simply because I only got to page 25 of that book before giving up on it. I finished this book, but it was hardly an enjoyable read. The one positive is that the chapters are very short, so it feels like the novel moves along at a nice pace. The actual content, however, is very poor. This book is just surviving off the past Cross novels. If someone was just picking up this book having not read any of the prior Cross novels, they are just not going to understand or care about the subplots involving Cross's estranged son, his other two kids, this new love life, etc. I've read all the books leading up to this book, and I barely cared or understood what was going on.   Compare this to Kiss The Girls or Jack and Jill, and it comes up way short. The story and the plot are very thin and very disjointed. Nothing about this book keeps you on the edge of your seat, and you will only feel compelled to finish it if you are a completist. This was by far the worst of the Cross books.

column9: you'll not care if Rachel herself winds up sharing the victim's fate. column1: You'll never get the straight story about nationalism out of Eric Hobsbawm
column2: who himself appears to try to reconcile his own ethnic identity with the topic.  David Pryce-Jones once noted that in Hobsbawm's own autobiography: "he [Hobsbawm] boasts of a visit to Bir Zeit University on the West Bank to display solidarity with the Palestinians.  Why Palestinian nationalism is valid
column3: and Jewish nationalism invalid
column4: is something else Hobsbawm fails to analyze and explain. Quite crudely
column5: he approves of nationalism in countries which proclaim themselves Communist and anti-American
column6: like Cuba or Vietnam
column7: while rejecting nationalism in countries which are not Communist and are pro-American
column8: like Israel" ([...]
column9: Jan. 3
column10: 2003).  Such twisted thinking is evident through "Nations and Nationalism
column11: where Mr. Hobsbawm spares no effort, however subtle, to demean nationalism that doesn't conform to his pre-existing prejudices.  In short, when writing about nationalism, Mr. Hobsbawm allowed his considerable analytic and writing skills to become corrupted by his religion, communism.  Therefore, unless you are an acolyte of that religion, this book is not worth your time, money or effort to read, and if you *are* a member of that religion, I suggest you broaden your intellectual horizons a bit, perhaps by reading Liah Greenfield's Nationalism: Five Roads to Modernity" or Benedict Anderson's "Imagined Communities.

column1: After reading this very badly written book my concern is how I am ever going to trust St. Martin's Press again. This book should never have been published by a company with such a trustworthy track record. Clearly
column2: some house cleaning needs to be done at St. Martin's Press.   The plot development and character development have all the ear markings of a novice writer. Characters are trite
column3: clichd and very unbelievable. The lead character
column4: Lin Breedlove
column5: is one of the most unsympathetic and unlikable characters in current fiction. So much of Haywood Smith's personal bitterness is encapsulated in this character that you find yourself wishing Ms. Smith had spent a little more time in therapy
column6: following the breakup of her own marriage
column7: instead of charging readers the price of a book for her personal catharsis.   Ms. Smith has created a lead character so misguided
column8: angry and judgmental that the story is painful to read. Some of her misguided beliefs include: Everyone in California has a sexually transmitted disease
column9: you can get venereal disease by sitting on a chair at a wine bar
column10: any man who wants sex without a lifelong commitment is an evil piece of trash and Democrats are bad. Smith barely misses a chance to toss an insult at Democrats
column11: Bill Clinton in particular. So
column12: Democrats beware. You are paying good cash to read a very bad novel and be insulted.   But even more unsettling is the self-righteous world view that masquerades as plot in this novel. It is not only bad writing but a true disregard for one's readers.  There are so many plot mistakes in this book
column13: which should have been caught by Smith or the editors at St. Martin's Press
column14: that I wonder if anyone actually read the final manuscript. At one point in the book
column15: we are told Lin Breedlove first met her ex-husband in college. At another point in the book
column16: we are told she first met him when she was 14 years old. Lin Breedlove criticizes and judges anyone and everything outside her personal sphere of experience and comfort
column17: then harshly deals with anyone who dares criticize her.   The dialogue reads like text lifted from the latest self-help books and very bad pop psychology. What is designed to come off as a feminist point of view is
column18: ultimately
column19: Smith's own shrill cry of personal pain.   One of the most unsettling elements of the book is Smith's constant quoting of scripture
column20: mingled with talk of ten-inch erections
column21: dildos and oral sex. Both subjects
column22: certainly
column23: ideal components of a good novel. Mixed together by Smith's less than deft writing talent? Ummm...yuk.  And
column24: personal note to Ms. Smith - Jerry Mather's of "Leave it to Beaver" fame is not gay.   One last point
column25: there were so many typos in my copy of this book
column26: that it is clear nobody proofed the final draft.   A true waste of money.

column9: such as What's a Smart Woman Like You Doing at Home? by Linda Burton and Staying Home Instead by Christine Davidson.  Sharon Reilly (jdreilly@ntplx.ne

column1: The novel
column2: A Tale of Two Cities
column3: by Charles Dickens
column4: is a story of love and compassion
column5: which takes place during the beginnings of the French Revolution. Despite the fact that many aspects of the revolution are portrayed well in the novel
column6: the book is still a tiring read and requires a strong liking for Dickens' writing style.  	Throughout the novel
column7: Dickens bogs the story down with excessive descriptions and meaningless scenes. The language is relatively simple and easy to comprehend
column8: but the extra descriptions make the novel difficult to fully understand. Most of the characters in the novel are completely unrealistic
column9: which makes it difficult for the reader to relate to what is going on. The character of Lucie Manette
column10: is portrayed as the perfect women with absolutely no flaws. Her character is the supposed epitome for women
column11: but in truth
column12: is highly improbable. Throughout the novel
column13: Dickens' does a great job at keeping the story dry and unentertaining
column14: giving little to no excitement to cause the reader to want to continue. Despite these countless imperfections
column15: Dickens' does manage to be partially successful in his quest to portray the revolution.  	The book
column16: with all its shortcomings
column17: did reveal to the reader
column18: the atrocities that occurred during the French Revolution
column19: and the events that led to it. The abuse of the nobles
column20: and the radical ideas of the revolutionists are all shown in many parts of the novel. The one other aspect that Dickens got right in his novel was the character of Sydney Carton. Sydney Carton is the only character in the story that many readers can relate too and understand a variation of what Carton feels. Carton is a lawyer who feels that everything he has done in his life has been wrong and believes that he can do no good in life. This characteristic is common among people
column21: and Dickens manages to capture that aspect of humanity precisely.   	The novel
column22: A Tale of Two Cities
column23: is a slow moving book with numerous flaws that cause the reader to lose interest fairly often. Dickens' overuse of description and unrealistic characters add to the book's dryness. However
column24: Dickens does capture a time in history with great accuracy. This is a book for a reader who likes Dickens' overzealous descriptions and enjoys slow moving stories.

column1: I don't see any point in writing nasty reviews and I apologize if this inadvertently comes off as nasty.  I'm just trying to save you some time and money.    I bought this thinking it would be a really good book on pranayama without diving into the one by rosen's teacher Iyengar.  I waited excitedly.  What a waste of time
column2: money and enthusiasm.  He doesn't even cover any kind of pranayama at all in any way that would make it worthwhile to read through this.    He's an official Iyengar yoga teacher and its like he would have had to get permission from on high to teach anything at all meaningful and he knew he couldn't so he settled for this book of basically nothing.    My understanding is his teacher
column3: Iyengar
column4: had tuburculosis (or something a lot like it) as a child and that's why he took up yoga.  For that reason he's kind of weird on the subject of breathing.  He thinks you should "master" the physical exercises before you even begin to do anything like pranayama (whatever the heck "master" means;be a ballet dancer?). He's the only yoga teacher I've ever heard of who thinks this (exept for the legions of people who teach his style).  It's like he got so good at asanas that he thinks that's all that matters.  The point is there's something about the Iyengar set-up that precluded this guy possibly putting out a book on pranayama that was anything but baby food.  Just deep breathing
column5: basically.  After reading this (which is good if you just want examples of different ways the Iyengar people use belts and blankets
column6: excellent pictures) I gave in and bought Iyengars book on pranayama.    I think one could buy that one instead of this and refer to the beginner schedules for pranayama programs in the back of the book and just jump right in.  You can buy it used on amazon for not that much.  I'll be honest with you
column7: I have misgivings about Iyengar as a teacher of anything other than asanas.  I read in one of his books that his teacher didn't really teach him pranayama (he went out on his own as a teacher when he was only eighteen).  I'm not sure where he learned his version of pranayama.  I think he said he may have learned it from a book called hatha yoga pradipika.    You can buy a very good version of "hatha yoga pradipika" on amazon by a guy named hans-ulrich rieker.  Another approachable one is by a swami vishnu-devananda.  A third and longer one
column8: put out by bihar school of yoga is by a lady named Swami Muktibodhananda
column9: who I'm sad to say passed away recently.    Anyway
column10: no matter how much Iyengar yoga is publicised by people like "Yoga Journal" in america
column11: it's really pretty much a one-trick pony.  The books from India put out by "Bihar School of Yoga" are infinitely better.  No matter how wildly popular Iyengar's method is right now there's nowhere to go with it
column12: in terms of it really being a spiritual pathway.  For that you need pranayama and they keep pushing that further into the distance
column13: like a carrot on a stick
column14: with the lame belief that becoming a gymnast is the answer.    If strenght and flexibility where the answer when you go to see the nutcracker ballet at christmas the show would never happen because when the curtain went up all the ballerinas would be laid out prone in samadhi (superconsciousness).  Ok
column15: now all the Iyengar enthusiasts can start throwing bricks at me.  I'm really just telling you the facts

How could anyone sit and read this boring work of fiction.  I am actually listening to the audio version and I am almost falling asleep and cannot remember a word the reader has said. I am going to stick to the movie versions of Anne of Green Gables instead of reading the rest of the books.  At least the movies keep your interest
By chance before picking this up I had just finished The Heart is a Lonely Hunter by Carson McCullers
column2: and was struck by the similarities and differences. It's a great "compare and contrast" pair
column3: as an exercise for high-schoolers.  Both are written as first-person accounts by teen-aged girls and are roughly contemporary. Heart published in 1940
column4: and Castle in 1948
column5: both about life in the 30s.   Both families are poor. In Castle though
column6: there is never any question that the girls might go off and get jobs. This is supposedly because they "don't know how to do anything". So instead they sell off their belongings and get by on scraps of bread and the odd bit of butter. How charming! They are "eccentric"
column7: which seems enough in the author's eyes to exempt them from the expectation of supporting themselves. Only Stephen the handsome young son of the late housekeeper
column8: enamored of Cassandra
column9: does work and gives the family his entire salary. But he is of the class that is expected to toil after all. Even he is rewarded in the end--able to avoid labor with an easy job similar to that of step-mum Topaz--striking poses.  Unlike the looming and grinding poverty of Heart then
column10: the poverty in the Castle never amounts to more than a lark--educated folks playing at being poor until they're rescued by romantic circumstance. Not so in America where Mick Kelly
column11: who didn't know how to do anything either
column12: went off to work at Woolworth's
column13: and to a life of little hope.  In Castle the solution comes in the form of that classic deus ex machina
column14: the inheritance. Two dashing young wealthy Americans one of whom has inherited the castle
column15: show up just in time
column16: with their chatty modern mum. They throw money around and talk too much
column17: in the cliched extravagant American style. Most of the remainder of the novel consists of Cassandra and her sister Rose swooning over one brother or the other
column18: with an eventual romantic result that assures all the characters of economic well being.   It's all so very charming
column19: bourgeois
column20: and harmless. If your life is hard don't worry--a man will show up to rescue you!  The reviews for this novel in Amazon are overwhelmingly positive. Smith was obviously talented. Her writing is elegant and a pleasure to read. I wish she had given Cassandra a little more ambition.

column4: especially for people who may not have read much in this area
column5: I thought it was superficial.  It wasn't complex enough for a psychotherapy audience and it didn't seem to be a good fit for the popular psyche market either.  I think one would get a better and clearer understanding from Jack Morin's book "Your Erotic Mind."  I don't know of anything better out there on this topic.  The two authors approach the subject differently
column6: so if you own this book already
column7: you may want to consider a different perspective.

column1: I wanted to like this book.  I wanted to learn something about the modern rise of anti-semitism.  Sometimes
column2: you just don't get what you want.  I read the book
column3: hoping to answer some serious questions: Is anti-Zionism the same as anti-semitism ?  Are Jewish anti-Zionists experiencing self-hate ?  Is the rise of European anti-semitism a product of long lasting traditions or a by-product of Muslim immigration ?  I still have these questions.  The book does attempt to address these issues.  It does so by a selectively culling statements
column4: events
column5: and quotes.  Where a book of this nature would demand 100's of pages
column6: the author here feels that his cobbled collection of editorials can address these issues with limited research and less than 200 pages.  It is tragic that such a serious topic is handled
column7: so casually.  Like many people
column8: I fear a second Holocaust prompted by Iranian nuclear ambitions.  What does Schoenfeld think of this issue ?  He agrees that such a threat exists
column9: but sees fit to address it in only one paragraph.  What about a solution to the rise of anti-semitism ?  The only one I can find
column10: is the belief that a stable democratic Iraq will reduce the phenomena.  I don't want to get too political here
column11: but that's a pretty disquieting source of optimism.  There is something here
column12: but there's not quite enough.  I don't disagree with the author
column13: but I don't feel that throwing out a collection of individual opinions constitutes a serious analysis of a serious topic.

column1: Very simply
column2: this is not the best movie guide out there as other reviewers have stated.  While
column3: it does add a lot of new films released each year
column4: it does so at the expense of older films.  The reviewers have a tendancy to gush over these new releases and underrate or compleletly ignore films that truly have standed the test of time.   I don't want to get in a rant about specific film reviews but I think the reviewers do follow a certain pattern.  If the movie made lots of money it is most likely to be rated higher than so called "flops".  However
column5: an exception is made for films that are too violent
column6: too sexual
column7: or too dark
column8: even if they were succesful or developed a cult following because this is basically a family orientated movie guide.  Movies made in the last several years are usually rated higher than the ones that were made in the film industry's youth.  Many people's opinion will agree that today's films are more entertaining for today's audiences but I am of the opinion that there are film treasures to be found in all eras. In some cases the reviews of these older films are so vague that it makes me wonder if the reviewer ever saw the film that is being reviewed or are they just recycling and paraphrasing some old review.  The biggest weakness of this book is that it does not include a great many movies at all.  In comparison with the Blockbuster movie guide and Maltin's classic guide

column1: I know H. James is considered one of the "Greats" of American literature and I question my taste for hating most of his writing.  With few exceptions I think he is  a pretentious purveyor of obscurantism.  I read Wings of the Dove many years ago in the days when I would not allow myself to set aside books I did not enjoy.  I recently picked up a collection of his short stories and remembered why I disliked him so much.  Now in my old age I had no pangs of conscience when I happily closed the book before finishing it.  If more of the stories had been like Daisy Miller I would have proceeded further but unfortunately much of the writing reminded me of Wings.  I am currently seeking  relief from Henry's turgid prose by reading Hemingway.  I'd trade in a Henry  for an Ernie any day.  It's also difficult to like Mr. James' snobbish
column2: shallow and unsympathetic characters.  The more sympathetic ones were obscured by his heavy hand and my impatience with his style.

column1: I read this years ago for a class I was taking. It was awful
column2: but required.  At the same time I was working the night shift in a psychiatric hospital.  The book bears absolutely no resemblence to the real world of mental illness.   If you have to read this book for a course
column3: hopefully you will then move on to a more interesting and useful class.   If you want realism
column4: try Ken Kesey's "One flew over the Cookoo's nest".  Everyone I was working with at the state hospital read this book
column5: then the local college produced it. A lot of the patients were taken to see the play and they loved it. (This was before "patients" became "clients").  The movie gave me nightmares; I saw it after I left the hospital and it was too real.  The mental health field has of course changed considerably since the 70's and a lot of those people are now out on the streets talking to themselves.  Unfortunately Szasz is a classic theorist and this book will still continue to be read

column1: I truly wanted to like this book.  After years of avoidance I had just finished Moby Dick and found it not only more readable than I'd feared but downright enjoyable.  In addition I'd heard nothing but good things about this novel whose premise certainly intrigued me
column2: and like its predecessor it has one of the truly great opening lines in literature:  "Captain Ahab was neither my first husband nor my last."  Alas
column3: it was all down hill from there; overall this is one of the worst books I've ever forced myself to finish.  This came as quite a surprise because the author is no untalented hack.  Author of two other published novels and a short story collection
column4: director of a university level creative writing program
column5: long-term teacher of writing
column6: and holder of a Ph.D. in same
column7: all to considerable critical acclaim
column8: she should be correcting and grading (failing) garbage like this not producing it.  So what went wrong?  How did this novel end up so awful?  The answer is brick by brick and piece by piece.  There is no one great thing wrong with it but rather a lot of little things.  LENGTH: If "brevity is the soul of wit"
column9: this novel's witlessness is easily explained.  At 666 pages (interesting number that) this novel is about three times as long as it should have been.  It would seem that
column10: to some extent like Melville before her
column11: Naslund confused Length with Importance
column12: but Melville was a lot more skilled at padding than she is.  IMHO this desire to fill too many pages made many of the other problems worse by allowing Naslund both to go into unnecessary detail about things no one else cares about and to repeat herself to the point of self-parody.  Somewhere under the barnacle encrustations may be the finely lined hull of a short novel
column13: but this was a manuscript desperately in need of editing... with a meat axe or a chainsaw.  THE NAME DROPPING: One of the pleasures of any historical novel is the encounters between fictional characters and historical figures
column14: but if badly handled these encounters can un-suspend disbelief and downright offend.  They are badly handled here.  An almost uneducated hick from the backwoods of Kentucky encounters by chance a significant number of the thoughtful elites of mid-nineteenth century New England and those she doesn't utterly charm with her brilliance and erudition she gets the better of as in her unintentionally hilarious encounter with Naslund's peculiar imagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne.  One or two of these
column15: developed at greater length could have added to the verisimilitude.  As it is
column16: it is a Zelig or a Forrest Gump without the humor (or the self-awareness).  THE POLITICS: Even the most conservative readers would probably find the popular views of a majority of mid-nineteenth century New Englanders a bit disconcerting if espoused straight in a modern novel
column17: so a certain amount of modernizing would be appropriate just to reduce the cringing.  However
column18: Naslund takes this to the opposite extreme by having Una espouse the Politically Correct view on every single controversy of the day (and some that only exist in our significantly sillier day) from slavery to whaling
column19: from feminism to free love
column20: from homosexuality to sensitivity towards the differently abled
column21: all without consequence or even criticism.  This latter is the most offputting because to have actually championed such views back then would have taken considerable courage whatever one thinks of the ideas themselves.  Una espouses them with all the negative consequences that Naslund receives for espousing them today
column22: which is to say: none.  THE ANTI-CHRISTIAN BIGOTRY: There is nothing so very wrong with characters in a mid-nineteenth century novel exhibiting agnosticism or atheism as both views were gaining more and more credence at the time
column23: but it is downright silly to suggest that such views would have been widely accepted.  It is even sillier to portray Christianity as something confined exclusively to the foolish
column24: the bigoted
column25: the future apostate
column26: or the mentally ill.  It tells us more about the author than anything else that Una is openminded towards every religious and quasi-religious idea of the time EXCEPT Christianity.  THE FARFETCHED SCENARIOS: I sensed the novel was in trouble during the opening scene in which Una loses both her mother and her baby but manages to withstand this blow by making friends with a runaway slave with whom she has a quasi-lesbian encounter....  After this the novel goes into flashback and becomes unrealistic.  After her crazy Christian father threatens to kill her (a sentiment the reader will come to know and understand)
column27: Una is raised in a lighthouse by her ludicrously liberal-minded aunt and uncle
column28: encounters two young men who both fall in love with her
column29: disguises herself as a cabin boy and sails on the same whaler with them
column30: successfully avoids detection
column31: is sunk by a whale
column32: survives by committing cannibalism
column33: marries the surviving young man after he goes insane
column34: and is abandoned by him after he goes to live with the Indians
column35: leaving her free to "marry" Captain Ahab (Una never really "marries" anybody but of course nobody ever criticizes).  Things don't get more realistic in the second half
column36: which includes Una's clever and successful investment in the crazy newfangled idea of obtaining oil from the ground instead of from a whale.  Riiiight.  THE MARY SUE: However
column37: the absolute worst thing about this novel is the fact that it is a "Mary Sue" that peculiarity of fan fiction in which a laughably idealized and practically perfect in every way alter ego of the author fulfills some basic psychological need while inducing a combination of anger and nausea in the reader.  A more realistic main character might have saved it.  Una never learns anything from her life's too-many-to-be-believed experiences because she already knows everything.  She doesn't change because she is already perfect.  She doesn't have to deal with the criticism of others because she doesn't receive any
column38: and she doesn't have to beg the forgiveness of those she has wronged because they forgive her so easily and besides
column39: Una had her reasons (and they were very good ones you can be sure).  The only thing I can figure is that her publisher approved this book on concept alone WITHOUT anyone ever reading it.  I feel like I've just waded through the inept scribbling of a delusional teenage girl who insists on rereading Moby Dick in her bedroom... with the door locked.

column1: Recently I completed teaching a seven week series on the sacraments. As I prepared my studies and made a short list of resources that I wanted to make available to those studying with me
column2: I asked myself "Now
column3: regarding baptism
column4: what kind of book do I need?"   		What I needed was a single volume that constructs its case out of a close reading of the biblical data
column5: that interacts with well-known objections in a clear but polite manner
column6: and that sets forth the mainlines of covenant theology in such a way as to show how infant baptism properly belongs to that system and to the life of the Christian church. What I choose was The Case for Covenantal Baptism.   		Written by a number of respected pastors and professors serving in various Reformed and evangelical settings
column7: The Case for Covenantal Baptism does not break new ground
column8: but it does offer substantial discussions of key biblical passages (e.g. Mt.28:18-20; Ac.2:39; Rom.4:11-12; 6:3-6; Heb.8:11-12; Jer.31; et.al). Further
column9: it places the discussion of paedo-baptism (and the debate surrounding it) firmly within the covenantal context of Scripture. While some differences among the contributing authors are evident
column10: yet for the most part this volume is remarkably even and coherent. Certainly it does make a clear case for covenantal baptism as well as offering theological and pastoral insight on the place of children in the Old and New Testaments and in the congregation.  		Although there are now several good books on infant baptism available
column11: yet I believe this articulate and constructive volume will be of benefit to pastors desirous of instructing their congregations in the sacraments. It will also be of value to seminary graduates heading into the pastorate and to continuing seminary students as a supplement to lectures. Finally
column12: The Case for Covenantal Baptism should also prove helpful and therefore be appreciated by those studying this issue and endeavoring to make up their minds about the biblical validity of this precious practice.

column1: I certainly would not recommend this book to anyone as a first Kellerman's novel. There are too many medical jargons and terms as if Kellerman is trying to show off his medical knowledge. There are just too many unnecessary references to either the rarer or more serious and feared disorders unrelated to the story and thus causing a lot of side tracking which to me is a pure waste of time reading and boring to readers especially those with medical knowledge. It took me a long long time to finish this novel and thought of discarding it numerous times even when I was more than half way through the novel! This is especially so after having read the very exciting Robert Crais's "Demolition Angel" followed by Lee Child's "One Shot".  The story in this book are also full of loop holes and I cannot buy the idea of a Conspiracy Club using Jeremy to get to the killer and allowing more murders to take place while he was stressfully doing so. However
column2: I must admit that I did enjoy reading a couple of Kellerman's other novels "Murder Book" & "When the Bough Breaks" quite some time ago

column1: Strange Candy is a collection of 14 short stories by Laurell K. Hamilton
column2: author of the Anita Blake
column3: Vampire Hunter and Merry Gentry novels.  The first story in the book
column4: "Those Who Seek Forgiveness" is
column5: as Laurell puts it
column6: "the first time Anita ever walked on paper for me." I hate to say it

column8: the wit
column9: the vicious sense of humor
column10: the repressed sexuality
column11: are nowhere in evidence - because they didn't yet exist in the author's mind.  Many readers will be shocked to discover "Those Who Seek Forgiveness" was the template for much of Laurell's short novel Micah. I said good things about Micah upon its release. I would have been less impressed had I known how much of it was a retread. The basic plot of Anita being hired by a murderer to raise the zombie of their victim
column12: the zombie breaking free of Anita's control to attack their killer
column13: Anita flung through the air to crack her head on a gravestone
column14: being knocked unconscious
column15: waking up at the end of the story in a hospital bed after her client's death
column16: all were lifted from "Those Who Seek Forgiveness".  The rest of the stories are mostly forgettable
column17: about half-and-half not-very-fantastic fantasy and not-very-horrible horror. There's a reason Laurell K. Hamilton is not known as a great short story writer: she isn't. Overall her characters are cardboard
column18: she hasn't the gift of sketching a believable
column19: sympathetic personality in the few strokes allowed within a short story's limited word count. There's rarely a sense of real peril involved in the problems her characters face. The stories come across as unsatisfying
column20: by-the-numbers exercises in which "people" you don't care about go through the motions of adventures that don't involve.  One irritating thing about the stories in Strange Candy
column21: there seems to be no rhyme or reason to the order in which they're presented. For instance
column22: there are two stories starring Sidra Ironfist set in Laurell's Nightseer universe. But why the hell is Sidra's first-ever appearance presented **after** the follow-on story?  We're almost through the book before we hit a real winner

column24: after wading through so much dreck
column25: to suddenly hit one of the neatest
column26: most vicious little psychological horror pieces I've ever experienced. It's like reading the work of a completely different writer. If every story in Strange Candy was of the quality of "Here Be Dragons" this would be a 5 star collection.  "Winterkill" which is also set in the Nightseer world
column27: is
column28: surprisingly
column29: pretty darn good. Other than "Here Be Dragons" it's the only decent story in the collection
column30: in my opinion. I found myself liking and rooting for main character Jessa - which
column31: considering she's basically a killer-for-hire is a great accomplishment on the writer's part.  Strange Candy is bookended by two Anita Blake tales. It begins ith "Those Who Seek Forgiveness" and ends with "The Girl Who Was Infatuated With Death" which takes place within continuity just before the novel Narcissus in Chains. As with so many recent Laurell K. Hamilton tales
column32: "TGWWIWD" has a great set-up. Anita is hired to find a girl who is (a) dying of bone cancer and will in fact have her leg cut off in a few days
column33: (b) about to be "turned" by a vampire
column34: that very night
column35: mostly so she can avoid the mutilation and painful death by cancer awaiting her otherwise. Problem: she's underage to legally make that choice. If the vampire turns her
column36: he'll be up for execution. Does Anita "save" the girl from being turned - which legally is what she should do - knowing that by doing so she's condemning her to mutilation and
column37: in short order
column38: real death
column39: or should she let it happen
column40: knowing she's condemning the vampire? This presents Anita with a no-good-choices serious moral dilemma.  Unfortunately the great set-up soon gives way to zero forward momentum as the focus turns to - you guessed it - Anita's sex life. An over-emphasis on this one facet of Anita's life to the exclusion of plot has ruined every recent Anita Blake story
column41: and it's no exception here. Thus
column42: instead of bending all her efforts to finding the girl and the vampire in the few hours she has left
column43: instead Anita spends the time playing footsy with Jean-Claude in his office at Guilty Pleasures while the police and other vampires do the job for her. Even Jean-Claude comments
column44: "There was a time
column45: ma petite
column46: that you would have insisted on riding to the rescue yourself
column47: questioning the girl's friend
column48: and refusing to bring in the police at all." At which point I could not help but think
column49: "Yeah
column50: and wouldn't that be fun to read? There was a time this story would actually have been good."  Recommended for Anita Blake completists who absolutely need to own every word ever written about the character. Recommended for "Here Be Dragons" and "Winterkill". For myself this is a library rental

column1: The Russian nuclear powered
column2: missile carrying (SSBN) submarine K-219 was about 15 years old when it nearly triggered either WWIII or a 2nd Chernobyl.  In 1986
column3: with Chernobyl still in minds of the public
column4: and the Reagan/Gorbachev summit in Reykjavik imminent
column5: the navies of both sides of the cold war sail SSBN's off each other's shore.  Floating platforms loaded with numerous missiles - some with multiple warheads - these subs are almost as dangerous to their crews as they are to the enemy.  In the case of K-219
column6: the balance shifted firmly against the crew.  Poor design
column7: construction and shipyard maintenance had prematurely aged the sub launched only a few years earlier than the first 688-class American subs.  Near Bermuda
column8: K-219 was nearly sunk by a missile explosion caused by leaking seawater.  With one tube already deactivated because of seawater problems on a prior cruise
column9: this was not a new problem.  In this case however
column10: the explosion nearly sinks the then submerged boat
column11: then floods it with toxic and corrosive gas.  Problems increase when the ships two reactors suffer a loss-of-coolant accident and nearly meltdown.  Echoing the experience of K-19
column12: some brave crewmen sacrifice themselves to shut the reactors down.  Complications ensue when superiors in Moscow order the crew (once safely evacuated to a nearby freighter) to re-board the poisoned ship.  An American sub with a maverick commander adds to the danger when he runs his ship too near the stricken sub
column13: apparently ordered to keep K-219 from being recovered.  Eventually
column14: the ship will sink
column15: and Captain Britanov will have to return home and answer to his superiors for the loss of the sub.  The loss of K-219 is a fascinating story
column16: but unfortunately this book doesn't do it justice.  The cause of the book's numerous flaws is the author's determination to write it as if it were a novel
column17: in which the facts
column18: if not complete
column19: are still single-minded.  That is
column20: despite an extensive bibliography
column21: there's only one version of the account.  Rather than document possible disputes over what happened
column22: or why people act the way they did
column23: "Hostile waters" offers a single
column24: linear perspective
column25: one with easily identifiable heroes and villains (the political officer is singled out for unpopularity even before he grabs the first lifeboat off K-219 - since he does nothing throughout the story he's an easy target).  This is not only a monumental cheat
column26: but also robs the reader of critical facts - such as what really caused the ship to sink as it did; also the circumstances surrounding the apparently feckless captain of the American sub
column27: and whether any blame should attach to Britanov for not knowing of the leaking missile tube or the painful domestic situation of the officer directly responsible for monitoring it.  "Hostile Waters" reads like a novel - a very unrealistic one

column1: After book 4 the series begins to meander around.  Characters are constantly side-tracked into meaningless
column2: boring tasks.  The first 200-300 pages of this book are basically a re-hash of the previous books only excitement (Rand's capture and escape from the "bad witches") seen from different characters perspectives.  This is an example of what writing becomes when the author obviously has no idea of where the story is going
column3: and there obviously is little or no editing.  The author must being paid by the word count and not the content.  The story seems to get written into little boxes
column4: and has to be written back on track again and again.  I no longer have the patience to actually read each page.  I find myself skimming through to find some useful information or a single point of action.  The characters have also stalled out with Rand spending most of his time talking to him-self while the world goes to hell.  His big secret plan to quickly deal with one of the forsaken (started in the previous book) continues to drag on and on and on.....  This series had a good basic story.  Unfortunately you have to wade through crap to try and find it.  I'm beginning to wonder if the series will ever end

column1: Despite an interesting title and a beguiling title page
column2: I honestly found nothing exceptional about Robin McKinley's collection of four fairytales. Whether her stories are original or retold
column3: they are rather dull
column4: predictable
column5: and written with long-winded language that makes for sluggish reading. All are centred on the interactions between this world and that of Faerieland - or to be more specific
column6: the interactions between young princesses and the inhabitants of Faerieland. None of these girls are individuals
column7: instead they are cast straight from the princess stereotype and all the stories end on a slightly sickly-sweet note with each dilemma that the girls' face wrapped up in a nice little bow. Faerieland is not seen as a wild and elusive place
column8: but as a pretty sparkling land with none of the depth or hidden meaning that fairytales are meant to have. They are sweet
column9: pretty
column10: *pointless* tales have nothing of the ambiguity or beauty that they could.  In "The Stolen Princess"
column11: McKinley tells the tale of one of the last kingdoms that border the realm of Faery
column12: and the anxiety that the residents face concerning the possible stealing of their children. This happened to the Queen's twin sister Ellian
column13: and now the same thing has happened to happen to their only child Linadel. The King and Queen take it upon themselves to rescue their daughter
column14: whilst she herself awakens in the Faerie realm to greet its inhabitants. The pacing of the story is extremely slow
column15: the "love-at-first-sight" scenario is entirely unconvincing
column16: and the descriptions of Faerieland are unimaginative and flat - it sounds like quite a dull place actually.  "The Princess and the Frog" is a retelling of the princess who drops her golden ball and has it returned to her by a frog. Here
column17: the Princess Rana is saved from the malevolent power of an unwelcome suitor's necklace by a talking frog. The ending is utterly preposterous: the frog returns to his human form
column18: and challenges the suitor Aliyander - at this stage Rana runs out of the room
column19: down to the pond
column20: fills a flagon with its water and rushes back to dump the whole lot on Aliyander. Presumably
column21: since no other explanation is given
column22: we are meant to suppose that during this lengthy interlude of running and fetching water
column23: the two foes simply stood looking at each other
column24: since when Rana returns neither one of them has moved. Furthermore
column25: how Rana knows that the pond-water will destroy Aliyander is completely unexplained
column26: and therefore comes across as random and bizzare.  "The Hunting of the Hind" is possibly the only worthwhile read
column27: which tells of Princess Korah
column28: whose kingdom is plauged by the beauty of a golden hind
column29: the very sight of which drives men into madness. When this terrible affliction lands upon her beloved brother
column30: Korah herself goes out in search of the hind to learn its secrets. However
column31: this story too comes to an annoying ending: the hind is under a spell
column32: which can only be broken if a person goes to the wizard who placed the curse and asks him to remove it. But to prevent the wizard from using your inner emotions against you
column33: one must enter his presence completely devoid of any feelings. So Korah leaves her inner emotions in the keeping of the transformed hind (err
column34: how exactly?) and asks the wizard for her freedom. That's it. I was expecting some sort of twist
column35: some sort of test or trick that the young girl must go through
column36: but no - that's it. To top it off
column37: McKinley throws in a brother to the golden hind to act as love-interest for Korah - why must every Princess land herself a hubby in the course of her adventures? Can't she just have the adventure for its own sake?  Lastly is the longest story
column38: "The Twelve Dancing Princesses" which is told from the point of view of a middle-aged soldier
column39: and is made all the better for it - by this stage I was thoroughly tired of McKinley's flat princess-heroines. The soldier takes up the challenge of solving the mystery of the twelve princesses
column40: whose shoes appear each morning entirely worn out
column41: as if they have been dancing all the night long. If you have read this old fairytale
column42: then there is nothing here that will surprise you - McKinley tells the exact same story
column43: except she takes twice as long to do it. There is a slight shadow of intrigue with the appearance of an old woman who aids the soldier
column44: but it's not enough to warrant the energy I used in dragging myself through this story.  As you can see
column45: this is a rather harsh review
column46: and if you happen to be Robin McKinley reading this - no offence! McKinley is a gifted author
column47: and I have enjoyed many of her books
column48: but this collection just left me entirely unsatisfied. I've tried to give legitimate reasons as to why this is simply isn't a worthwhile book
column49: without simply ranting at it
column50: and the truth is that it just felt completely devoid of any real magic or passion.

column1: Three problems with this film:  1. PACING - The film's pacing doesn't vary.  It's very boring.  As a matter of fact
column2: this wouldn't be a problem if the film were much more tense (e.g.
column3: "Speed")
column4: however this film lacks the high-action intensity to pull off such a slow expository speed.    2. EFFECTS - Too many sequences of this film rely on color and light superimpositions
column5: and there is an overabundance of high-speed imaging.  The scene changes that employ erratic barrages of images desensitize the viewer from the thrilling "horror" scenes.  Furthermore
column6: they fail to make enough sequential sense of the film's plot to really mean much to the film as a greater whole.  The upshot: the film relies too heavily on the art of editing
column7: to the point where plot twists are no longer interesting.    3. TRIVIALITY - The plot's conclusion quails in the face of the "so what?" question.  The viewer is left with a sense of
column8: "I sat through the film for THAT?"  In light of points (1) and (2)
column9: this obnoxious bit is the icing on the cake.    Don't waste your life.  ALon

column1: The cover indicated unusual scenes on the golf course.  The other monthly pictures were rather ordinary
DRUMMING is Steve Reich's longest work
column2: two full discs of minimalist rhythms performed by an occasionally changing ensemble. This installment in Deutsche Grammophon's "Echo 20/21" series of contemporary music reissues provides a rare complete performance of the work with no cuts
column3: recorded in 1974. In the end
column4: I found "Drumming" to be minimalism at its worst.  During the late 1960s Steve Reich had worked in a studio for electronic music. In 1970 he visited Ghana
column5: and there found confirmation of his suspicion that acoustic instrumentation contained all the possibilities of music by itself. Stylistically "Drumming" is a continuation and final refinement of the phasing technique that Reich had been working with since 1965. This is a process in which "two or three identical instruments playing the same repeating melodic pattern gradually move out of synchronization with each other." Yet
column6: three new techniques are here. The first is that the timbre gradually changes while pitch and rhythm remain constant. The second is that the human voice is used to imitate the exact sound of the surrounding instruments in the ensemble. This has an effect similar to Ligeti's "Clocks and Clouds"). Since the glockenspiels are too high for the human voice to mimic
column7: whistling accompanies the lower registers of the instrument
column8: and a piccolo the higher. The third innovation is the process of substituting beats for rest or vice versa within a repetetive rhythmic cycle. Though there is development of the theme
column9: there is yet only one basic rhythmic pattern for entire two discs of the work.  The ensemble is a showcase of early 1970s avant-garde performers. Cornelius Cardew
column10: who went on to become England's first Maoist composer
column11: plays marimba's here. I think that a similar section of Cardew's work "The Great Learning" (also in "Echo 20/21") is much
column12: much more successful than "Drumming" and encourage all to check it out.  I admit it
column13: I think minimalism is the greatest disaster to befall contemporary music
column14: and has provided more charlatans than any other style. I prefer the zahlenmystik of Gubaidulina
column15: the frenetic business of Lindberg
column16: or even the academic dryness of the lab coat-wearing composer Boulez. Yet
column17: I can appreciate some works of Reich. The other Reich disc in the Echo 21/21
column18: with his "Variations for Winds
column19: Strings
column20: and Keyboards"
column21: "Music for Mallet Instruments
column22: Voices
column23: and Organ"
column24: and "Six Pianos" is quite enjoyable. "Drumming"
column25: on the other hand
column26: is so dull that I felt no compulsion to return to it except the curiosity to know if there was something in there after all. Yet
column27: after many listenings
column28: I find that the work is still without any captivating qualities. The development of the music seems to take longer than in any other minimalist work
column29: and two hours of music have a range so limited that you won't believe you just paid so much for this release.  I really cannot recommend this disc to anyone except those who
column30: like me
column31: are collecting all of the "Echo 20/21" series
column32: or those who want to fill holes in their Reich collection. I was greatly disappointed by "Drumming"

column7: so don't feel bad if you get left behind on this subject. This is a typical college text book and class. This book is just not a quality product

column1: In Let Freedom Ring
column2: Sean Hannity sends out the subliminal message that he and his writing are about truth
column3: justice
column4: and the American way. Just the title represents everything true and good about him and America. For his five-star reviewers his message reinforces their pre-conceived beliefs and Hannity's words are the validation of those beliefs.  If this was written by a ghost writer
column5: he should have withheld payment. If it wasn't written by a ghostwriter
column6: Hannity should have one for his next attempt at literary hyperbole.  The first chapter is written in a maudlin
column7: "those-were-the-good-old-days" wistfulness of his immigrant grandfather who he describes as an honest man of integrity
column8: and a believer in the American dream. But before you can say "Erin Go Braugh" he is talking about the courage of George W. Bush for standing up to terrorism. Exactly how G.W. does
column9: he doesn't elaborate. How he goes from grandfather to Dubbya is a bit of magic.  Hannity's next trick is to impugn Clinton and Gore as being soft on terrorism. His source for this is
column10: of all people
column11: Dick Morris who knew the Clintons and now works for the Fox Republican Advocacy Network. He quotes Morris who makes such vague statements as "It seemed they were afraid of talking about terrorism
column12: or they seemed to be indifferent to terrorism." These "Morris mind-reads" are conjectural
column13: but Hannity uses them
column14: which he does with impunity.  Let's take a closer look at Hannity's unimpeachable source for a moment. It was Dick Morris who quit the Clintons shortly after the second election. It was Morris who had a penchant for streetwalkers
column15: did some jail time
column16: and entered alcohol rehab. You'd think SH could find a better source if he expects freedom to ring!  But
column17: Hannity doesn't skip a beat. He points out how democrats such as Senators Kerry and Daschle voted against certain defense-spending bills. What he neglects to inform his readers are the reasons they did because of riders that were attached to the bills
column18: or the number of republicans who also voted against the same bills
column19: or the many defense bills that Kerry and Daschle did vote for. He never once advises his reader of the defense spending programs that were killed by Dick Cheney when he was Secretary of Defense. Such deception is called propaganda.  Propaganda is something that Hannity has no compunction using here. This he does in continuing to tell a tale that has long since been debunked. Namely
column20: it is the story of President Clinton being offered Osama bin Laden by the Sudanese government. Again
column21: it's what he doesn't say that misdirects the reader. Sudan made the offer in the hope of having the economic sanctions against them for slave-trading
column22: lifted. However
column23: the FBI determined that the Sudanese were playing us because they had neither the ability nor the intent of handing over bin Laden. The Sudanese also made the offer to Saudi Arabia
column24: but the Saudis had revoked bin Laden's citizenship
column25: and refused to take him.  Benjamin Franklin said "Statistics is a liar." Hannity uses charts for the same purpose. He shows how under Reagan
column26: the army bought over 500 tanks. Under Clinton
column27: the army bought none. This leads one to the assumption that Clinton did nothing for the services. He doesn't mention that the army buys tanks
column28: not presidents. He doesn't mention the army had all the tanks they needed for armored warfare against the Soviet Union that never came. He doesn't mention that the army began changing its warfare strategies which would include more transportable fighting vehicles.  Be grateful that Hannity cannot rewrite famous works of literature as he attempts to do with history. If he could
column29: instead of seeing a dead Captain Ahab being killed by the whale in "Moby Dick
column30: we might just see a grinning captain standing next to a tethered whale with the caption: I caught a fish this big!"  There's something very fishy about his facts
column31: his historical parallels which aren't parallel
column32: and what he chooses to tell you
column33: and what he chooses to leave out.  In this book
column34: he tells whale-sized whoppers!

 This is a sad effort and sadder still that these ideas were published. The fact that any publisher believes that readers of social history would be interested in such a twisted analysis of the nature of man/woman and the development of societies is indeed sad. McElvaine is a longtime self promoting boor stuck in a jerkwater academic environment with way too much time for idle pondering. His imagination worked overdrive to produce this piece of fantasy. I guess if any of us had enough time on our hands we too could construct elaborate theories on the 'nature of things' and put enough of a self-loathing feminist slant on it to attract a fringe readership. That's what happened here. Don't waste your time. A disturbing aspect to this is that he's teaching the next generation of leaders

 The authors set out on what *appeared* to be an interesting project. How could philosophy be reconstructed in order to be made compatible with the results" of second-generation cognitive science? Yet Philosophy is not fundamentally an empirical enterprise. Empirical results
column5: while interesting
column6: do not often help to answer philosophical questions. Knowing that we conceptualize time as moving does little to tell us whether the A theory or the B theory of time is true. One of them must be
column7: for they are mutually exclusive alternatives. Is space-time kind of substance
column8: or is it merely a system of relations? Are propositions about the future true *now*? Nothing in this book will give you an inkling. The authors seem confused between a thing and and our conceptualization of it
column9: and the majority of this book just seems like a long ad hominem circumstantial. Even if everyone who ever believed in God was absolutely insane
column10: that would do nothing to settle the *philosophical* issue of whether or not God actually exists. The fact that we conceptualize time spatially tells us nothing about whether or not time is really like space. It might be
column11: and it might not be
column12: the fact that we conceptualize it thus is entirely irrelevant to the issue. The problem lies in their calling these cognitive mechanisms "metaphors"
column13: since calling them such presupposes that they cannot be literally true. Since the authors treat them as metaphors
column14: they win by default
column15: and there's simply no argument to be had. For example
column16: they call "time is space" a metaphor. But is it really? The past does not seem to be co-located with the future. They do not interpenetrate each other
column17: and this presupposes that they are indeed "separated" some quasi-spatial sense. It would have been better if the authors examine these "metaphors" as they went along to decide whether they were true or false
column18: instead of postulating a priori that all conceptualizations must be nonliteral. For a whopping 600 pages the content is remarkably sparse. Their shallow analysis of philosophical theories is more likely to inspire laughter than serious reconsideration. Their theory of truth is also very deficient. If whatever is true is true "according to an understanding" how is it that anything ever turns out to be false? Suppose I have two patches of color that are almost exactly the same shade of red
column19: but not quite. Let's call them red #96 and red #97. Suppose further that they look indistinguishable. Then I propose to you that the two patches are the same shade. You look at them and (mis)percieve that they are the same shade. So the proposition is true "according to your understanding". But it is in fact false. Truth fundamentally involves a relation between the asserting mind and the fact asserted
column20: and all the cognitive science in the world cannot change that. I give this wasted exercise two stars
