column1: The format of this book is interesting -- a collection of essays by people who might have nothing else in common besides being in this book.  In that
column2: you read about a diverse group of topics by people who hold diverse opinions.  Unfortunately
column3: they also have a diversity of credibility.  I found some lapses in essays on topics I know a bit about
column4: so it made me wonder what lapses there were in essays on topics I knew little about.  The result was I found it hard to fully believe anything in the book.  For example
column5: an essay by Arianna Huffington on how evil drug companies are and how they're in cahoots with FDA to get their drugs approved was laughable.  She cited no references to back up her assertions.  FDA analyzes the data submitted and only then sees if the conclusion they come up with on their own matches the conclusion of the company.  They cannot be pushed around by anyone.  And while it's true that some drugs that have been marketed have later been recalled for safety issues
column6: it's awfully hard to identify rare adverse effects in the limited numbers of patients that go through clinical trials.  Much later in the book
column7: the editor has a short essay on a compound that he claims cures cancer.  His evidence is based on test-tube assays and some anecdotal data in animals.  Oh
column8: and it's a natural herbal product used in Chinese medicine for centuries.  His gripe?  That FDA (the same one so easily pushed around
column9: according to Ms Huffington) won't let sellers of this herb put the anti-cancer claim on the label.  Well
column10: FDA likes to see well-controlled
column11: prospective trials that demonstrate a drug (or substance) is safe and effective.  They don't accept the "a billion Chinese people can't be wrong" argument
column12: unfortunately.  They also need to inspect your manufacturing plant and to see your methods of producing the herb so that they can ensure the product is consistent.  If a company doesn't want to go through that cost and effort for an herb they can't patent
column13: well
column14: that's their decision
column15: but FDA can't let them make a claim they haven't proven.  And a final example is the essay on veganism.  The author is clearly very passionate about living a life free of animal products or exploitation of animals in any other way.  However
column16: his argument might have been more compelling if the literature he cited were from sources other than animal rights writings.  Furthermore
column17: he makes a couple of errors:  he claims that humans cannot manufacture vitamin D (we do
column18: in sunlight
column19: of course)
column20: and he neglects to mention the problem of vitamin B12
column21: stating that we can get all we need from plant material.  There is no vitamin B12 in plants at all
column22: so vegans need to get it from somewhere.  Most supplements come from an animal source
column23: so unless vegans eat lots of yeast extract
column24: they're kind of stuck.  Nonetheless
column25: the book does provide a lot of viewpoints and information you would certainly not read in the newspaper or hear on the nightly news.  So read it
column26: but remain connected to your inner skeptic

column1: This biography of General Winfield Scott is lacking from a number of perspectives.   First
column2: there is a total lack of military analysis - the author merely states what Scott did but never in much depth and without an assessment of his strategy or tactical abilities.  We never learn how Scott evolved from a lawyer into a soldier - what was his military education
column3: how did he evolve as a soldier over a 40 year career. How did he view new technologies like railroads and rifled artillery?  Second
column4: Scott appears as a cardboard character here with little or no personal depth.  What were his views on subjects such as slavery
column5: tariffs
column6: the Indians? His family relations are virtually ignored - why did his wife spend so much time in Europe?  Instead
column7: the author spends far too much time on Scott's political ambitions and his intra-service rivalries and bickering.  This is not what he is remembered for and should not be the primary focus for a military biography.  Scott was probably one of the best generals the United States has ever produced
column8: particularly in light of the superb Mexico City campaign
column9: and his generalship should be center stage in a biography
column10: not low-level barracks intrigue.  Finally
column11: the notion that Scott was the agent of manifest destiny is unsupported; he was a dutiful soldier
column12: not an imperialist. Maps were inadequate to follow Scott's battles

column1: Please forgive me

Even those with the best intentions often lead people astray in their zeal and ambition for what they perceive to be "spiritual" or "selfless" longings. The author demonstrates in the introduction a profound disrespect
column4: even for those who teach her
column5: that goes beyond being a productive iconoclast. She also is
column6: at least indirectly
column7: sexist. If we replace the gender in even most of her other book titles
column8: for example
column9: rendering them: "A Man's I Ching" "The Man's Spirituality Book" "All Men are Healers: A Comprehensive Guide to Natural Healing" I think we could observe a pattern developing
column10: as if a guide to natural healing could be comprehensive by focusing on only one gender. Still
column11: if a man tried to get away with that
column12: he would be considered a bigot
column13: and rightly so
column14: but I wonder why not a woman. Still
column15: it doesn't end here. Her innacuracies in regard to history are further disuading. She calls Buddha "the great savior of India
column16: which is quite a statement, something I am not familiar with, although I have been studying and/or practicing both Buddhism and Hinduism in both school and on my own for over ten years. She says that many Christian parables were directly taken from Buddhism, something she offers no evidence for. She also says that Shiva, one of the three fundamental gods of Hinduism, whose very symbol is the phallus, began as a woman- again presented as fact but without any supporting evidence. All in all, as I read, these things and others developed a mistrust of what else she may be attempting to teach.  As per the blogs on the back of her book, I do not believe that there is a difference between male/female sprituality. Spirit is not defined by such things, and it seems to me to represent a profound mistrust and misundrstanding of life's balance. Feminism is as empty as Masculinism." Again
column17: "feminist metaphysics" is another term that seems loaded with ignorance. Perhaps her Reiki portions are good
column18: but analagously I would not take the chance to learn Algebra from a person who can't get their basic arithmitic down
column19: especially when it seems like she alienates herself from the very people who taught her Reiki. Sadly
column20: I heartily do NOT recomend this book or this author

 I would like to start by saying that I was in the 101st airborne unit and assigned to the 2/502 strike force in Vietnam during the time which Manny Garcia is talking about in his so called book, I have talked with a lot of men that served with s during that time in the 3rd plt, and none of can recall a Manny Garcia. I can say that I am happy to say that he didn't include me in his book but he talked about an ambush where Boaz was killed and how he was sith him and how he watched his body being airlifted out on a chopper in a body bad and I can tell you from first hand that is no even close to the truth, I was a machine gunner during that time and Boaz was my A-gunner and a RPG rocket came in and got Boaz, my ammo bearer and myself and Boaz did not die in the field he hung on for three days and died on a hosiptal ship, and I was with him when we were air lifted out of the field, Garcia discraced a lot of good men that were my friends and I would like to have the chance to meet him and have im provide to me the proof he has for the book. I'm sure that won't happen but I can prove what I have said and would be more then happy to do so. What Garcia failed to talk about were the men that recieved the C M H and the one POW that we had. He talked about a parachute jump he made and he he did he did it alone because we did not make any combat jumps while I was there in 67-68. I hope the readers of this book would do the same to the book as he claims to have done with his metals and dumps themn in his yard. This ends my opinion of this book. Strike force all the way

 I have been reading James Patterson's books since the first Alex Cross came out. I thought the first 3 or 4 Cross books were brilliant but since then I feel the standard has dropped gradually to where we reach London Bridges.  This book has a solid storyline that needed fleshing out but I think the author was in too much of a rush to get the book on the shelves to worry about the story.  Let me get this right - Alex's family are taken hostage in the final few pages of the book, we get a couple of pages devoted to Cross' work and then the family is returned. There was no discussion on the anguish Alex was facing, nothing on the fear that the family was facing, nothing written about this at all! It would have been better to have taken them at the start of the book and have the book devoted to the fear that Alex was facing and his determination to catch the Wolf and get his family back.  If Alex was so dedicated to catching the Wolf, why was he taking so many time-outs throughout the book to visit little Alex, have dinner with his numerous friends etc?  Most disappointing, Mr Patterson 
 This is just a watered down version, by replacing the colorful language they have also taken away part of the beauty of the story.  I wish I had not wasted my money on this version

If you've never read any well written and insightful books on technology adoption (such as Lewis Mumford's "Technics and Civilization") then perhaps parts of "The Change Function" may appear profound.  However if you had
column2: then this text will find you wishing you had spent your time and money elsewhere.    People won't use technology that's hard to use? Profound.  People only learn a new way to drive to work when the old route is under construction? Brilliant.  Coburn goes way out on a limb to predict what technology will succeed...are you ready? Flat screen technology and Blackberries (mobile enterprise email). The man is a psychic.   On top of the lack of anything remotely fresh in this book

 The thesis of this book is that the economic disparities between the US, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Haiti result from the superiority of WASP  culture.  The study of the relationship between culture and progress has a  long history dating back to Max Weber.  This book offers nothing new except  a harsher edge that gives it a stench of white-supremacy.  Harrison is  clearly aware of the potential for charges of racism.  He makes extensive  use of quotes from blacks and Hispanics to make points that would be  offensive coming from a white person.  This is reminiscent of the 2000  reform party's black vice presidential candidate whose job it is to state  that Pat Buchanan is not a racist, not an anti-Semite, and not a homophobe.    Harrison's book purports to be a book on development, rather than a  justification for the disparities of wealth between the first and third  worlds.  Indeed, there are reasonable policy proposals in this book, as  well as a decent refutation of dependency theory.  However, there is  nothing really new here.  Economists almost universally rejected dependency  theory long before Underdevelopment is a State of Mind" was  first published.  Anyone even vaguely familiar with the development  literature will come away with nothing more than the simplistic argument  that poor people deserve to be poor because of their inferior culture.    The book gives no hint as to the fundamental causes of cultural  differences.    Clearly culture affects economic progress.  However
column18: it is  equally clear that economics affects culture.  The U.S. has a culture  conducive to capitalist growth in no small part because it is a wealthy  capitalist nation.  Any writer sincerely concerned with improving the  welfare of poor people should look favorable upon immigration and cultural  exchanges.  With the fed raising interest rates to choke off US growth and  prevent labor shortages
column19: the U.S. can absorb vastly increased levels of  immigration.  The success of immigrants from very poor countries makes it  clear that it is the institutional and cultural restrictions of poor  countries that make them poor.  They do not bring their supposed  "cultural inferiority" with them.  The fact that Harrison's book  contains diatribes against immigration shows that his concern is with  relieving his own guilt about living better than 90% of humanity rather  than improving the lives of the bottom 90%

Gay marriage probably won't weak the instution of marriage as a whole--it is on shaky legs as it is--but it certainly won't help it.  The state regulates marriage as it is--we are NOT free to marry whomever we want
column16: and just because we might want to badly
column17: that doesn't make it our right.  It is government's job to protect the interests of its citizens
column18: and clearly citizens feel they have a very strong interest in NOT redefining marriage.  And in fact
column19: gays do have the same rights as the rest of us
column20: contrary to what Mr. Rauch suggests.  Gays are free to marry a member of the opposite sex
column21: within the boundaries set by law.  That they don't want to is hardly society's fault
column22: and hardly a reason to change a fundamental social institution
column23: just to satisfy their desires.  His arguments that gay marriage is not a slippery slope remain unconvincing.  If objective values like tradition are so easily discarded to accomodate a small minority of malcontents
column24: then what logical reasons can there be not to accomodate other malcontents? Does this mean that we can realistically expect people to petition to marry their dogs?  Of course not.  But is there really a compelling argument
column25: then
column26: for continuing to outlaw polygamy?  No.  I agree with Rauch regarding leaving the argument to legislators rather than the judiciary.  Most Americans despise the idea of having a judiciary shove its values down our throats
column27: and this more than anything is probably what has given traction to the anti's position.  As a matter of strategy
column28: it's bad for gays; as a matter of policy
column29: it's bad for America.

column1: This book really has annoyed me. I knew nothing about using color in oil paintings
column2: and I still know nothing after reading it: 1) The book is basically a series of pictures of this artist's paintings (one or two per page)
column3: with really little comments near them. The pages are really empty: small pictures with little text. 2) Sometimes the author speaks about techniques (i.e. direct or indirect painting) and after reading the text I still don't understand what is she talking about.  3) There are also a lot of trivial explanations (like that of primary

column5: etc.) that it seems a joke dedicating a lot of space to them. 4) The paintings are almost all beautiful

column7: and I did it. I like the result because it reflects the emotions I had when I was painting. You must do what you find right". Do I have to extract a knowledge from that?  After reading the book I thought the author made an effort to avoid good explanations. Perhaps this book is not intended for beginners like me

column1: You would do better to actually use the money spent on this book and buy a drink on your next cruise.  Horror of horrors
column2: the cruise ship industry is out to make money!!!  Shocking facts such as these as well as those that pay for premium suites get extra benefits and perks (shocking) can all be learned from this book.  The author did a wonderful job of investigative research by basing most of his facts by talking to a disgruntled waiter over dinner.  Thirty cruises is not what I would call extensive experience in the cruise ship industry.  One cruise ship had a problem with its' air conditioner so the author assumes that ALL cruise ships have a problem with air conditioning (or they just turn it off to save money).  This book is a waste of time and money and I will continue to cruise despite his efforts

column1: I was pleased to see a new "supersized" history of WWII box set come to DVD
column2: and being a superfan of this subject bought it.  I wasn't expecting a lot of new footage but I thought perhaps a new perspective would be refreshing. column3: and this box set is built entirely on these old reels.    Patrick O'Neal's voice drones on like the engines of a tired old bomber on a long run to the heart of Germany. Literally a couple of minutes!    A far better choice would be the "BBC History of World War II"

column1: I picked this book up because I was intrigued by the title.  Unfortunately
column2: it only took me seconds to see that the author had a very specific ideology that was ignoring other psychological and historical viewpoints.   For example
column3: the author points out that "adults are on time" and that being late is an "act of passive aggressiveness."  While this can be true many times
column4: it is certainly not true all the time.  Anyone who knows the Jungian based Myers-Briggs personality test will know that "perceivers" are notoriously late because they get easily distracted while "judgers" are frequently early for every appointment.  But in the author's world
column5: only the "J" personality type is "mature."  Another statement the author makes
column6: on the very same page
column7: is that being adult means "raising your own children."  Sounds fair on its face.  However
column8: it ignores historical and economic facts.  The nuclear family of two parents and children is a 20th century creation.  In the past
column9: societies had extended families that were heavily involved in the rearing of the children while parents worked.  This is still true in many societies even today.  So how does this become a definition of maturity across the board?  I don't get it.  Obviously
column10: people shouldn't just have children willy-nilly and ignore their needs.  But the author's perspective is pretty much B&W.  Their is no gray.  (IMO
column11: this is in itself a statement of immaturity.)  The whole thing just smacks of a certain political mindset.  My advice: Take the Myers-Briggs test
column12: find out what you are
column13: figure out what parts of your personality need some work.  This is a far better solution than having this author spoon feed you her personal views

column1: My thoughts about this book can be summed up by a quote by Lanfear herself:  "you don't use one tenth of your potential".  The most frustrating element of this book (and the series as a whole
column2: for that matter) is the wasted potential.  The world of this series was so vividly realized and the plot was complex and engaging.  Now
column3: it is difficult not to sit back and wonder where exactly Jordan went off track.  Most other reviewers commented on the fact that all the characters did not "miraculously" end up in the same place for the last battle.  Personally
column4: I found it very disapointing.  Three of the four plot lines are resolved satisfactorally (even the Nynaeve/Elaine one...though I will admit it wrapped up too neatly and had me hoping at the end that the Black Ajah would come back at the last minute and wipe the self satisfied smile off Nynaeve's face).  Even so
column5: I was left wondering whether the weeks I'd spent reading this book were worth it.    What this book lacked most was direction.  It was very much a filler book for the characters/readers to take a breather in between major plot movements (at least I think that was what the original idea was).  Readers can debate about whether the book was a success or not until they turn blue in the face (as I know they will) but for me
column6: the book (and the series a sa whole) has fallen very flat

column1: This book is important for the historian who wishes to get a glimpse into the workings of the mind of an important figure in American Revolutionary history
column2: but it doesn't stand on its own. It is written almost entirely as a response to Edmund Burke's "Reflections on the Revolution in France"
column3: so I would not recommend reading this one until and unless one has read that one. Otherwise
column4: it is impossible to judge the fairness of the rebuttals of Burke's points
column5: as one only sees them through Paine's perspective
column6: and Paine is far from a fair and impartial debater; he misses no opportunity to belittle his opponent's arguments
column7: and even his opponent himself. I would not be at all surprised to discover that he gives an inaccurate picture of what Burke had to say
column8: particularly given that history speaks rather better of Burke's misgivings than of Paine's panegyrics. Both books were written before the Reign of Terror that resulted from the revolution in 1793; the second part of this book came out in early 1792. Also
column9: history shows us just how silly some of Paine's claims for a Republican
column10: representative government are: 200+ years of representative government in the US have hardly banished wars
column11: or the high taxes associated with them
column12: even though the world as a whole is far more democratic than it was at his time. He makes some good points
column13: and certainly it is hard to stand up against him in favor of hereditary monarchy
column14: but it is apparent that he failed to see that not ALL "democratic" movements were necessarily benificent
column15: even if it would be hard to have much sympathy for the autocratic regime that they overthrow

column1: This book seeks to look at American cultural patterns within a cross-cultural perspective. A number of cultural stereotypes are compared with the American stereotype
column2: particularly Japan. I say "cultural stereotypes" because this is what is primarily used. At times
column3: I have to disagree completely with the authors' interpretation of the meaning behind the actions of the cross-cultural experience. For example they give some examples of difficulties the author(s) had in Japan and then they explain why this occurred
column4: always giving the benefit of the doubt to the Japanese culture. However
column5: if that same action would be seen as an insult by a Japanese person I really see no reason for the authors to explain it away using a Japanese cultural value. In other words
column6: they fail to critically analyse different cultures either from within or from an American perspective. The end result is that you are to assume that other cultures always treat people with respect and it is only an American-centric view that would think otherwise. I am not American and can claim something of a dispassionate view on the subject.  At first glance this book appears to be a useful
column7: quick read for those going overseas but in reality it is a tough slog through some unanalysed stereotypes. This book fails to get past surface meanings to the deeper reality of the cross-cultures with which it contrasts American culture

column1: I was scouting around for a new British crime series to start and heard good things about Peter Robinson. So
column2: when I came across this second in the Inspector Banks series
column3: it seemed like fate was telling me to dive in. However
column4: I and my wife both found it a severely disappointing
column5: utterly unimpressive procedural. I can only surmise the series gets better over subsequent volumes
column6: because this is utterly average stuff.  Inspector Banks has recently relocated form London to sleepy rural Yorkshire and is still getting a feel for the lay of the land (following his first case in Gallows View). One day a retired historian turns up dead in a field near the village of Helmthorpe
column7: leaving Banks with an old-fashioned whodunit. Pretty quickly
column8: the stable of suspects is established: his widow (who inherits a nice legacy)
column9: his old friend and publisher
column10: his mystery-writing drinking pal
column11: his local GP and drinking pal
column12: a local entrepreneur developer drinking pal
column13: or the local folk singer he may have had a fling with a decade ago?   Like a latter-day Miss Marple
column14: Banks and his plod underlings go back and forth from house to house
column15: interviewing suspects and trying to tease a semblance of motive and opportunity from their statements. Of course
column16: like the old-fashioned constructions of Christie
column17: we are left with lots of semi-plausible motives and seemingly few opportunities. Banks is convinced the answer lies in a fateful summer ten years ago. Meanwhile
column18: a local teenage girl brags about seeing something the night of the murder
column19: placing herself in danger. Will Banks be able to get to the bottom of things before the killer strikes again?!?!?   It's all pretty bland stuff
column20: and gimmick by which the murderer masks themselves is a bit of a groaner. The clues dovetail nicely
column21: and Robinson's done a capable job of constructing a puzzler
column22: but the story and characters are instantly forgettable. The writing is utterly without style or distinction and the Yorkshire setting never really came alive for me. It seemed a kind of generic green and pastoral land with insular people and cure stone cottages. All in all
column23: very little to recommend here.

When you have lost weight
column2: it's a very natural thing for others to be curious about how you lost your weight and kept it off. Whenever they have heard me tell my story
column3: read my blog or book
column4: or found out that I did it on the low-carb lifestyle
column5: one question invariably has come up from time to time:   "What do you think about this low-carb diet where you can eat whatever you want for one-hour per day?"  My initial reaction to these people was usually something along the lines of this:  "That's absolutely crazy! There's no way you could ever lose weight and keep it off using this method."  I did the Atkins diet and honestly have not stayed on top of all the bazillion other low-carb diets out there. But there was something very odd about this plan that it made me look around to find out more about it.  Little did I know there was an actual book out there about this very diet so many people had been telling me about. It's called The Carbohydrate Addict's Diet and it was written by a husband/wife team Drs. Richard and Rachael Heller.  The CAD diet
column6: as it is referred to
column7: makes the claim (and I agree with it) that many people are addicted to carbohydrates and need to be weaned off from depending on them for sustenance. Just like a drug addict gets small concentrated doses of their preferred drug daily so they can eventually get by with less and less
column8: that same concept is what goes into the CAD diet.  If people think the Atkins diet is restrictive
column9: then check out what you have to do on the CAD diet:  BREAKFAST: ZERO-carb meal consisting of protein and fat. LUNCH: ZERO-carb meal consisting of protein and fat.  You are NOT allowed to eat any bread
column10: fruit
column11: milk
column12: juice
column13: and most starchy vegetables. Absolutely NO snacking whatsoever except for black coffee or diet soda. You cannot use artificial sweeteners either.  Sound appealing
column14: anyone? Hmmm? I suppose if that's all there was to this diet
column15: then NOBODY would do it. But there is one more key aspect of the CAD diet that you probably will be interested in.   DINNER: Eat equal amounts of protein
column16: vegetables and dessert of whatever you want to eat in whatever amount
column17: but it must be eaten in a one-hour time frame. You can even enjoy a beer or glass of wine with your "reward" meal.  How's that for incentive? You basically starve all day long just so you can get to those sixty minutes at the end of your day where you can say hello to the buffet line! Who wouldn't enjoy a diet that lets you do THAT?!  Well
column18: I'm still very skeptical about any lifestyle change that encourages you to eat the very foods that got you overweight or obese to begin with on a DAILY basis. I caught a lot of flack from my fellow low-carbers about my controversial "planned splurge" meal every 6-8 weeks during my weight loss. However
column19: the Hellers give you a DAILY planned splurge!!! What's up with that?  We can blame this on Dr. Rachael
column20: who stumbled upon this way of eating when she weighed 268 pounds after being on diet after diet. She became a psychologist to learn more about why people overeat (ostensibly to help herself in the process
column21: too). She had skipped breakfast and lunch on a particular day she was fasting for a blood test and then
column22: like most of us would
column23: ate to her heart's content whatever she wanted for supper. The next morning she noticed she had dropped 2 pounds.  Thinking something must have gone wrong with her scale
column24: she tried it again the next day
column25: skipping breakfast and lunch and then eating a gargantuan dinner and once again
column26: she lost another pound. She played around with what would eventually become The Carbohydrate Addict's Diet and went on to lose 150 pounds which she has kept off to this day.  The frequency of eating carbohydrates is the key behind the CAD diet. The Hellers believe that anyone who consumes ANY amount of carbohydrates during the day will set off all the bells and whistles in your body that you are hungry faster than if you avoided them altogether. They say that eating carbs throughout the day is like giving lots of small doses of cocaine to a cocaine addict. It will make them crave their poison even more!  That's why you basically avoid eating carbs on the CAD diet until the end of the day. This process of getting over carbohydrate addiction is a tricky one
column27: and the Hellers think they have found a solid plan for making it work for lasting weight loss in people.  I still can't get around the fact that you don't change the poor eating habits of the people who have packed on the pounds. Sure
column28: they basically starve themselves throughout the day before they eat their one BIG meal each day
column29: but how is that stimulating the metabolism and preventing the biggest obstacle to weight loss success -- HUNGER!  There's no way I could do the CAD diet because I enjoy eating every 2-3 hours to keep my digestive process constantly in motion. I truly believe this is one of the things that has helped me lose the weight and keep it off. Since you cannot snack or use artificial sweeteners on the CAD diet
column30: it would literally drive me insane even if there was that "reward" meal at the end of the day!  Wanna take a test to see if you are a carb addict? Click here to take the 10-question Carbohydrate Addict's Test. I scored a 2
column31: which means "You do not appear to be carbohydrate addicted." No kidding
column32: ya think?  Dr. Jonny Bowden
column33: author of Living The Low-Carb Life
column34: examined the CAD diet and said the diet uses some fuzzy science to make their points about why their plan works.  "While it seems pretty clear that there are both insulin and serotonin abnormalities in the obese
column35: it's not at all clear that high levels of insulin depress levels of serotonin
column36: as the Hellers hypothesize--in fact
column37: the majority of the evidence points to the opposite response."  Furthermore
column38: Dr. Bowden said he is concerned about the lack of attention on exercise as part of their weight loss program
column39: stating "it's vital to both maintaining weight and to raising the metabolic rate."  While The Carbohydrate Addict's Diet has worked for a lot of people and I always tell people to do what works for them to lose weight and keep it off
column40: I still have my reservations about this program. I think I'll pass on carb-loading my body for one hour a day

column2: informative
column3: and entertaining
column4: entitling this work Introducing Semiotics is a misnomer.  This work does not serve well for someone hoping to gain an introduction to semiotics which will provide a basic framework to build on.  Though the author does introduce us to key figures in the development of semiotics and gives the reader some idea of the relationships between them - a useful list for further study - the main theme is not coherently presented.  The book reads much more like a very loosely ordered collection of snippets from lecture notes or casual discourses between semioticians planning on writing a book.  Topics are interleaved and skipped between in at best a partially constructive manner.  Often ideas are introduced in a way that seems like we're joining their discussion midway through.  The level of technical jargon is high and the writing style showcase's the author's extensive vocabulary without an equal capacity to bring the terms and ideas into a simpler
column5: working summary with straightforward examples. And many of the examples that are included tend to obscure than clarify the topic.  The illustrations are interesting and give the page layout a welcoming feeling which the text unfortunately does not support.  I would look for another book if you want a useful introduction to semiotics

column1: Tao Teh Ching is a monumental work.  Unlike other religious texts
column2: the Tao Teh Ching is barely 5000 letters spread over 81 single-page poetic passages.  You can probably read thru it in a couple hours or less.  But for the serious reader
column3: it can take a lifetime of study and contemplation.  In ancient times
column4: scholars in China and Korea really did spend a lifetime on this one text
column5: not only sudying
column6: but transcribing it
column7: discussing it
column8: and abiding by its tenets in their daily lives.  I've myself pored over it many times in Chinese
column9: Korean and now English
column10: and every time I read it I cannot but be amazed by the wisdom of Lao Tse (or
column11: as some allege
column12: the group of people who contributed to this text).  The problem with English
column13: or I suppose any language not associated with Chinese
column14: is that it is almost impossible to translate Tao Teh Ching with sufficient coherency.  Chinese words are each and all very efficient
column15: in that virtually every single "letter" is replete with meaning.  Therefore
column16: whereas the Chinese may use 10 words to describe something
column17: English might require 10 times that words to adequately translate the meaning.  For example
column18: in the second passage
column19: third stanza
column20: the translated text says
column21: "therefore
column22: the Sage manages his affairs without Ado."  What does "without Ado" mean?  In chinese this is stated in two letters as "Mu Wi" - non-action.  It does not mean to sit back and not participate or instigate any activity.  Rather
column23: "Mu Wi" means doing things in a very natural
column24: spontaneous way that is not forced
column25: does not create conflict and has no secular motives.  As there are no secular motives behind the action
column26: it is as if the Sage does not "act" in the way other poeple act.  His actions are like breathing
column27: and almsot imperceptible; thus it is as if he does not act.  Concepts like "Mu Wi" and "Mu Ji" - non-knowledge - abound in Tao Teh Ching.  These cannot simply be translated away with a couple english words.  In short
column28: a Tao Teh Ching ranslation requires pages and pages of footnotes to accurately reflect the rich meaning behind every passage.  Moreover
column29: many passages can be read in more than one way.  In fact
column30: different translations sometimes say radically different things about the same passage precisely because of this ambiguity.  Any serious translation of Tao Teh Ching should point these out.  Tao Teh Ching is very concise
column31: and written in a poetic style.  But unless you are versed in ancient Chinese language and tomes
column32: you should really consult the literally thousands of guides that scholars wrote over the years to help you read thru the text.  Tao Teh Ching is not some kind of Buddhist sutra that you can just recite over and over without knowing what it means.  It is deeply profound and rich with hidden subtexts.  In China and Korea many of these guides - some of them more than a thousand years old - still survive.  I've yet to find an enligsh guide.  But I am sure they exist.  PLease find them; refrain from reading the translation by itself
column33: for most times all you will see are a jumble of meaningless words

column1: At least
column2: that seems to be the consensus among the people I know who really enjoy the paranormals. I'm surprised Roc billed  it as a fantasy.  To me
column3: "Claimed by Shadow" does not stand up to Chance's first novel.   Success is hard to follow.  The singer Joni Mitchell once said
column4: "No one ever told Van Gogh to paint Starry Night again
column5: but that's not necessarily true.  When an audience comes to expect a certain style from an artist, they're disappointed when the creator doesn't deliver.    In that vein of thought, a second novel should be very much like the first.  Wooddavis' review stating that the novels are running in place is spot on thematically.  Both novels have the same plotline with some variation.   The problem is, in my opinion, the second novel was not quite up to the standard of the first.  Most writing instructors and editors will advise newbie writers not to use flash-forwards and flash-backs at the beginnings of their careers.  While these devices are very useful and evocative, they can often lose the reader.  While Cassie's time-shift capability was an interesting new development, Chance did not handle these episodes with the same finesse that author C. E. Murphy uses in her Walker Papers series when Joanne goes vision-questing.  The time-shifting skill is definitely an interesting talent in conjunction with clairovoyance.  Aside from the paradoxes Cassie can create, she can also effect her own predictions--nulling and creating new ones as need arises.  I'm not sure Chance has sufficiently prepared her girl with the strength and decisiveness to be that dangerous an opponent.   Cassie also seems more indecisive in this story.  She's definitely entitled to these emotions, but that indecisiveness doesn't make her as likable as the stronger butt kicking heroines we're used to in fantasy.  Also, the episodes of 'what do I do' tend to derail the forward motion of the plot and stall the reader out.  These are spots where I as a reader get frustrated and tend to want to just skip.  While I read the entirely  of Chained" I'm pretty certain I will skip the third book.

column33: compiled from the notes for the adult education classes he taught in the United States.  Conclusion: The shallowness

I see below that there's a new book out on the dangers of soy.  Well

column1: This book reveals the ideology behind new American unilateralism and the philosphy that underpins the Bush doctrine;  "Might is right" or machtpolitik.  Kagan's (sometimes sneering) analysis of the European world view is a simplistic one.  He contends that Europe favours diplomacy and international channels before military action not because that might be a altogether preferable way of conducting diplomacy
column2: but rather because Europe is militarily weak.  Kagan assures us that
column3: if the EU had the muscle of the USA
column4: it would be as quick to dismiss internationalism and embrace a more militaristic and unilateralist foriegn policy
column5: just like the USA does today.    In otherwords
column6: European objections to the Iraq invasion were due
column7: not over concern at the motivation for it and the shoddiness (now laid bare for all) of the intelligence that supported it
column8: but simply that the EU doesn't have the military might to conduct such operations.  The benefit of hindsight illustrates how preposterous and
column9: well
column10: wrong
column11: this idea is.  This is the central and oft repeated tenet of the book.  It would seem to me that the target audience for this book seems very much to be readers who already agree with current US policy.  The arguments are facile
column12: hollow and repitious.  I cannot imagine it convincing anyone
column13: not already of Kagan's persuasion.  Kagan refers to "Saddam Hussein and his weapons of mass destruction" as a pretext for military action with the same assured certainty with which he talks about how the EU is living in a fantasy paradise secured by American power.    Looking to the future he sees only decline for the EU as a power and continued dominance for the USA.  It is a measure of how flimsy some of the arguments in this book are that he fails at this point to even mention the gargantuan and record-smashing  defecits the USA is currently running as the Military Industrial complex gorges itself once again on taxpayer money.  It's a very short book
column14: but gave me a better understanding of the dangerous views that are shaping the policies of the current administration

column1: I just finished reading Ida Lupino and was so disappointed.  The author is not a biographer - he's a second-rate journalist at best.  He managed to cull together a great many facts and just tossed them around
column2: hoping for a narrative.  There are so many things I'd like to know that just weren't answered.  An example - Ida had one child
column3: Brigett.  She's mentioned a few times
column4: then qualified as the center of Ida's life and the main reason for her giving up her directing career - to stay home and raise her.  Yet we learn absolutely nothing about this daughter.  No personal description
column5: no personality profile
column6: no private life or professional info.  All that is said is that when she grew up
column7: she moved out of the house and moved "far away from Los Angeles."  These facts would have been easy to find
column8: but the lazy author just glossed over whatever he didn't have. The style is high school level - things repeated over and over and restated in sentence after sentence and rephrased a paragraph later.  Terribly amateurish.  Didn't he even have the benefit of an editor?  Lastly
column9: the author has fallen in love with his subject and lost all perspective on both her flaws and her achievements and lasting importance.  There's no solid analysis of her acting technique - just carefully chosen trade reviews that are most favorable to her.  Ida Lupino mastered basically one type of performance
column10: and she gave it over and over again.  For a particular type of role
column11: she could be extremely effective by displaying her tense
column12: neurotic personality.  But she certainly wasn't any great actress
column13: not by anybody's standards
column14: except the author's
column15: and definitely only a competent director
column16: not the female William Wyler the author tries to paint her as being.  Lupino deserves a far more thorough and honest bio than this

The product works as described but the tortillas are not at all good for health since they remain uncooked in the inside

column1: It just astonished me as how certain discursive formations can actually lead people to believe as the 'real' reality. It does not matter whether for an event to 'really happen' or not. What matters is that you hear it on a radio or read it on a newspaper or website or even talk about it at the water-cooler. Those who have had the chance to watch 'Wag the Dog' might get the idea of how such 'reality' is constructed.  On a more advanced level 'discursivity'
column2: a la Foucault
column3: is a building block of a discourse in which certain linkages
column4: here and their
column5: add to what ordinary people believe on the street.  Now obviously Hitler was one of the worst things that happened during the 20th century. This is commonsense. But to add certain 'material' so as to advance another claim by building upon Hitler
column6: is something that should be carefully approached
column7: at least for people who at least visit and read stuff through Amazon. If a chain in a series of discursive formations can be shown to be weak or invalid than it would be proven that that chain of a discourse is on shaky grounds
column8: and that most of what is known about it is likely to be false. Unfortunately we see certain 'material' is attached to certain claims so as to resemble the Holocaust. Let us revisit a single claim on part of those would like to exploit the events during the early 20th century. A reviewer
column9: for instance
column10: obviously bought one claim and thus knows it to be the 'truth'  Adolf Hitler: "Who
column11: after all

column13: of course. "It sounds like as if it is true

column15: D.C. Political Communication and Persuasion
column16: Volume 3
column17: Number 2 (1985) Abstract This article traces the history of a purported Adolf Hitler quote which cites the perecent of the world's lack of reaction to the fate of Armenians during the First World War as a justification for his planned extermination of European Jewry in the course of the Second World War. By a detailed examination of the genesis of this quotation the author demonstrates that there is no historical basis for attributing such a statement to Hitler... [...] If one is serious about really getting into history
column18: rather than believing simply what is out their in the popular press
column19: I would additionally suggest to take a tour of the documents of Ambassador Morgenthau. But there are historical evidence that suggests that Morgenthau did not even know Ottoman scripture
column20: and that this is proved throughout his letters when he attempts to translate 'words' and 'dates' of events. Do not hesitate to read... [...]   For those who have CAREFULLY read what I have written so far

column23: but again all I am saying is

column4: a well to do computer programmer who is engaged to a wealthy banker. However

column5: serious trouble

column1: This story starts out pretty successfully. We are shown the life of the brothers in the abbey and their daily routines. This seems to set the tone for a dull plot. Then
column2: the reader experiences the sickness of a brother of the abbey and the mood of the story changes from the placidity of the abbey life to the chaos of trying to help the brother. This livens the book up some
column3: but not enough. Very few exciting events happen between that point until the death of Rhisiart. After Rhsisiart's death
column4: we are thrown back into that state of low-action; only this time
column5: with the added commotion of trying to figure out the murderer's identity. The ending wasn't a huge shocker. It was almost too predictable from the beginning. So
column6: all in all
column7: I would not recommend this book unless you wanted to be easily put to sleep

Admission to America's elite colleges is an increasingly trying affair. An academically strong
column2: middle class high school senior with no particular claim on a space
column3: "un-hooked" as it is known
column4: is faced with increasingly long odds of acceptance. The "un-hooked" applicant is squeezed by a dynamic made from increasing applications as more high school seniors go on to college and the colleges' own efforts to expand the applicant pool through increasing financial aid as well as recruiting international students even as they hold the number of places in freshman classes unchanged.  In this environment it is hardly a challenge to find a really sharp kid who was not accepted and also to find some "hooked" applicant who seemed rather less than qualified who was accepted. Venting on this situation provides a good release.   Golden vents well
column5: but is unfortunately short on substance. Lacking quantitative data
column6: the scope and scale of the matter escape Golden.   More importantly
column7: Golden does not attempt to address what seems to be the most pressing question: What do we expect of these elite institutions? Do we require that they be social engineers? If yes
column8: to what degree? Failing  an attempt to answer this question "The Price of Admission" is reduced to a voice only of frustration and angst.  For a more thought provoking read
column9: see Harry Lewis's "Excellence Without a Soul". Lewis is not specifically concerened with admissions
column10: as GOlden is
column11: but Lewis is very much interested in the question of what an education at one of these elite institutions should be.

Then the "fun" began as I tried to get a replacement for the damaged items from Amazon.  I checked the box on Amazon's on-line site asking to have the set replaced
column3: as I was requested to do
column4: and waited for the E-mail to be sent that was promised in the instructions.  Five days later: nothing
column5: not a word from the company by E-mail.  So
column6: I went to a near-by store that ships things
column7: paid to have the bake set packed up
column8: and then paid for shipping.  Next
column9: I went on-line and did a search on Google to find Amazon's 800 number.  As you will discover
column10: you cannot find it on the Amazon site; at least I couldn't.  I called
column11: sat on the phone for 15 minutes
column12: and finally got through.  After discussing the problem with the representative of Amazon
column13: I got reimbursed for the cost of the packing and postage to send the set back to the company.  And another set was sent.  It arrived five days later. There were no problems with these trays. Bottom line:  Too much time wasted to get the item replaced by Amazon.  Amazon: please
column14: please put your 800 number on your site where people can find it easily.  Also
column15: if someone checks a box asking for a replacement
column16: please get back to the person by E-mail as you promised!!!!!!!!!

column1: This is a collection of articles written for Petrowski's monthly column in American Scientist magazine. Many are brief biographies of 19th-century engineers; a (very) few look (very) briefly at particular pieces of historical engineering (an article on the Ferris wheel is probably the best); others are ruminations on such hazards of the engineering practice as the stress that keeps them up at night and their failure to be awarded Nobel prizes. These seem quite satisfactory articles for a magazine column but they are slender stuff for a book. And Petroski's tendency to return to the same subjects
column2: pardonable in a monthly column
column3: becomes repetitive when the columns are collected. All but die-hard Petroski fans can skip this on

column2: and it reminded me of why I seldom read fiction.  The plot has numerous barely-believable twists

The "storybook ending"just prior to the boarding of the FBI Director's private jet is implausible as well as gratuitously sappy.  Also
column4: I highly doubt that the FBI Director gets personally involved in many -- if any -- such cases.  Thankfully
column5: I paid only 25 cents for this book in paperback form at a garage sale 2 weeks ago.  Given that it's written at about a 4th-grade reading level (and I have no children)
column6: it'll make good fireplace kindling next fall.  First Grisham = LAST Grisham

column1: Professor Ellis is a very intelligent man
column2: but he plays fast and loose with the facts
column3: and sometimes he uses his gift for writing prose in ways that mislead the reader especially in
column4: American Sphinx.  Ellis has obviously covered all of the ground with regard to what is known about Jefferson--but he doesn't objectively present all of the factual scholarship existing about our 3rd President.   If you want to know more of the detail of what was all involved with Sally Hemings
column5: you MUST read Douglass Adair's essay "The Jefferson Scandals."  This essay is found in the book: Fame of the Founding Fathers: Essays by Douglass Adair.  Published by W.W. Norton.  Sally Hemings was the daughter of Jefferson's father-in-law; and Sally's lover was not T.J. but T.J.'s nephew (his sister's son).  That's why Jefferson never talked about the "scandal" because his close family relatives were involved; however
column6: not the way Prof. Ellis says.  The unfortunate fact is that Prof. Ellis mentions Douglass Adair in American Sphinx
column7: but he never mentions Adair's research (which Ellis cannot reasonably be ignorant of) on the alleged Sally Hemings-Thomas Jefferson liason.  It's obvious from American Sphinx that Ellis has read Adair's essays.  Prof. Ellis must know that the best evidence exonerates Thomas Jefferson
column8: but he never tells us about that. The well publicized DNA test does NOT prove TJ was the father of any of Hemings' children.  TJ never fathered any children with Hemings and Ellis knows it. Prof. Ellis is intellectually dishonest on this point
column9: and on many other points of Jefferson's life.  Too bad because he would otherwise have written a tour-de-force.  Instead it's a tour-de-FRAUD

column1: Philip Slater puts forth with vehemence and passion his opinions on the trends of hyperconsumerism and overindependence that are driving rifts between the people of our nation and diverting much-needed resources from  instituations designed to create health and well-being. His observations  about how middle-class Americans are alienating themselves by placing far  too much emphasis on material possessions
column2: individualistic thought ("I  am different from all of you")
column3: and an economy that is powerfully  rooted in the need to simply consume and produce goods rather than increase  the quality of life are interesting
column4: though a bit dated
column5: and still hold  much relevance to the current situation today.    Still
column6: the phenomena he  rages against are nothing new to the conscientious among us
column7: and there are  many other views on the problems of loneliness and hyperconsumerism that  prey on us. Slater makes powerful points
column8: and he clearly has a deep desire  to see change and the end of the injustices that characterize our century
column9: but I found his writing style and thought process to be scattered and far  too extremist to inspire me. His book seemed less of an empirical analysis  of the problems facing our nation and what we can do to solve them and more  of an emotional rant about what he personally feels is wrong and where he  feels we all went wrong. Nothing bad about that
column10: it's just he seems so  angry and hurt about it all that he didn't come close to capturing me  (though the chapter about Vietnam and the last chapter were coming close).      It was a good book
column11: but there are far better books written by far more  inspirational people. Carl Rogers ("On Becoming a Person") was a  psychologist who spoke beautifully and wisely for the healing of the  isolation and misunderstandings in our relationships with each other.  Barbara Marx Hubbard ("Conscious Evolution: Awakening the Power of Our  Social Potential") writes convincingly and with an uplifting sense of  hope about the problems we face as a people and a culture and what we can  do in the coming decades to move in the direction that Philip Slater longed  for. Both these authors
column12: and many others
column13: rationally describe problems we  all face
column14: then offer warm and well though-out advice about what we can all  do. Slater seems like something of a ranter
column15: and reading his book only  depressed me. But hey
column16: read the book
column17: then move on. Good luck

column1: The sub-header to this book could very well be: "All Work & no Play makes Jack a Dull Boy".   Basically
column2: Tom Stanley's scholarly treatise on American wealth comes down to this mind-ripping
column3: continent-blasting conclusion:   Millionaires
column4: you see:   1) Save more than they spend;   2) Don't spend anything.   That's it. Page after page
column5: chart after chart
column6: graph after graph
column7: anecdote piling up on anecdote
column8: all of it boiling down to the same conclusion: don't spend more than you save. Clip coupons. Hang on to your wife `til Death you do Part. Buy a rambler for 80 grand
column9: and cling to it like a rat clutching a Big Mac in a hurricane.   To wit: if you're a good little Bob Cratchit
column10: and burrow down in your suburban Dacha
column11: drive the Civic
column12: eat Top Ramen
column13: and take your vacations at the State Museum of Knitting & the Fine Arts
column14: you'll die loaded!Sound like fun?   Didn't think so. Look: you've got one life
column15: and after death all bets are off. Sure
column16: you could be hauled up by the angels to Paradise
column17: or it could just be one plate of linguini too many
column18: a nasty flatline and one vast inky void of non-consciousness. Either way
column19: you're looking at one single trip on this not-so-flat Earth
column20: so you might as well live large.   It's true
column21: now: you can haul in major bank in whatever profession you choose: eremetic horror-writer
column22: Wall Street tycoon
column23: Railroad baron
column24: small-town librarian
column25: legal eagle defender of the Criminally Insane
column26: whatever. And you can always outspend it. That is the source of endless tragedy and Dickensian woe throughout the ages
column27: without a doubt.  But there pitfalls at the other extreme. Listen: I live next door to one of these McMillionaires. The guy is this enfeebled little wizened gnome of a critter
column28: used to be a bank Vice President and got bought out because he was a dingus. Total skinflint. Miser. Goes on his own hunting trips and brings back venison
column29: deer meat
column30: which he forces his family of---jesus
column31: I think 12---to eat for months. Lives in a shacky little rambler
column32: buys used Crown Vics from the local police department and bargain basement prices.   The guy
column33: no doubt
column34: is high net worth. But he's also a loser.   This is a guy who didn't want to cough up a few hundred bucks to help build a joint fence between our properties---so there's a fence
column35: even a fence that abuts his property---but beyond my house and demesne
column36: he elected not to build a fence. Instead
column37: he got a plastic Jersey Barricade (orange and white) and went with that. Is that any way to live? Is that really what it means to be a `millionaire'?  I think not. Half the glory of the Age of Great American Consumption is buying stuff you don't need
column38: but want. Desire. Demand. What else is work for?  Find a way to creative bliss
column39: work at something you're good at
column40: that you have a real passion for
column41: and the money will follow.   But for the Love of God
column42: it's only Money: spend it! What is money for
column43: if not to indulge yourself?   Sure
column44: get a pace---plan to the end---set a budget. But how many of you want to be that newspaper column on page A3
column45: the 95 year old dowager pauper who begged for alms on the streetcorner
column46: ate catfood out of a tin
column47: and scrounged for quarters by the bus stop
column48: then was found rigid and cold in the urine-stiff sheets of her dirty bed
column49: sprawled atop a fortune estimated at 20 million bucks? Sound like a plan? I think not. Money may not buy happiness
column50: but it sure as hell can get you a Rolls-Royce Phantom.   "Millionaire Next Door" might have it right in its sociology---and for what it is
column51: Stanley's thesis is meticulously researched
column52: mustered like a well-trained army
column53: and capable of marshalling its teeming forest of facts like a well-drilled martinet---but it's off the map when it comes down to the point of the whole thing: if you've got it
column54: flaunt it.   "Millionaire Next Door" isn't a bad book: it's scholarly
column55: and plods along its own hand-me-down lodestar towards its prophesied conclusion (be cheap! Die loaded!)
column56: and perhaps some folks will be astounded to discover there are some real richies down the block who in another day would have been called skinflints.   But as a map to your stars
column57: this one is a little cramped
column58: cribbed
column59: dank
column60: and stinks of mothballs. I think I'll take first class---scratch that
column61: how much did you say that Learjet was going for

column4: PASCAGOULA IN MISSISSIPPI AND AS FAR EAST AS MOBILE ALABAMA. WHATEVER THE CASE
column5: THIS BOOK MISSES THE WHOLE POINT

column1: I read The Real Lincoln once and was
column2: in some regards
column3: impressed with the number of sources and the style of writing.  Still
column4: it bugged me because so much that I have read did not allow his pejoratives to ring true.  Therefore
column5: I began investigating its sources in detail
column6: one by one
column7: before coming to a conclusion.  I have found that The Real Lincoln is one the slickest example of half truths
column8: anachronisms
column9: and unfair assaults I have ever read.  So incensed am I that I am preparing a book to counter Mr. DiLorenzo's disgraceful rewrite of history.    Obviously
column10: I can't go into great length here
column11: but let's look at two examples.  1) Several times DiLorenzo scathes Lincoln for ordering the arrest of Clement L. Vallandigham for making an anti-administration speech before Congress in August 1861.  That is false on two counts.  First
column12: Ambrose Burnside alone was responsible for ordering Vallandigham's arrest
column13: a fact well documented but not appearing in Mr. DiLorenzo's bibliography.  Lincoln knew nothing about the arrest order until it had been consummated.  Second
column14: the event that led to the arrest was not Vallandigham's August 1861 speech to Congress but a May 1863 speech that he gave in Ohio.  All this appears several times in the Official Records and contemporaneous newspapers.    2) DiLorenzo cites a number of Republican newspapers that ostensibly criticized Lincoln's policies.  Except when you read the entire article (one from the New York Times
column15: for example) you find exactly the OPPOSITE is true
column16: that DiLorenzo only cited that portion of the article that paraphrased the opposition's thoughts
column17: not subsequent paragraphs where they savaged Lincoln's opponents.  This happens in many other cases such as making historian David Herbert Donald appear to be on the DiLorenzo ticket of Lincolnism when full cites would have revealed something totally different.   Either Mr. DiLorenzo did not do his homework
column18: or he is outright lying.  His obvious purpose is not providing a cogent look at Abraham Lincoln but beating the drum for his modern-day libertarian economic viewpoints.  Only the purest form of the Jeffersonian economic and political model matters to him
column19: and any deviation from it is tantamount to tyranny.  While one may argue the point of minimal government interference
column20: DiLorenzo blasts Lincoln with one pejorative after another and gives but lip service to Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal.  DiLorenzo even goes so far as to blame Lincoln for Reconstruction
column21: as if the dead president were somehow able to lead events from the grave.  Radical Republicans are responsible for Reconstruction
column22: and Lincoln was never a Radical Republican
column23: much less a live one.  I could say much more
column24: but it will have to wait for publication where I can expound at length.   The saddest part of this book is that too many believe this drivel.

column1: This book was highly recommended at [...] which is a respected forum and website of information for people in the sports photography business.  (pee-wee to pro)  I even paid for overnight shipping as I was very excited to have it.  I was very disappointed when after reading it.  The book indicates it will help users learn to shoot sports or to make users already doing it even better.  It will do neither.  Let me begin by saying the best chapter in the book is where the author talks about his career in professional sports photography.  He works mainly with the NFL and some Division 1 universities.  However
column2: the chapter is quick and not very deep in its storyline.  There are no great stories about games or being on the road.  Instead it sounds like a talk at career day at a High School.  I was really left wanting more.    There is a chapter on equipment but it didn't do much more than go over the basics saying you need a camera with interchangeable lenses and it will need to be digital today.  He did mention that prosumer cameras like the Canon 20D or Nikon D70 were not adequate to do sports.  I strongly disagree with that statement and I think you will find many people doing excellent work with cameras such as that and not just $4
column3: 000 and up cameras.  He really seemed to be hung up on frame rate which would mean he is more about machine gun style shooting than more careful shooting and anticipation.    Do you really want to come home from a game with 1000 shoots to sort through?  The chapter on digital workflow spends as much time describing what people used to do with film and slides and developing and scanning.  I see no value in that information.  The digital information is very general and not much use.  It basically said that to check with whatever agency or publication you were working for and do whatever they require.  There is a chapter written by an old NFL Photos Editor describing what they like to see in football photos.  Again
column4: it really doesn't go very deep and states the basics such as vertical shots make better magazine covers and isolated player shots are better for things like trading cards.  He also talked about submitting a portfolio.  He said to send your best shots and not to send out of focus shots.  (Thanks for the information.)    The rest of the book focuses on individual sports.  It covers some sports but not all.  For example
column5: it leaves out sports such as volleyball and golf which I think are important.  The author said once you learn the feel for the other sports
column6: you will just know what needs done for the sports they don't cover.  The chapters are all very weak and while he the book promises to tell you about shooting positions and lens selections
column7: it is not nearly detailed enough to help anyone wanting to become a professional and is generally obvious to anyone watching sports.    For example in football
column8: it says that the sidelines or end zone are place you can shoot from and some people like to kneel when shooting to make the player look bigger.  He also says you need a long lens like 300mm or better plus maybe a second body with a 70-200mm.  There also is mention of strobes on professional basketball and hockey arenas but it is too general for pros and useless for people doing kids/school leagues.  The best part of the book would be the pictures.  However
column9: the pictures are not presented with any type of technical information to help you learn about your camera and lens settings.  At best there might be a quick mention if the written text glossing over the information.    I usually like to think I can find something redeeming in any (technical) book but not in this one.  The information presented is available for free and is better on several photography forums on the Internet.  At least in those forums
column10: you can find other sports shooters (and other kinds too) and share information and interact including presenting your own work for critiquing.    If you would like to see excellent example of sports images
column11: then subscribe to the sports magazines and/or buy some of the coffee table type of book full of sports photos.  This book is not worth the money.

column1: There is no doubt that the author is extremely knowledgeable about financial statements
column2: but he struggles to write a clear introduction for newcomers. I finished the book with a muddy
column3: incomplete understanding of financial statements.  In his attempt to introduce financial statements to first-timers like me
column4: the author gets a couple things right:  - it's short. the length is a very comforting 130 pages.    - it's illustrated. there are drawings of scales with profit/loss
column5: etc. This is essential for visual learners like me.  However
column6: the author fails on these points:  - cute phrases instead of genuine insight.  The author's little jokes in the text felt a little self-indulgent
column7: and didn't help explain.  There is one exception: it was useful when the author describes the fans of the various reports - P/L vs Balance vs Cash Flow.  However
column8: most of the rest of the joking was irrelevant and amateur.  - Not well written.  Like many technical books
column9: the quality of writing was poor.  Many parts like first drafts - left me with lots of questions.  The illustrations often felt incomplete and didn't help explain much.   - Expert blindness.  In some ways
column10: experts are the worst people to write books for beginners.  They are passionate about the details and history
column11: which is not what newcomers need.    I understand why financial experts would recommend this book to newcomers: they share the passions of the author. However
column12: this doesn't help newcomers.  I will keep shopping for the book that gives me the basic 'big picture' understanding of financial statements I need

column1: I bought a copy of this book and it IS forcing me to give greater attention to an arguably important part of handicapping
column2: therefore
column3: it might be worth the money.  While Klein's percentage of winners and return-on-investment calculations are adequate for the leaders at the first call
column4: they are without merit for those that do not lead because he dumps both categories in together. This statistical error causes a disparity
column5: but it only "seems" that the ROI between leaders and non-leaders looks larger. But
column6: sheesh
column7: there is only ONE leader but SEVERAL non-leaders. Using basic math
column8: if the win percentage for leaders in a certain category is 30% then the win percentage for non-leaders is 70%.   Using Steve's calculation method
column9: in an 8-horse race you would bet $2 on the leader and $14 (the "non-leaders" times 2)on the non-leaders. Even if a non-leader won there would still be six losers among the non-leaders so the "win percentage" is just 14 percent. Unless the winner pays off at more than 6-1 odds it's a NEGATIVE return-on-investment!  In my opinion
column10: look to other handicapping books for a better return on investment

column1: When it is all said and done about Clinton's Legacy
column2: Gene Lyons has assured himself a place in the Presidential Library by writing such a book. The book does point out several areas that Clinton haters seldom want to  see or believe. For example
column3: regardless how you feel about Bill
column4: you must  admire his ability to not only survive a sad
column5: sordid and disadvantage  childhood but achieved his goals in education
column6: public service and politics.  He did so on his own initiative
column7: using and abusing close friends who also  did the same to him
column8: and focusing on saying anything at anytime that could  help him at that time. Whitewater was a shady inside financial political  deal
column9: made among many politicians with profiteers when the Saving and Loan  sector was deregulated
column10: not just in Arkansas but throughout the country. It  was denied during the campaign and avoided by a phony accounting report  that was needed in the primaries
column11: but proved to be less than accurate after  Clinton was elected president. On one hand
column12: two of Clinton's friends became  upset when the deal went south and felt Clinton abandoned them when he  became president. Now did those friends feel betrayed by Clinton and wanted  to bring him down as the book points out? The author has made a great case  saying so and I believe him. On the other hand
column13: was it the silence of  others who refused to answer pivotal questions whether such meetings with  Clinton took place? This would lead back to the president when he was a  governor and would show he plotted and scheme with them? No doubt about it
column14: their silence saved this president. Therefore
column15: in the book Gene Lyons wants  us to believe the former but some facts clearly show an investigation was  needed and reported properly by the media contrary to the author's  CONclusions. Either way
column16: 17 convictions including the Solicitor General's  convictions are facts not fiction. The author has been trying to apologize  and justify Clinton's behavior since the impeachment. In the end
column17: no book  using revisionists history is going to exonerate this president's actions  prior to and during the first four years of his presidency that  accomplished more than people expected. At the same time
column18: no book can  change the fact that president Clinton was able to avoid impeachment for  many acts that even his party said can be punishable after these last four  years of absolutely few accomplishments whatsoever. No friend or enemy of  the Clintons' have been able to help or hurt the Clintons' more so than  themselves as well as this book that lives off of a public's poor memory.  The only problem is
column19: when you view the Clinton presidency even after  Whitewater
column20: it is one few can be proud of and the only fool is the one who  claims it had made up scandals to bring them down. Sorry
column21: they did it all  by themselves and still are doing it
column22: to the dismay of the many who support  them
column23: and frustration of those would destroy them. The book is worth  reading to provide an overall view of the Clintons' but it can't change  history

column1: Published in the early 1990s
column2: this book puts forth the thesis that the end of the Cold War
column3: and its victory by the US
column4: marked a significant turning point in history.  Specifically
column5: mankind can see the light at the end of the tunnel of history
column6: that the liberal democracy that is America at the end of the Cold War is pretty close to a perfect society and once every society reaches this stage
column7: mankind has reached the end of history.  No more wars
column8: no more revolutions
column9: no more upheavals
column10: etc
column11: etc.  Of course
column12: events in the next decade up to and after the 9-11/2001 terrorist attacks proved this book all wrong.  Mankind is nowhere near the end of history; in fact we might be staring at a very long war between established governments and multinational terrorist groups.  And the dot.com bust
column13: the Enron and related scandals
column14: and now the economic and social wreckage due to a summer's worth of hurricanes shows that liberal democracies like the US are not even close to being optimal societies in terms of managing people - people or people - nature relationships.  I believe this book is even more foolish; that its thesis and its premise was flawed even in 1993
column15: and that the author should have known better than to publish such bullcrap.    First
column16: the human population continues to grow.  Yet the amount of arable land and drinkable water is not increasing.  This can only lead to conflicts.  It led to conflicts in the past
column17: and will only lead to more conflicts in the future.  We are seeing it happen already; every year the SW states in the USA duke it out in courts over water access.  Every year the Jews and Palestinians in Israel bicker over water access.  And of course we have at least one war per decade over oil; whether it be in the Middle East or somewhere else.  As the world's population grows
column18: we are only going to have more wars
column19: and since wars make great history
column20: a lot more history to go thru.  Second
column21: the author's premise that America is a liberal democracy is totally false.  America is a corporate democracy.  Pull over 100 people on any American city street (D.C. excepted) and ask them who their congressmen is
column22: or who their state representative is
column23: or even who their mayor is
column24: and after a slight pause
column25: the most common answer would be "I DO NOT KNOW".  On the other hand
column26: ask him/her how their 401K is doing
column27: or how is their mutual fund performing
column28: and you will get a certain answer.  This discrepancy of awareness and involvement between civic society and the corporate world can only mean one thing; America is a corporate democracy.  An even more potent sign; many of the prisons
column29: schools
column30: and health care facilities in the US are increasingly run in part or in whole by corporations.  Three of the most fundamental aspects of any society; criminal punishment
column31: health care
column32: and education
column33: are run by corporations in the US.  Third
column34: democracies don't always last.  A Roman Republic over 300 years old converted to dictatorship in under a century.  The area that is now Poland was comprised of democratic states throughout the Middle Ages.  These were successively conquered by their bigger neighbors (France
column35: Germany
column36: Russia) and subjected to dictatorships.  The Native American tribes throughout the N. American continent were all democracies in the purest sense of the word.  From 1776 - 1910
column37: each and every single one of them was either destroyed
column38: displaced
column39: or absorbed by one nation that only allowed white males to rule; the USA.  Last
column40: in any given time period
column41: the democratic nations that exist are usually expanding their possessions
column42: usually be conquering less democratic nations.  Semi-democratic
column43: aristocratic England conquered the Middle East and India.  Democratic France conquered N. Africa.  And of course the US has defeated or taken over various countries such as Cuba
column44: Puerto Rico
column45: Mexico
column46: Spain and the Philippines
column47: all of which were less democratic than the US.  Democracy does not put an end to man's greed
column48: it only channels it outwards towards its neighbors near and far.  All in all
column49: a book of false conclusions based on false premises.  It is worthy of reading if only to see the mistakes in its logic and arguments
