column1: Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn. No other ballet partnership is as legendary -- the fiery Russian defector and the graceful
column2: aging English ballerina formed a bond on and off the stage that for several years practically defined romantic ballet. Thus
column3: for this very reason
column4: hardcore balletomanes should get this dvd. Many of us (including me) were too young to have seen Nureyev and Fonteyn live
column5: so these videos are the only example to dissect the legendary partnership.  However
column6: caveat emptor: this is NOT a "typical" Swan Lake by any means. You can argue that there is no "typical" Swan Lake -- the original production in 1877 was a failure. Some of the music went missing. After Tchaikovksy's death
column7: the choreographers Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov restaged Swan Lake
column8: and that version more or less is the Swan Lake audiences know today. There's lots of music
column9: so most versions of Swan Lake use the "traditional" pieces.   Nevertheless
column10: there are some different traditions of Swan Lake. In the Russian productions
column11: the outcome is usually "happy" -- Rothbart is killed
column12: and Siegfried and Odette are alive. In the productions used "everywhere else
column13: Odette and Siegfried leap into the lake, and are reunited in the otherworld. I prefer the second ending personally, because I think it better matches both the story (the happy ending was enforced by the Tsar, and seems tacked on), and the music as well.  Rudolf Nureyev's 1966 film, however, is unlike any other Swan Lake I've ever seen. First of all, from the opening closeup (of Siegfried in blue eyeshadow and red lipstick) you realize this film is not going to follow Balanchine (and classical ballet's) creed of ballet is woman." The first act is redesigned to incorporate a lot of solos and dance opportunities for Siegfried (Nureyev). The first act usually ends with Siegfried picking up his bow and arrow and going hunting with Benno. In this film
column14: there is a long elegiac solo for Siegfried (using music that's usually used in act 2).   Nureyev even dares to tinker with the famous Act II choreography by Lev Ivanov. In the famous Odette/Siegfried Adagio
column15: the melody is not repeated with the cello -- instead
column16: there's another solo for Siegfried. Margot Fonteyn was born in 1919 so it's possible that the emphasis on Nureyev is due to Fonteyn's technical limitations at the time. And one notices that Fonteyn
column17: as graceful and lovely as she is
column18: is at times unable to cope with the famously demanding Odette/Odile role. For instance
column19: Odette's solo in Act II usually ends with a series of turns and then Odette stands on pointe and holds a balance before going into the wings. Fonteyn doesn't attempt the feat
column20: but ends the series of turns in first position -- flat on her feet. Fonteyn by modern standards also lacks the athleticism
column21: bonelessness (her arms always look like arms
column22: not wings)
column23: flamboyance
column24: and flexibility
column25: that one usually associates with this role.  Act III's music choreography is pretty standard
column26: but the musical arrangements (and choreography) for the Black Swan Pas de deux are radically different. Fonteyn actually churns out the fouettes
column27: confirming something I've long suspected: that everyone looks at the fouettes
column28: but Odette/Odile's real challenges are the balances
column29: footwork
column30: and leaps
column31: and this is where you can see Fonteyn suffer.   Strangely
column32: Act IV (the act that is usually cut to shreds) is the most intact. And it's the best-danced act: it;s the reconciliation scene between Odette and Siegfried that one can catch glimmers of the genuine bond that existed between these dancers. Elsewhere
column33: the technical limitations of Fonteyn by this time and Nureyev's reworking of Swan Lake as a solo showpiece for Siegfried distracted me from simply enjoying their partnership. I particularly loved when Siegfried runs all over the stage
column34: turning up the head of each swan
column35: to find his Odette
column36: and when he finally finds Margot's head
column37: it's a truly beautiful moment. The ending of Nureyev's version follows the original Swan Lake

column43: and they simply look like a corps that hasnt danced Swan Lake enough. The sets are also deliberately artificial and the costuming

column51: and still impressive technique make her Odette/Odile much more appealing to modern tastes. This Swan Lake is of great historical value

column54: and I certainly wouldnt recommend this dvd as anyone's first Swan Lake. Its just too unorthodox.

In this cleverly titled book by veteran archaeologist William Dever
column2: we are presented with a novel theory for Israelite origins.  Dever spends the first two thirds of his work on building up the introduction.  This isn't necessarily bad
column3: if the payoff is big at the end.  Indeed
column4: he surveys many of the most important sites around Canaan
column5: introducing us to the history and culture of this region and different schools of thought regarding Israelite origins before progressing to a solid and sustained critique of Finkelstein's nomad-sedentarization model.  The problem with the book
column6: however
column7: begins with the final third
column8: where Dever enthusiastically describes his theory
column9: which basically holds that the "proto-Israelites" were in fact sedentarized Canaanites who fled to the hill-country in the wake of the general late-Bronze Age collapse.  Although the first part of the book
column10: which served as the build-up
column11: consisted of discussions of archaeological sites and critiques based on lack of evidence
column12: Dever introduces his theory (which takes up a measly eleven pages) with an up-front admission that it also lacks evidence!  "My theory
column13: is speculative
column14: of course; and like Medelhall's and Gottwald's peasant revolt it has little direct archaeological evidence to support it." (179) "Nevetheless
column15: Dever assures us, this scenario is quite realistic". (ibid)  Thanks!  Now one has to wade through the rest of his discussion knowing in advance that it lacks evidence.  But wait a minute
column16: didn't Dever just spend a hundred pages attacking other archaeologists because their theories lacked evidence?  One can buy into his theory or not
column17: that's not the point.  It's more about how little we really know about the origins of Israel outside the biblical record
column18: which when rejected
column19: creates a vacuum that can be filled with any "realistic" and "scholarly" sounding theory.  If you buy this book
column20: use it for the archaeological survey and critique of Finkelstein.  Just remember to continue Dever's critique onto himself!

column1: Conclusions that Richard Lynn draws from the data should be valid if and only if he could explain the historical facts and not only the extant situation.  His ahistorical approach is exemplary. While he explicitely conducts evolutionary analysis of the humankind he surprisingly forgets to connect his IQ data with historical facts such as:  that the first great civilisations emerged in the Near East and Northern Africa not in Northern
column2: Central or Eastern Europe; the first European civilizations connected with metalurgy (the Asia Minor and the Balkan Complex)
column3: rational thought (elaborate philosophy and mathematical theoremes) emerged in Asia Minor and SouthEast Europe
column4: not in Northern or Central Europe. Northern and Central Europe started to emerge in the history of civilisation only at the end of the middle ages and was enlightened by the Arab translations of the ancient Greek thought. This explanatory paradox substantially weakens Lynn's general conclusions on the direct connection between geography and general cognitive abilities. This is also valid for the conclusions in his book on IQ and the wealth of the countries. His ahistorical explanations are astonishing in negative sense.  For example
column5: the higher IQ scores of Northern Europeans compared to the Southeast Europeans could be a result of the very well documented South to North migratory flow during the last 5-6 centuries of Turkish Ottoman suppression in Southeast Europe. Many highly intelligent people even today leave Southeast Europe and migrate to USA or Western Europe for better life. This is an every day fact. Thus
column6: it is not only the cold winters that concentrate clever people in some geographical regions in some periods of time. The real high resolution picture of the IQ-Race-Geography dynamics is probably much more complex and intricate than Lynn is ready to admit. His explanations
column7: thus
column8: can be treated only as zero (or at most) first approximation acceptable on the general geographic scale. Much more subtle historical analyses are needed on lower geographic scales to make his explanations meaningful

column1: This book is a decent introduction to Direct3D graphics
column2: but it's by no means a definitive guide
column3: nor is it a guide to Direct3D9 graphics. A discussion of the real meat and potatoes of Direct3D9
column4: the facet that makes the API so exciting for developers
column5: pixel and vertex shaders
column6: is completely omitted. So it's essentially a Direct3D7 level text.   The discussion of 3D mathematics was abysmal
column7: a lot of the actual math isn't really shown
column8: but how to use the D3DX helper functions are. Worst of all
column9: Thorn didn't show us how to multiply matrices -- LUDICROUS! If anyone wants to be a professional graphics programmer
column10: implementing and developing new algorithms
column11: they're going to need to get to grips with the
column12: sometimes grueling
column13: mathematics.    The discussion of 3D concepts is okay
column14: but it's all extremely basic. I was able to get a very simple
column15: fixed-function game engine running using this book as a reference for some of the API functions
column16: but if you want to make more cutting edge graphics programs
column17: you need pixel shaders to do that.   If you can get this book used and dirt cheap
column18: then it'll be a decent intro to Direct3D
column19: but I suggest you pick up either Wolfgang Engel's Beginning Direct3D Game Programming and/or Frank Luna's book -- both of which introduce pixel/vertex shaders.   After you read the forementioned
column20: "Programming Vertex And Pixel Shaders" by Wolfgang Engel will be most useful
column21: as well as the ShaderX series (also edited by Engel).

column1: Living in Washington
column2: DC and seeing the changes in demographics in the city and surrounding area made me pick up this book at a sidewalk sale for 50 cents to see what Wilson's take on the "new urban poor" and his research correlating them to the loss of work opportunities. Reading this book should be mandatory at an advanced statistics course of how to come to bad conclusions through the use of selective and wrong data.  DC has never had a big industrial base
column3: but it had a very strong and influential black middle class early in the 20th century up until FDR's New Deal when the city was swamped with undereducated and socially dysfunctional immigrants from the southern states. It is the same time that DC became a "black majority" city. This is the same time frame that Wilson uses to "prove" that there was a direct correlation with the loss of factory jobs and the explosion of the urban poor. In order to come to this conclusion
column4: Wilson uses a lot of statistics taken out of context
column5: manipulated to support his conclusions
column6: and then come up with a rehash of "new" policy initiatives which are essentially a regurgitation of LBJ's "war on poverty" programs
column7: which were an expansion and rehash of FDR's "New Deal." What Wilson ignores are demographic shifts and trends that are much more easily explained and much more solidly supported by Charles Murray
column8: Marvin Olasky
column9: and others who were much more thorough in examining the trends that Wilson writes about.  The Washington DC area today has more jobs than ever before
column10: yet the illegitimacy rate for black children is 90%. In the 1920's and 30's
column11: the illegitimacy rate for whites and blacks was the same
column12: even during the height of segregation and discrimination. The city now has a population base 25% smaller than its peak in the 50's. Even though job opportunities were expanding for minorities in DC
column13: the black middle class abandoned DC and moved into Prince Georges County to get away from crime and other deteriorating social norms
column14: but none of this is to be found in Wilson's research. The same is true for other cities where a combination of "white flight" and "black flight" of the middle class made these downtowns more closely resemble cities in third world countries than the USA. Similar problems can be found in Paris and its suburbs
column15: and many other cities around Europe where immigration and a lack of assimilation have created huge ghettos of the "Urban Poor." There is indeed a much greater correlation to be found in the expansion of the size of the urban poor with the expansion of government programs designed to eliminate poverty. None of these alternative
column16: and much more persuasive
column17: reasons for the plight of the urban poor are to be found in this book. It was people like Wilson who "proved" Galileo to be wrong when he said that the Earth revolved around the sun
column18: and this book is about as convincing. There are many good statistics and arguments in this book. The problem is that Wilson has excluded any alternative explanations of the reasons for the urban poor
column19: which makes this a very dishonest book.

column1: I'm afraid this is going to be the last Mary Balogh book I buy.  It's painful to admit this to myself because
column2: since discovering her novels (my first was No Man's Mistress) and then glomming all her back titles from the last 20 years
column3: I've spent many a happy hour in her Regency romance world.    But Balogh's titles of the past six years--the "Slightly" and "Simply" books--have all disappointed me and Simply Magic is
column4: sadly
column5: the worst of the lot.  I continued to buy and read Balogh
column6: in spite of my disappointment
column7: because I'd hoped she was in a slump from which she'd emerge.  But after reading Simply Magic
column8: I'm giving up that Balogh will ever again write the heart-rending
column9: angsty gems (The Temporary Wife
column10: The Notorious Rake
column11: Heartless
column12: Dancing With Clara
column13: Lord Carew's Bride
column14: et al.) that made her reputation.  Where to begin with what's wrong with this latest effort?  With the uninspiring beta hero (among the most irritating I've ever encountered in the genre) who's unbecomingly dominated by his morally-challenged mama (and who sheepishly admits to the heroine his knees shake when he has to give his steward an order)?  Or the emotionally stunted heroine whose behaviour seems like that of someone clinically depressed throughout most of the story--complete with a sort of disassociation of her mind with her body when it comes to sex?  And then there's Balogh's unfortunate penchant
column15: which has become more and more pronounced in her recent works
column16: to clog the story with so many extraneous characters and tidbits about their lives that the reader feels the need to take notes.  The biggest problem I have with this book
column17: however
column18: is that it reveals Balogh's abandonment of what I believe is THE crucial premise of the romance story.  Balogh spends a great deal of energy on making the point to the reader that the "love story" is not the cake in her heroine's life but the frosting.  In her recent novels she takes pains to show the heroine doesn't require the masculine essence of the hero
column19: in its highest form of romantic love
column20: for her emotional
column21: spiritual and physical completion.  Her recent heroines are emotionally self-sufficient
column22: have employment they love
column23: and while it would be ever so luscious and easy-around-the-manor to be married
column24: it's not a core
column25: primal necessity for their life's fulfillment.    There's always a moment in Balogh's recent books where the hero has this epiphany
column26: when he "gets it" that the heroine will be just fine without him.  The story is not allowed to move on
column27: in fact
column28: until the hero has that bit of feminist-tinged dogma firmly implanted in his head.  I suppose all of us modern types are supposed to nod in agreement but
column29: in a romance novel
column30: I find the whole presentation dreary to the max.  (Can we not escape the death of romantic love anywhere?  Not even in its supposed last bastion
column31: the pastel cover romance novel?)   I read romance novels to experience the archetypal wonder of romantic love between a man and a woman--a love that torments and creates upheavel but also redeems
column32: completes
column33: saves.  Romantic love is full of messy dependency
column34: jealousy
column35: and a lot of shadow--that's what makes it romantic. It gives a vision
column36: a much needed vision
column37: that continues to persist and inspire--and has great power to explain the behaviour of men and women toward each other.  Balogh used to write books that glorified that archetype.  Often employing the stock characters of the genre--the dark
column38: tortured hero
column39: the empathetic
column40: nurturing heroine.  But then she "saw the light" (or something) and her works have devolved over the last several years into neat
column41: passionless feminist samplers that have more than a politically correct whiff to them--and all the depth and complexity of a "Can This Marriage Be Saved?" column--or worse
column42: the Regency equivalent of a Glamour magazine editorial about balancing career and "relationship."   Simply Magic reminds me of a kind of romance prozac.  It calms
column43: tones down
column44: erases and tames the wild beasts of the masculine and feminine romantic archetypes.  I don't want that drug. I want to feel.

column1: Here's the news:less than half the forces on the allied side on D Day were from the  U.S. Would you guess that from reading Ambrose's book? - nope. The vast bulk of the volume is devoted to the U.S. experience. It seems Ambrose thinks the British
column2: Canadians etc were just there to make up the numbers.  It's just not acceptable for a historian to devote the bulk of what purports to be an account of that day to one national contingent and then call it 'D Day' . To perpetrate that is petty and appallingly parochial.  Worse: it's offensive to the memories of ALL those who fought and died for democracy. The American sacrifice was real and  doesn't need this sort of thing to keep its memory green.  Robin Neillands and John Keegan have both written much better
column3: fairer accounts.  If Ambrose had called the book 'the American contribution to D-Day' no one could have complained. As it is
column4: it has no claim to our serious consideration as history.

Is there something poignant about the selection of this particular reader?  She does Evanovich no justice. The story begins with a missing uncle report...main character "Stephanie's" missing uncle
column5: that is.  Oddly
column6: no one reports that he's missing for 2 days & none seem very concerned about his disappearance.  I found it extremely odd that the family would discuss his absence "over coffecake as is customary in the 'burg in New Jersey."  Pardon me
column7: I'm not from "the 'burg" or NJ but it's really a stretch to believe that everyone from the "'burg" casually discusses the case of a missing relative while dining on coffeecake. Attempts at humor are pathetic
column8: such as: "I got my shower; jumped out & dried my hair by way of styling it."  What????  "Ranger" naturally drives a Ranger (creative genius there).  Stephanie goes on a job & forgets her gun (was I supposed to fret or laugh?  Who knows w/this reader's tonal quality). The novel continues
column9: yet still no one concerns themselves with the missing uncle.  Stephanie sleeps around with carefree abandon but it is tough to take seriously while listening to that lisp!  Characters appear & we really have no clue as to why they immerged onto the scene. (Maybe the clue was in book 1
column11: 3 or 4??) Again
column12: this is the AUDIO version.  The reader's voice works as well as Michael Jackson reading the Da Vinci Code...a no can do! After listening to the audio version of High Five
column13: I can emphatically state: sometimes words are better left unspoken (just read them!)

column1: Attached is an extract of my letter to Larry Berman dated April 01
column2: 2002.  Subject: "No Peace
column3: No Honor"  Dr. Berman: I am reading (with great skepticism & disagreement) your above book. I have a keen interest in Vietnam War history (and pseudo history) and have recently received from my daughter (college librarian)the Choice heads up about your book....(I was a 1956 Political Science graduate of The University of the South and was a co-pilot in SAC until 1959. We
column4: of course
column5: Studied Dien Bien Phu
column6: the Geneva Accords
column7: SEATO and the then already identified Communist insurgencies in South Vietnam
column8: Cambodia
column9: Laos
column10: Thailand
column11: Indonesia and other areas of South East Asia and were well aware of Communist Ho Chi Minh's plans to take over South Vietnam by covert and/or overt invasion
column12: rigged elections
column13: infiltrated agents
column14: democratic [Communist] fronts
column15: etc.). You surely knew all of this at one time (because I note that you too have read Nixon's "No More Vietnams" and his & Kissinger's memoirs...) Apparently you agree with hardly any of Nixon's assessments
column16: or if you do
column17: you have deliberately chosen to adopt the simplistic [straight leftist] history of gentle 'George Washington' Ho Chi Minh and his noble efforts to unify Vietnam [under ruthless totalitarian Communism] and his betrayals after the Geneva Accords..(p18 et seq). (I really think that you are too smart for this and what follows and that you have adopted the "Russian style of history writing" that you [and Zumwalt
column18: Jr] attribute to Nixon & Kissinger at p9). In particular
column19: although you do refer
column20: without elaboration
column21: to the Jan 2 & Jan 4 1973
column22: Democratic caucus votes to cut off all funds to Indochina - with legislation to terminate the war speeding its way to the floor...
column23: you do not make the obvious points that the antiwar movement and the determination of the Doves [predominately Democrats] to force an end to the war - with or without a negotiated agreement & whether or not 150
column24: 000 NVA troops remained in South Vienam
column25: or Laos or Cambodia
column26: or whether or not all of SE Asia would surely fall into Communist hands - totally under cut Kissinger's negotiation options and forced him to take the only Agreement available. Everyone knew that leaving 150
column27: 000 NVA troops in place was a terrible option and that continued US military support of South Vietnam would be essential
column28: and that strict US enforcement of the Paris Agreement - by resumed bombing of strategic military targets might well be necessary. (As you well know
column29: the North concluded in 1968
column30: or earlier
column31: that the growing antiwar movement and the outspoken Democrats would force an end to the war within a few years
column32: or less
column33: and that victory could be obtained - if only the North could hang on until Congress defunded the war. Gen Giap has confirmed this and has stated that he designed a strategy to avoid large & costly full scale engagements
column34: but to hide in the jungles & Cambodian sanctuaries and initiate enough ambushes to keep the US body count high
column35: and to stall the peace negotiations indefinitely...) You
column36: of course
column37: conclude [very much disingenuously
column38: in my opinion] that Kissinger was out-negotiated
column39: that the Paris Agreement & Nixon brought no peace
column40: and no honor
column41: and that he and Kissinger deceived the American people into thinking that the terms of the cease-fire would be the end of the American involvement [I don't know of anyone who thought that...] and that this was a dishonorable two-faced deception
column42: and that Nixon [& not the US Congress] betrayed our South Vietnam allies by forcing them to accept an Agreement that could only be enforced by continued US monetary & air power support - which Nixon fully intended to provide (as well as secretly promised reconstruction aid to the North - as an economic incentive to abide by the Agreement...). Watergate
column43: of course
column44: prevented Nixon from re-introducing air power to enforce the Agreement
column45: and light weight Ford had neither the leadership ability nor inclination to advocate for strict enforcement - absent Congressional willingness to do so. The betrayal of South Vietnam and the dishonoring of the American people was Congress' doing - at the urging of the Doves and antiwar protestors like John Kerry
column46: et al. As you know - and conveniently failed to even discuss in your book that purports to assess blame for the betrayal - [Russian history style..] - Nixon very clearly & cogently [and convincingly
column47: in my opinion] laid out the facts upon which he concluded that the US Congress "Lost the Peace". ("No More Vietnams"
column48: Chapter5) You also assert that Nixon & Kissinger deceived and misled the American people [and the Congress] and did everything they could to deny any independent access to the historical record and that only [now?] "This story of diplomatic deception and public betrayal has come to light only because of the release of documents and tapes that Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger sought to bury for as long as possible." This too is disingenuous
column49: in my opinion. I find very little in your book that was not more comprehensively presented in Kissinger's 1979 book "White House Years". (He had at leased ten times [this is an exaggeration] more facts about the Paris negotiations than you did
column50: and I do not find any place in your book where you demonstrate that any statement by Kissinger was false - or even misleading or deceptive. In other words
column51: I find very little in your book that is new - other than your gratuitous assertions that you have uncovered new data that shows that Nixon & Kissinger were dishonorable and deceived and betrayed the American people....In my opinion
column52: your slanderous assertions are not supported by the facts contained in - or conveniently omitted from - your sensational and poorly reasoned book. But this is just my opinion
column53: and who cares?? John Elli

Did the students injured at the recent shooting at Dawson College in Montreal (Canada) create that? Or even still ... did the people who were on the New Zealand airplane that crashed in fall 2006 in the Pacific create that as well? Sometimes others impose their wills on innocent bystanders through brutal force and that is not creating your day. That is just plain tragic. We are not victims of life but neither are we masters of the universe either.

column1: This book begins with "The Three Statements That Strike the Essential Points" from the Last Testament of Garab Dorje the first human master of Dzogchen: "One is introduced directly to one's own nature"
column2: "One definitively decides upon this unique state" and "One continues directly with confidence in liberation." They seem straightforward enough - OK maybe a little terse. Dudjom Rinpoche's Short Commentary (1 page) is very nicely translated and to the point. Next is a short work by Patrul Rinpoche with his poetic commentary that develops things further. By its end we are up to Page 67. Then Mr. Reynolds commentary kicks in - wow. I read it but it's some pretty rough sledding. Far
column3: far too many insertions of Tibetan terms break the flow of what is
column4: after all
column5: supposed to be a translation. Then there are nuances (in parens) within interpolations [in brackets]like this from Page 145:    "As for the the real meaning of this: [All of] the states [consisting of the nondual gnosis or knowledge (which is primordial awareness) present in the hearts]of all the Sugatas are encompassed within this (single unique state of immediate intrinsic Awareness found within every individual sentient being)."  Dzogchen just isn't this hard!   The latter part of the book is lengthy scholarly material intended to defend and support Dzogchen's ancient lineage problem and its radical differences from Tantric Mahayana Buddhism. Hey
column6: it either works in your spiritual life or it doesn't. What difference does it make if the concepts and techniques arose in 2
column7: 500 BCE or 1100 CE? Read "The Mirror
column8: Advice on Presence and Awareness" by Namkhai Norbu and you can start living it - today.

column21: I'm not going to debate God's sovereignty in all things nor suggest that God does not have the right over life and death.  But to claim that this man losing his children was judgement from God is a leap of faith I'm not going to take.  All in all

column1: A few points.  First
column2: there is no settled-upon interpretation of quantum physics.  For any seemingly miraculous quantum phenomenon
column3: there is an interpretation of quantum mechanics which disallows it.  Nonlocality for example
column4: and all of the pseudo-intellectual new age mumbo jumbo that so often accompanies it
column5: does not occur in many interpretations of quantum mechanics.    Second
column6: Goswami is philosophically inept.  It is clear that he has never read philosophy
column7: which is fine for a layperson but is completely unacceptable for a man marauding as a serious thinker in a book the contents of which hinge on arguments for tendentious philosophical positions.  Goswami is terminologically inept as well.  Monistic idealism?  It's simply Idealism
column8: which is by definition a version of monism (since it holds that there is only one kind of thing in existence).  Had this man read his philosophy
column9: he might have both ameliorated his gross abuse of philosophical terminology AND discovered that his ideas have been put forth
column10: hashed and rehashed countless times over the course of at least 2000 years.  Furthermore
column11: no one in academic philosophy or physics gives any credibility to the ideas promoted in this book.  The only people who embrace this garbage are those who are scientifically or philosophically illiterate (or both).  Philosophers dismiss these ideas because the arguments given to support them (in the rare cases that there ARE arguments given) without exception constitute faulty reasoning.  For example
column12: this entire book takes the form of an abductive argument
column13: an inference to the best explanation of what Goswami claims is evidence.  If I may be permitted to make a well-studied value judgement
column14: this argument is weak enough that it could be effectively countered by an average first-year college undergraduate.  Far too weak to hold water or be taken seriously.  As a work of philosophy
column15: this book fails miserably.    Scientists dismiss these ideas because we simply haven't come to understand quantum mechanics yet.  The truth is that no one (not even Nobel laureates) can agree on an interpretation of quantum mechanics.  To claim as evidence for his position the role of consciousness in quantum mechanics and the existence of instances of nonlocal causation is to build an architecturally flawed building on top of a house of cards in the middle of a wind storm.  The book is logically and empirically bankrupt.    So why did Goswami write the book?  Why risk his career?  Funding.  Fantastic ideas attract attention and with attention comes more funding.  My advice?  Find a serious and respectable work on interpretations of quantum mechanics.    This book fails as science and the overwhelmingly flaky and credulous Goswami fails as a scientist.  This book is a fine example of a scientist doing the exact opposite of what scientific principles perscribe

column1: "Is it really my failure
column2: or theirs?"  Carol Kennicott asks herself this question nearly 250 pages into "Main Street
column3: regarding her impossible relations with the residents of  the town of Gopher Prairie, Minnesota. By this time, I was asking a similar question: Is it really my failure
column4: or Sinclair Lewis's?"  "Main Street" seemed a good idea as it sat on my shelf. Touted as a satirical look at middle-class America
column5: it was Lewis's first successful novel
column6: ushering in a new era upon its publication in 1920
column7: and breaking critical ground for the Golden Age of American Literature
column8: of Hemingway
column9: Fitzgerald
column10: and Faulkner. Lewis was the first American to win the Nobel Prize for Literature. How could I go wrong picking it up?  The book tells the interminable story of Mrs. Kennicott
column11: who marries a country doctor while imagining herself an improving influence on his as-yet-unseen town of Gopher Prairie. Imagine her surprise when she is greeted not as a liberator but grist for the gossip mill
column12: with her Big City ideas and lack of churchiness.  Carol's alternating turns of resistance and acceptance are about the sum total of this plotless book. Lewis's descriptive powers are much in evidence
column13: and you find yourself trapped in G.P. as much as Carol
column14: his descriptions of noisy neighbors and smug dinner parties bearing the unmistakable imprint of someone who grew up in small-town Minnesota and knew of what he wrote. The problem
column15: when you get past the period slang and the barbed commentary
column16: is that the subjects of Lewis's satire are so miserable and nasty you can't understand why Carol thinks she can change them
column17: except perhaps with the idea nature couldn't possibly create people as one-dimensional as those found here.  I thought I'd never read a duller work about small-town Americana from the early 20th century than Thornton Wilder's "Our Town." My apologies
column18: Thornton. "Main Street" is as down on the same locale that "Our Town" exults
column19: only Lewis lays on derision with a dripping trowel. Wilder
column20: by contrast
column21: seems almost surgical in the delicacy with which he makes his points. Lewis makes sure that when he presents us with the atheistic radical Miles Bjornstam
column22: he is not only a voice of reason and affability to Carol but ultimately run out of town for his beliefs on the heels of having suffered a great tragedy
column23: just in case we didn't otherwise get how miserable a town Carol is stuck in.  "And you want to reform people like that when dynamite is so cheap?" Carol fumes early on.  There is one effective section in the book
column24: when Carol first discovers how isolated she has become and feels the "moist
column25: fleering eyes" of prying neighbors so powerfully she draws down her window shades. Passages with her husband
column26: the stolid
column27: straying
column28: but not worthless Dr. Kennicott
column29: present some desperately-needed ambiguity.  But the book just keeps going
column30: hammering home the same points
column31: before winding down with an ending that feels more like a cop-out

Here are some references that I believe are linked to current administration.   Page 21 - Reference to Dixie Chicks Page 28 - Reference to the "invisible weapons of mass destruction
Since his retirement in 2000 as Bishop of the Episcopal Church in Newark
column2: John Shelby Spong has fashioned himself as a leading spokesperson for a radically progressive Christianity. In a dozen or so books he has insisted that institutional Christianity must aggressively question the very essence of its faith inheritance
column3: and not just in a cosmetic way that tinkers with the fringes. Rather
column4: he admits that his drastic antidotes might kill the patient
column5: although it is not clear that he would view that outcome as unfortunate (pp 58
column6: 178). His current book is simply one more verse of this refrain. Given his unsparing and unflinching critique of a church he spent a lifetime serving
column7: I wondered why he even wants to continue to identify himself as Christian. To be sure
column8: his alternate proposal has at best only a tenuous connection to anything historically or theologically Christian.             I suspect that those who would like to address the very important question Spong's title purports to address will find his book disappointing. His style and tone throughout are condescending towards those with whom he disagrees (mainly anyone more conservative that he is). He categorically disparages these people as profoundly ignorant
column9: duplicitous
column10: repressed
column11: and pitiable. Complex issues are oversimplified. Speculative and dubious opinions (Mary was Jesus's wife
column12: Paul was a repressed homosexual
column13: Judas did not exist) are offered as serious alternatives. He constantly invokes the weakest
column14: weirdest
column15: and most bizarre forms of arguments to dissect (straw man arguments). Finally
column16: there is the feel of self-promotion and kitsch to this book. I mean
column17: what are we to make of a dust jacket that includes a blurb by Bill O'Reilly of Fox News and the hype that "history will recognize Spong as one of the major change agents of modern Christianity." I tend to think of people like Spong as fundamentalist liberals.             All this is unfortunate because the ostensible subject of his book is so very important. What are we to make of the passages in the Bible itself that
column18: upon simple reading
column19: sound so horrible? Like God's command to exterminate the Canaanites
column20: or the death penalty for cursing or breaking the sabbath? Paul's insinuation that homosexuality is God's punishment for improper worship? Related but slightly different
column21: what about how so many believers have abused the Bible to support horrendous evils like slavery or genocide? Spong writes that he wants to "filter" the Bible through the sieve of contemporary knowledge; that is good and necessary. But we also need to learn to move in the opposite direction
column22: to filter the world and all its evils through the Scriptures. Interpreting the ancient Scriptures in our contemporary world
column23: then
column24: is a complex task
column25: and one is likely to find little serious help in Spong's shrill manifesto.             For a great orthodox-liberal dialogue
column26: read the many exchanges between Tom Wright and Marcus Borg. For creedal development try Pelikan. For how and why religion becomes evil (a major theme for Spong)
column27: there is Charles Kimball. Showing very little awareness of how his own social location and theological commitments might have shaped his own thought
column28: Spong exemplifies the dilemma of taking the Jeffersonian scissors to the text
column29: which is that you end up with a Bible that looks remarkably like your own image

column1: In "Using Terri"
column2: Jon Eisenberg attempts to provide the reader with insight into the legal
column3: ethical
column4: moral
column5: and medical aspects of the tragic death of Terri Schiavo.   He falls far short of the mark on all of them.  In his November 6
column6: 2005 review for the New York Times William Saletan succinctly sums up the book:  ""Using Terri" is just another use of Terri."   Eisenberg begins with the death of his 79 year old aunt Ros trying to draw a parallel between her and Terri.  The situations could not be more different.  No one
column7: not Eisenberg
column8: nor her two brothers had any desire to care for Ros.   Her case is indeed tragic and agonizing.  Had she not been dehydrated to death her fate would most probably have been to remain institutionalized and uncared for until she finally succumbed to a sad end.  A very different fate awaited Terri were she to be delivered into the care of her parents and siblings.  She would have received the best loving care and devotion that her parents could lavish on her; she would have most probably lived a long life
column9: giving love to all those around her and perhaps even being able to receive the love that was lavished upon her.  But Eisenberg and the bioethics community would have us believe that Terri's life was a life "not worthy of life".   They are absolutely certain
column10: beyond all doubt
column11: that a severely brain damaged person is
column12: in fact not a person at all.   He or she is simply a vegetable to be treated as an inanimate object.  Vegetables
column13: like pet rocks
column14: and tomatoes can never receive love.  Vegetables do not have
column15: nor should they have
column16: access to the rights and privileges that "normal" people take for granted.  This certainty permeates Eisenberg's book at every level and every page.  Symptomatic of this certainty is the obscenely arrogant inscription placed by Michael on Terri's tombstone which reads "Born December 3
column18: departed this earth February 25 1989
column19: at peace March 31
column20: 2005."     What Eisenberg and so many in the bioethics community conveniently forget is that all too often the most horrendous acts of cruelty and evil are committed by those that
column21: like them
column22: are absolutely certain that what they are doing is good and just.  Jacob Bronowski devotes a chapter in his classic work "The Ascent of Man" to the issue of knowledge and uncertainty.   In describing the Nazi horror he stands in swamp outside the crematorium at Auschwitz and declares:   "When people believe that they have absolute knowledge
column23: with no test in reality
column24: this is how they behave. This is what men do when they aspire to the knowledge of gods... We have to cure ourselves of the itch for absolute knowledge and power."       If you feel you must read this book I would at least urge you to exam impartially the other side.  Read Wesley Smith; read David Galenter
column25: read Dr. Daniel Eisenberg; read Jacob Bronowski; read Rita Marker
column26: and yes read father Frank Pavone whom Eisenberg so brutal and unjustly demonizes.   They are my heroes.   And question Eisenberg's statements
column27: his description of the events
column28: his conclusions and especially his demonizing of those who disagree with him.  Sometimes one's motives and philosophies can be revealed in the most trivial passages.  There is one such sentence that especially struck me in "Using Terri"; on p 191 Eisenberg describes the scene at the hospice on the last day of Terri life:  "A woman blew on a shofar - a ritual horn sounded by the ancient Hebrews during battle."   As a Jew and as human being I find such appalling ignorance of my religion deeply insulting.  But in a wider sense perhaps it is symptomatic of Eisenberg's utter contempt for everything that does not fit into a purely secular framework and does not worship at the altar of the false god of autonomy.

column1: I've read a few books by ex-CIA folks now and they all seem to have an overblown sense of arrogance and self-importance. Drumheller makes the case that the CIA was made the scape-goat in the lies that supported the Iraq invasion by providing faulty intelligence. The critical point being the Iraqi informant called "Curveball" that was being protected by German intelligence. Drumheller laments that Curball's self-serving claims where used without proper vetting out
column2: that he (Curveball) had been long declared a "fabricator"
column3: and that no American intelligence professional had even been allowed to speak with him before Colin Powell used the unproven claims to construct his now famous "mobile biological labs" speech delivered to the UN as the 'foundation' of the WMD case. Drumheller makes this case within the first 90 pages of his book
column4: but also convinces you that while he might be right
column5: he could have been a little more proactive when it mattered. For example
column6: after he reached his epiphany that the administration was molding the intelligence to fit the politics
column7: he should have started talking to the press right then and there.  Drumheller's entire mission in this book was to say "the CIA is a good organization
column8: we did our job
column9: but we where   wronged". Maybe so
column10: but you took an oath to protect and defend the constitution
column11: you saw it being trashed
column12: and you did nothing when you could have made a difference.

column1: This was my second book by James Robert Baker
column2: so obviously there was something in the first book I read by him (Testosterone) that made me want to know more of his work. I think with this one I've had my fill. If this and Testosterone are two of his best works
column3: I've had enough.(btw
column4: I thought Testosterone much the better of the two.)  What is interesting about this book was the way Baker described the 80's and 90's and an era of AIDS angst in southern California.  He does capture the mood and the anger that were 'out there' in the gay community in the Regan and early Bush (the pappa) years (I am ten years younger than Baker and was living in Los Angeles in the same time.) So from that perspective the book was a time capsule.   But what was overly annoying were the overdrawn situations and the relationship of Time and Pete.  It just didin't ring true to me.  What did ring true was the anger and the over-the-top obsessive / compusiveness of the protagonist Tim (clearly drawn from Baker's own life experience).  It is sad (but not surprising after reading these books) to learn that Baker committed suicide in 1997 at age 51. He was clearly a man with lots of issues on many levels. And a lot of the issues Baker deals with are not different than issues gay men deal with today (HIV
column5: aging
column6: the superficiality of many gay communiites).  Baker's responses all seem so extreme.   All in all
column7: the book has become a period piece of the days when Act Up and Queer Nation were out there in a big way
column8: which is an interesting counterpoint to the passiveness of the gay community today.  Also
column9: one does wonder if Baker would have toned-down his brash and outlandish writing style with the advent of some maturity that comes with age.

column1: I can not recommend this book.  While reading it I found 4 major errors.  This leads me to believe that the author did not do any research nor did his editors do any fact checking.  The 4 errors I found are as follows: 1. The author states that no trace of the crew of the B-24 Lady Be Good was  ever found.  All but one of the bodies of the crew of the Lady Be Good were  found by the mid-1960s.  2. The author states that Zeke was the allied name  for a kamikaze.  Zeke was the U.S. Navy code name for the Japaneese  Mitsubishi Zero-sen fighter plane.  The U.S. Navy gave Japaneese fighters  male names and bombers female names.  Any WWII historian should know this.   3. The part about the rescue of Eddie Rickenbacker says that a 2-man  Kingfisher float plane spotted their raft and they were picked up by a PT  boat.  In reality
column2: the Kingfisher landed on the ocean and picked them up.   Since the plane only had two seats
column3: the survivors held on the wings and the  pilot taxied across the water to an island.  4.  In the section on the  death of Joe Kennedy Jr. he states that the mission was to attack the  London Gun sites.  This is incorrect
column4: the mission was to attack  U-boat  pens.  He also incorrectly states the crews of the bombers were to bail out  over German held territory.  The crews were to bail out over England and  the bomber would be flown by radio control to the target. There are other  things in the book that just don't seem correct. column1: This book is fine if you are interested in a purely academic approach. This offers nothing for practitioners
This is a philosophy book. There is almost nothing about natural selection and not much more about religion
column2: just plenty of standard philosophy loosely connected to a condemnation of current western culture and its supposed pseudoscience sustenance. Midgley uses the term 'evolution' to mean the philosophizing of scientists and science writers. As religion too is human philosophizing it is hardly difficult to make the two converge.  This 'evolution' Midgley citicizes as being too human-centred. As there is nothing more human-centred than the social sciences
column3: humanities and religion and this 'evolution' is really philosophy then it is an empty criticism. Only the physical sciences look beyond humans but this is unacknowledged.  She is
column4: though
column5: correct in saying that natural selection is not about progress up a ladder nor about a hostile
column6: doom and gloom world. Other than this her grasp of biology is suspect eg she asks how genes can be selfish when they die when the cells they are in die!!!!! No wonder the excellent work of people such as Dawkins is beyond her grasp if she does not understand the connection between body cells and germ-line cells.  Though I generally agree with Midgley's concerns about competitive greed and the destruction of our planet I think she is wrong to blame science
column7: pseudoscience or sociobiology and to disconnect people in modern western culture from their ancestors and their cousins in other cultures. She is clearly out of her depth when it comes to biology
column8: at least.  With a statement that evolution is the creation myth of our age plus the eye-catching mistitle of this book Midgley is far more guilty of hyperbole and melodrama and potentially far more misguided and damaging than
column9: for example
column10: Dawkins when he used the 'as if' selfish gene perspective.  There are a few interesting discussions of works by scientists and philosophers but
column11: especially for the science writers she criticizes
column12: I would very much recommend people read the books themselves and not simply accept Midgley's views on them.

column1: First the good points:  This book is quite well-written
column2: and an excellent overview of many competing "therapies" for autistic children.  Both myself and my sister have worked extensively with autistic children
column3: and we have family members who suffer from both autism and Asperger's syndrome.  But....  This book is EXTREMELY biased--and sadly
column4: not altogether true.  The Lovaas method is praised as "recovering" children from autism
column5: and though Mrs. Maurice repeatedly states that her children are "recovered
column6: from the evidence she herself provides, it's fairly clear her children were not autistic" to begin with.  It seems that while her daughter may have had some mild-to-moderate form of developmental disorder
column7: she was obviously not autistic (and the idea that her daughter "recovered" in a matter of mere months is ludicrous).  Even sillier is the story of her youngest son
column8: who does not seem to have developed any indications of autism beyond being a late talker.  It seems as if Mrs. Maurice found doctors who told her what she wanted to hear
column9: and then became obssesed with "recovering" her children.  Clearly her daughter benefitted from the early intervention
column10: but Maurice's story lacks credibility.  For those who have children with true autism
column11: Mrs. Maurice's story of a "miracle cure" will prove more devastating than encouraging.  (A particularly tragic story of a woman named "Lucille" is appended to the book
column12: who upended her family's life to enroll her autistic son in a Lovaas-based program--partly on Maurice's advice--and whose son has so far made little progress).  There are autistic children who do become very high-functioning
column13: even mainstreamed
column14: but deficits remain.  That Maurice's children "recovered" so fully and rapidly is proof that they were never autistic to begin with.  At her interview with her child's behavioral therapist
column15: she states decisively
column16: "Anne-Marie IS going to recover."  Of course--since she'd already decided in her mind that her daughter was autistic
column17: it was easy enough to then declare her "recovered" a few months later.  Maurice seems not to understand that autism is a "spectrum" disorder
column18: and she accepts as faith that it is a completely neurological disorder.  Much like depression
column19: autism can have either biological or psychological causes
column20: and the root cause is not always so clear.  At one point she notes "Failed bonding is a result of autism
column21: not the cause"--but again
column22: this isn't always true.  Even more biased is her presentation of the various alternative therapies for autism.  She rejects all medication therapy; various nutritional approaches (such as those for food allergies and Vitamin B) are briefly raised and then dismissed.  Her extreme prejudice towards holding therapy belies her own statement that she believe it to have some "real" if "limited" worth.  She paints Dr. Martha Welch as a dangerous flake
column23: a gross libel.  Dr. Welch may well have been a bit New-Agey for her tastes
column24: but I have seen children benefit enormously from it.    Even more dishonestly
column25: she viciously pans Virginia Axline's seminal "play therapy
column26: which has stood the test of time and which, again, I have personally seen the benefits of.  It is true that behavioral therapy has an excellent track record in terms of helping children become higher-functioning, but no one therapy is a magic bullet."  In my experience
column27: children benefit from an integrated program which includes behavioral
column28: speech
column29: play
column30: and nutritional therapy (and very often also medication
column31: though the author does not explain her animosity toward it.)    Lastly
column32: though I am not indicting the author for being rich
column33: she blithely ignores the fact that the average parents (not working on a Wall Street
column34: not a nonworking wife who has a full-time nanny anyway
column35: not living in a fancy Manhattan prewar co-op
column36: etc.) cannot afford to have this type of intensive treatment brought into their homes
column37: and must instead become advocates for their children within the local school system.  Maurice does supply some valuable information on the appeals process with schools  and HMOs.  But if you are the parent of an autistic child
column38: think again before reading this book.  It will likely hurt your feelings
column39: and what good information it provides is readily available elsewhere.

column1: Literary coincidences occur occasionally
column2: and this year's coincidence is the appearance of two novels about Henry James
column3: both written by authors hailing from countries east of the Atlantic. (The other novel is David Lodge's Author
column4: Author; I'll review that book here soon.) It is as if James has been appropriated by Irish and British authors
column5: having been largely ignored by those of his native America for so long. James
column6: who became a British citizen at the end of his life
column7: spent most of his productive years in England and continental Europe. It is no surprise that his fiction has a European flavor
column8: nor is it any surprise that he is such a beacon for British and Irish writers.  The Master in question is old Henry himself
column9: who
column10: in the final period of his life
column11: has received this nickname from critics in praise of the quality of his prose and plots (James was arguably the greatest American author of his period; I confess to being a James fan myself
column12: and even have a print of his portrait
column13: painted by John Singer Sargeant
column14: on the wall next to my desk).   At this time
column15: Henry attempted to break into the theater
column16: with the belief that he would not only achieve recognition from the general public but also the fortune that accompanies such success. In the way writers want to sell scripts to Hollywood today
column17: James wanted to sell his stories to the London theater. Alas
column18: it was a failure; a resounding failure
column19: one that shook James' resolve and faith in himself.   Tibn is clearly a Jamesophile
column20: yet he portrays old Henry as a socially inept
column21: somewhat confused old man
column22: who is uncomfortable at dinners and balls
column23: and who longs for his preferred solitude
column24: which he eventually finds in the house he purchases in the small town of Rye. While some may claim that this is a valid portrayal of James
column25: though exaggerated
column26: Tibn neglects to provide the book with a plot
column27: and instead merely relates a series of incidents and events in Henry's life. While Tibn's writing is agreeable-it is
column28: naturally
column29: somewhat Jamesian-his story has little interest. Seen as a series of vignettes
column30: cobbled together with flashbacks to try and put some depth into the story
column31: Tibn shows James far too incompletely to make a novel that works.   For Tibn seems obsessed with showing examples of James' alleged homosexuality
column32: going as far as inventing an incident with Oliver Wendell Holmes
column33: when the two of them shared a bed in their youth. Recent years have seen many "scholars" suggesting that James is homosexual
column34: though the evidence is of the "they have weapons of mass destruction" type. In fact
column35: after reading this book
column36: with its unsuccessful denouement
column37: one wonders if Tibn simply wanted to present this hypothesis in a fictional form
column38: and filled in the rest so there would be something worth publishing.   Tibn does little more than fill in spaces around events described by Leon Edel in his monumental biography of Henry James. By fleshing out these events
column39: Tibn does give more life to them than Edel does
column40: but is it worth it? To me
column41: having read Edel recently
column42: and being familiar with James' work
column43: the book seemed to drag on
column44: as I hoped to find some sort of narrative thread in the work. But I was not fortunate; Tibn simply relates events
column45: albeit occurring within a specific period
column46: without doing more than adding dialog and inner impressions to the characters actions.   But this raises a deeper question about such a book. That a writer of Tibn's ilk could simply create a docu-drama of some events in a real person's life suggests that he is in a period of plotter's block. It is relatively simple to depend on reality
column47: and add a few strokes of dialog
column48: and while it is oft said that truth is stranger than fiction
column49: in this case
column50: the truth doesn't provide for an interesting read. James' life was certainly remarkable
column51: yet decidedly uneventful. And Tibn's choice of telling a part of that story in this manner falls flat
column52: in part because there is no real denouement.   Many reviewers seem to be fawning over this book
column53: using such panegyrics as "the literary novel of the summer." But it seems that these critics are jaded
column54: and willingly accept anything that has a "classical" background in order to escape the banality of much contemporary fiction. Henry James was an extraordinary writer
column55: an exceptional man
column56: in his own manner
column57: and his life is quite a story
column58: but he is poorly served by this "novel"
column59: which seems to be little more than an exercise in fictionalizing such a man's life. This book will certainly appeal to the boobs (as Mencken called them)
column60: who find it just the right thing to make them look smart
column61: but readers looking for a good book would be better off picking up some of the Master's work and ignoring Tibn.

John Ames
column2: the preacher-protagonist of Marilynne Robinson's Gilead
column3: remarks at one point that in all his reading
column4: what he has learned most is that "some very tedious gentlemen have written books." Indeed.   Unlike the deliberately slow-paced narrative of Housekeeping
column5: the epistolary Gilead drags in other
column6: less successful ways. As the aging Ames writes to his son
column7: he attempts to chronicle his own life and gives us glimpses of his father's and grandfather's
column8: both preachers in their own right. But as the elderly do
column9: he tells the story haphazardly
column10: the first hundred pages consisting almost solely of discontinuous ponderings and pithy religious truths. Ames admits
column11: "I sometimes almost forget my purpose in writing this
column12: and the reader grudgingly agrees, starting to wonder if even Robinson believes it when Ames says, it is hard to make people care about old things."  Not that he doesn't try. For a pastor--and the book is pastoral in more ways than one--Ames can sound obnoxiously self-important ("Often when someone saw the light burning in my study long into the night
column13: it only meant I had fallen asleep in my chair"). His efforts at conjuring religious imagery are riddled with mixed metaphors that often fall short ("Mary Magdelene probably made an occasional casserole
column14: whatever the ancient equivalent may have been. A mess of pottage
column15: I suppose"). Though exceedingly eloquent throughout
column16: he also cops out in his most revelatory moments ("If only I had the words to tell you")
column17: leaving the reader unfulfilled. Like the mysteries of godliness
column18: the book simply leaves us to wonder
column19: if only on something far less significant.  Still
column20: there is balm in Gilead. Though Ames' antagonist (and namesake) doesn't appear until ninety pages into the book
column21: this plotline's parallels with the prodigal son work better than others
column22: and his appearance gives the book a direction that allows it to explore its more successful themes of home and healing. Somehow despite his meanderings
column23: Ames finally brings us to a place where we sympathize with his plight and want to hear his life lessons as much as he needs to share them. If only he had gotten us there sooner

column1: I'm going to take the con side of this debate.  Having not really read many comics in the past 20 years or so I really haven't followed any of the Ultimates stuff.  I have had it explained to me by a co-worker that's a big comic buff.  It seems to make sense to update some heros' origins.  After all Nick Fury and Dum Dum Dugan would be in their ninties these days.  I understand that they are also keeping the original origins in place which is fine.  Having said that
column2: I don't know if this is an Ultimate storyline or not but I didn't care for it at all.    Taken as a stand alone movie
column3: if viewed by someone with no idea of who Iron Man is
column4: this is really run of the mill.  Tony Stark wasn't a very cohesive character.  As far as alter-egos go this one is kind of a hypocritical milksap.  He makes a big deal out of not building weapons but has an entire room full of indestructible power armor.  If the suits are for research why the need for powerful lasers and missles?  The writer's seem to face the same dilemma most of Hollywood finds itself in these days.  It's politically incorrect to endorse violence but you still have to give the audience a good action packed fight scene.  As a result you get unrealistic portrayals of altruistic millionaire industrialists and pacifists with more weapons than Dirty Harry.  I may be reading a little too much into a cartoon but the level of some of the violence here (one person gets executed with a gunshot to the back of the head) suggests this is for a mature audience.  If this is the case the writers should have given the actions and motivations more depth.  The biggest problem is the time it takes to actually get to Iron Man.  Once there the fight scenes are few and far between.  The film suffers from the same problem a lot of live action superhero movies suffer from
column5: too much screen time for the alter-ego.  The action sequences are lacking visual impact.  I think that is partly due to the mediocre quality of the animation.  The CG doesn't mix too badly with the hand drawn but it's all just servicable at best.  In the end the movie seemed overly long and convulted with the end being a less than satisfying resolution.  Even if I weren't aware of Iron Man before this I don't think I would recommend it as anything more than a rental

column1: I bought this for our daughter and decided to open it

column1: I have usually enjoyed this series since the first title was released. As time goes on
column2: I find myself waiting longer to read these books. They just aren't a "must read" any more.  Like: The humor! No one does this aspect as well.       The mystery
column3: when it is actually a mystery.       Her friends - what an amazing assortment of characters.    Dislike: The whining. Its more than time for Eve to face up to her past - or not. just do it one way or the other. Other people (in real life) with much less going for them (supportive spouse & friends
column4: job
column5: respect and so on) have managed to face thier pasts in a healthier way than Eve. I do tire of reading about the horrific abuse in every book. Isn't it time for Roarke to use his influence and find her parents? We all know the man she killed wasn't really her father
column6: right? She has to be a much-missed child from good parents.         The sex. Perhaps some people read Robb for the sex scenes but they bore me. I find they bring the series down rather than elevating it. These scenes I skip and its easy to do since
column7: once they start
column8: they invariably take up the rest of the chapter. Why not leave these scenes to the heavy-breathing historical type stuff she writes?         Love Roarke but dislike that we have to always hear what a bad boy he was. This book kind of moved away from that. Kind of.   Overall
column9: its just time for the main characters to grow up and stop sniveling. There are people out there in the world with ever so much less than either one of them have who managed to overcome. Why not make these characters like that?  Oh
column10: and what is with the "stand for"? Someone is always standing for someone. Its written in such a way I just know that no one would ever really talk like that. And its said much too often. She has used that phrase in other books as well (& other series). Perhaps she does know people who speak like that
column11: but I have yet to meet one. Sometimes her characters come across as almost comic when she places words in their mouths that just aren't thiers.  All that said
column12: I honestly do enjoy Robb
column13: but for the mystery and the humor and the relationships. The cop work is usually good
column14: but its been missing. Basically
column15: I could do without all the sex (some romance is lovely) and truly appreciate a good detective story written by a talented woman.

column1: Part of the work involved in writing is editing. Through editing
column2: a writer -or editor if the writer does not do his/her own editing- can eliminate any word that is not essential to the text
column3: minimizing the amount of text required to express the author's ideas. I believe Hemingway wrote about this and how he applied it to his work. In the case of Glickman's book I became bored rather quickly given that she took too many pages to express the same ideas and concepts. It's not that the idea is a bad one
column4: but I don't think that the book is "The Best it can be." It is written in a sub-optimal manner. I purchased the book based on the glowing reviews
column5: and on the comments by respected authors such as Covey
column6: Blanchard
column7: et. al. De Bono's comment seems to be focused on Thinking
column8: not Optimal Thinking
column9: though. While I'm glad the book is appreciated by many people
column10: famous or not

column12: repetitive
column13: and disappointing after reading so much praise. I have a lot of material to read
column14: and need to optimize the way I invest my time. In a sense
column15: after the first couple of chapters
column16: I felt I was wasting my time reading this book. I wish I had found Steve Pavlina's brief review prior to purchasing Optimal Thinking. I will give it 2 stars because it does contain useful ideas. I don't think so many pages are required to express these ideas

column1: Let's start with the good things about this book.  It has extensive quotes from no less than 67 documents that are relevant to the conflict
column2: along with five tables
column3: two charts
column4: and 23 maps.  And it does supply plenty of facts.  But this book completely misses the big picture
column5: partially due to bias and partially due to poor scholarship.  Absurdly irrelevant events
column6: such as Arafat saying (for the thirtieth time) that he might do something to promote peace
column7: are given star treatment when they deserve no mention at all.  Major aspects of the conflict
column8: such as the training of a generation of Arabs to be nihilistic antisemites
column9: get little attention.  It is taken for granted that small details about borders are the main issues: the possibility that the fight is over something as fundamental as human rights is discounted.  The authors explicitly realize that the task of the historian is to determine truth
column10: explain it
column11: weed out lies
column12: infer as yet unknown details
column13: and predict the future.  They simply fail in that task.  Not only do they implicitly accept many manifest fabrications (only to take out their suspicions on those who ought not be mistrusted without good cause)
column14: they often fail to distinguish between errors of judgment and outright malice.  It is sad to see such problems with what could have been a far more useful reference.

column1: This novel is narrated by a senior at an exclusive boys' boarding school
column2: portrayed as the type of place where all of the students are hiding their true selves.  Those who are wealthy try desperately to hide that fact
column3: and those who are on scholarship
column4: as is the narrator
column5: try even harder to hide their heritage.  As this story is told from the point of view of one character
column6: it is impossible to determine if this is actually true
column7: or if his fear of being exposed as a fraud clouds his vision of everyone else.  It is hard for me to believe that these boys are so disconnected from each other.  According to the narrator
column8: nobody is really friends with anybody else
column9: despite the fact that they have been living with each other for so many years.  No student has any real relationship with any other student.  What is real
column10: is literature.  Writers are artists
column11: who form their own social club and are therefore able to escape the boxes into which their heritage has forced them.  It seems every boy at school aspires to write
column12: and once every semester the class is rewarded with a visit from a famous author.  These visits are paired with writing contests
column13: in which boys submit a piece of writing in the style of the famous author.  The student whose writing is chosen by the visiting author is rewarded with a private audience with him or her--an unbelievable honor for the student.  The narrator of the book is desperate for one of these audiences
column14: and devastated when his opportunity to interact with Robert Frost and Ayn Rand passes him by.  When he finds that Ernest Hemingway is to be the next visiting author
column15: he is willing to do anything
column16: even plagiarize a story he comes across in a literary magazine
column17: to meet the famous man.  Some of the parts of this story are interesting
column18: especially those focused on the visiting authors.  I particularly liked the passages about Ayn Rand and was delighted when a boy asked her
column19: quite seriously
column20: "Who is John Galt?" and received nothing but looks of utter loathing in response.  I also liked the responses of the authors to the works of the students.  The boys submitted very earnest bits of poetry or fiction that were terribly misinterpreted by the authors who judged them and read much more into them than the boys had ever anticipated or expected.  However
column21: I didn't really connect with any of the characters
column22: perhaps because the narrator of the story never got close to anyone.  He talks about his roommate and how the two of them lived together for years and kept seeming like they might become friends
column23: but it never really happened.  In fact
column24: the narrator
column25: although friendly with many
column26: seems to have no actual friends.  There is only one girl who might be a love interest in the story
column27: but the narrator also has only minimal feelings for her.  In the end
column28: this lack of interest for anyone in the story left me feeling rather uninterested in everything
column29: as well.

column1: For good or bad there are certain things one comes to expect when watching animes especially after watching them for many years. Surely the avid anime enthusiast would like to see more and more serious anime films
column2: but at the same time they'd like an anime feel to their films... what's most important though is whether or not the film is intriguing
column3: creative
column4: and powerful. This film fails short of all of those things and instead pretends to be something it isn't.  This didn't have an anime feel... which wasn't really a problem for me - I've seen a number of anime movies which were serious
column5: but this movie was - in my opinion - about as horrible as they come.   Trying to show itself off as a feel good anime film about Christmas (how many damn Christmas-happy movies do we have out there?)
column6: this anime follows the same premise as thousands of films before it and fails in the face of them. "A Christmas Story" and all of those films far surpass both the quality and thematic/story-delivery found within Tokyo Godfathers.   Are we supposed to like it because these themes are found within a Japanese animation? I doubt anyone could really say that the visuals were great (they were not
column7: but that's beside the point since visuals aren't all that matters)
column8: I doubt anyone can even say this film was really all that original (the only thing semi-original about it is the cast of "odd fellow" characters like the street bum with the heart of gold who wants nothing more than to have a child of her own... except she is a transvestite
column9: really a man).   I feel really bad about posting this review considering so many people enjoyed it
column10: but I can only guess that they haven't watched very many Christmas movies in the past or that they have little to no capacity for judging films accurately.  The director however is one of my favorite - I deeply enjoyed Perfect Blue and Millennium Actress is perhaps my favorite anime movie ever made - after watching this movie though I'm kind of disappointed that fans of decided to "cling" onto this movie and call it a classic when in reality it mimics half a dozen non-animated titles and brings nothing new or intriguing to the table.   Furuya was successful in taking a bland film
column11: creating such a big hype over it by attaching his renowned name to it and putting a child in it and some heart breaking tales already told time and again. column1: Robin Hobb knows how to write well and proved it with Assassin's Apprentice. Unfortunately
column2: she seems to be in love with her descriptive prose and forgets mundane items such as plot
column3: action
column4: and likable (or at least interesting) characters. Ship of Magic suffers from an excess of flowery prose adorning a dull
column5: meandering story containing uninteresting and mostly unlikable characters. I read a quarter of the book and stopped. Some of the (mostly glowing) reviews claim that the book gets better
column6: but my patience dwindled to naught.  Specific things I disliked:  1. Another Hobb book in which magic but inanimate objects (the wood of the liveship) come to life only after multiple people (three generations of ship owners
column7: in this book) die while touching the object. Can't her magic creatures have lives and personalities of their own?  2. Teens and young adults rarely learn from mistakes and repeatedly act stupid. (Maybe they are all budding politicians.)  3. The interwoven story of sea serpents from some other plane of existence is distracting because of lack of context. It probably will make sense later
column8: but it adds nothing but confusion in the early chapters. Hobb should have started the book at the middle or near-end of the story (so we would know the importance of the serpents and the liveships) and then gone back in time.  4. The members of the main family are mostly unlikable. The only likable one has unrealistic lines: the 13-year-old acolyte talks like a 50-year-old philosopher

column1: The book may be entertaining to read because of the way Mankiw sets his examples. Unfortunately what we have in our hands is the same irrealistic exposition of how the economy works that has been dominating university curriculums from the first day Adam Smith was appointed at Glasgow. As an example I may cite my personal experience as a teaching assistant. When explaining the comparative advantage theory I obviously gave the Ricardian demonstration of the theory. But when I wanted to treat the absolute advantage theory
column2: Marx's name was nowhere to be found. Even Samuelson devoted some pages to Marx's contribution to economic theory. President Bush's economic advisor seems to lack objective exposition when dealing with basic economic theories. I don't consider myself to be paranoid
column3: but the economics curriculum
column4: and it's instruments
column5: such as this book
column6: only serve a mode of reproduction of the dominant ideology
column7: which we all know has lots of contradictions that everyday spring up in everybody's life. It is time to bring to the market a more balanced exposition of the various tendencies within economics
column8: even if the course is described as being introductory. Most of the people who take these basic courses don't even know that there are alternative paradigms. They just finish their Mankiw's as if nothing else could be thought about how the economy really works
